PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask: what were the reasons for the Government's change of mind to allow the Australian troops about to go to Cambodia to be armed? When will the Minister make a statement to the Parliament about Australia's full commitment to the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Cambodia and, in particular, the number of Australian personnel involved in the second and larger phase of the operation, known as the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia?

—Whether the troops were to be armed or not armed was a matter of a recommendation made over time. I do not think there was a specific decision in regard to that being either yes or no. It was one of the things to be considered, and a decision was made in favour of it.

PARA.TAB: On the broader question of a statement, it is not always Government policy to make a statement on every commitment to a United Nations peacekeeping force, but my understanding is that the Prime Minister intends to make a major statement on Cambodia. The only hold up in that statement at the moment, as I understand it, is that we are still negotiating with the United Nations on the second and larger contingent, its nature and its composition, and we did not want to pre-empt that at this stage. As soon as those negotiations are over, the Prime Minister will make a statement in the Parliament, and I assume either Senator Button or Senator Evans will replicate it here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Referring to the answer to the second part of my question, in view of the fact that there has been a large number of what are presumably speculative reports about the number of Australian troops who will be committed—there are 40 going in a few days; so it is as low as that, but even up to 1,000 troops have been the subject of speculation—is that not a good reason for an early statement to be made about the size, at least, of this commitment?

—There are two Australian contributions, one to UNAMIC and one to UNTAC, and it is on the second one that Senator Durack asks his question. I think it is relevant that a statement be made on it, but the difficulty at the moment is that probably up to 20 or 30 countries have considered at Cabinet level, or whatever other decision making process they go through, the type of contribution they would like to make. It is then the task of the United Nations to coordinate all those offers and to determine whether they can be acceptable.

PARA.TAB: There is not much point if every country offers air transport and no-one offers anything else. We are still involved in that process, and the United Nations is still involved in that process, of determining the acceptability of each country's offer and trying to blend them together. It is for that reason that we cannot necessarily anticipate that our favoured configuration that we have offered will or will not be accepted. I am fairly confident that it will be accepted, and as soon as that point is reached, as I indicated, the Prime Minister will make a full statement to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of members of a delegation from the parliaments of Nauru, Niue and Tonga. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming them to the Senate. I trust that their time in Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister explain the precise nature of the agreements signed recently in Paris on a settlement of the Cambodian conflict and outline Australia's expected role in the implementation phase of the settlement?

—Some aspects of this have been covered in the answer that Senator Robert Ray has just given. So far as the political side of the settlement is concerned, the agreements signed in Paris were four, two of them of treaty status and two supplementary agreements. The first was an agreement on a comprehensive political settlement of the conflict committing all parties to it to a permanent cease-fire, the demobilisation of military forces, the holding of free and fair elections, the adoption of a new democratic constitution and the associated arrangements involving the United Nations in supervising this entire process.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, there was a declaration by Cambodia of its future neutrality and guarantees of that neutrality simultaneously by other states, including the provision for joint action which might be taken in the event of a threat to that neutrality. The third element was a declaration on rehabilitation and reconstruction describing the principles and processes involved in reconstruction assistance. Then there was the final act of the Paris conference, so-called, which is essentially a procedural document, describing the status of the conference and the various agreements signed at it.

As honourable senators will know, the agreements in Paris represent the culmination of more than two years of very hard and patient work by the Permanent Five; members of the Security Council; the regional countries, particularly Indonesia as co-chairman of the Paris conference; Australia; and the Cambodian parties under the chairmanship recently of Prince Sihanouk. As has been gracefully acknowledged in a number of quarters in the past couple of weeks, the settlement is based in very large part on general principles and quite detailed proposals devised and developed by Australia over the past two years.

While the achievement of the settlement itself is momentous and historic, we, like everybody else, are now concentrating our energies towards assisting in the very complex and difficult process which remains ahead of implementing the settlement. We have provided an electoral expert to the UN to assist in preparatory activities for the eventual holding of elections, which we hope will take place in a year or so. As has just been said, we will shortly send a 40-man contingent to Cambodia to provide vital communications links as part of the United Nations Advance Mission into Cambodia—known as UNAMIC.

We also plan to make a major contribution in personnel and materiel to the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia, UNTAC, probably involving about 500 personnel—as Senator Ray has said, that has not yet been resolved—and possibly involving the military command in question. As Senator Ray has said, and I can only—

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you told the Minister for Defence this?

—That is the order of magnitude that is presently being contemplated. It is impossible to be precise about it because the overall numbers have not yet been resolved. It is not just a matter of each individual country's contribution, which, as Senator Ray has said, still remains to be resolved; it is a question of the overall numbers. The working premise is that it is of that order of magnitude, but a lot remains to be settled and there is no point in making any final statement about that until it is settled. The main UN body, UNTAC, will be deployed from early next year to provide major humanitarian and administrative assistance to the Cambodians and to help guarantee that neutral and secure environment for the holding of free and fair elections, which is the indispensable requirement of the whole Cambodian settlement.

PARA.TAB: We are now in the process of establishing a physical mission on the ground in Phnom Penh to support our activities in the implementation phase. I am anticipating that we will have a resident Australian ambassador in Phnom Penh by late November. I will be visiting Cambodia on present expectations in mid-December.

Might I say finally that Australia will not step back from its responsibilities to provide an appropriate level of assistance to repatriation and reconstruction efforts in the country. We have just provided $1m to the UNHCR for the repatriation of displaced Cambodians on the Thai-Cambodian border and we are very actively encouraging the early convening of the International Committee of Reconstruction in Cambodia—ICORC as it has been designated—which is provided for in the settlement documents and which will have the task of encouraging greater coordination in planning and organising the provision of longer term assistance in the reconstruction and development of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
—Ask him about Cambodia and how you got it wrong.

—Senator Bolkus should come back and ask that in a year's time. Does the Australian Government support the European Community's peace plan for Yugoslavia, as agreed by five of the six Yugoslav republics on 25 October? Has the Australian Government communicated that support to the President of the Republic of Serbia, as the one republic holding out, and to the chairman of the peace conference in The Hague, in order that Australia might be associated with an international consensus on the best way to end this tragedy?

—We are awaiting the outcome of the Hague conference—which is presently proceeding and which will reconvene this evening, Australian time—before forming a final judgment of our own on what we can most usefully do to support or contribute to a settlement on that basis.
—Meanwhile Vukovar is going down the drain.

—I would like to hope that with Senator Harradine's vocal support we could single-handedly solve the problems of the world in general and Yugoslavia in particular. The problem is, as everyone should know by now, an immensely complex one. It has been very difficult to secure the active agreement to and effective enforcement of, on both sides, the various tentative cease-fires that have so far been reached.

PARA.TAB: Although I have said often enough in this place and elsewhere in recent times that we believe the primary responsibility for the scale of the violence which is presently occurring must rest with the Serbian authorities, nonetheless, it is not the case that the other side to the conflict—the Croatian side—is completely immune from responsibility for the continuation of this particular conflict. It is a very difficult situation to manage, both for the parties on the ground and for those who are trying very hard to get a peace settlement in place.

We are awaiting the decision of the EC on the question of economic sanctions, which does seem to be the likely next step in the European process if the parties are unable to reach a workable consensus among themselves. Should developments point to that need, we will move quickly in concert with the EC and with the UN Security Council, if that too becomes involved, to meet our appropriate responsibilities.

All I can say at this point of time is, bearing in mind what is happening in The Hague and the likely meeting very soon of the UN Security Council, that we will very strongly support international moves to produce a sensible result. We continue to call upon all the parties to this conflict, as we have from its very outset, to observe restraint and to go down the path of a negotiated solution. We will do everything that we appropriately and sensibly can to support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will be aware of concerning reports that the Burmese Opposition Leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, may be critically ill after starting a fast on 25 October when she was refused permission to see a United Nations human rights investigator. Can the Minister confirm these reports and detail the diplomatic action the Australian Government is taking to protest against the detention of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner?

—When those reports came out a few days ago I immediately asked our ambassadors in Bangkok and Rangoon to investigate them and to report back. It is very difficult to verify the information in question as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is held incommunicado, of course, as everyone knows, under house detention. Recent information from the embassies' contacts in Rangoon just a few days before the reports in question were that she was fit and well.

PARA.TAB: Our assessment, based on all available sources of information, is that it is unlikely that there has been any drastic or dramatic deterioration in her health since that time. There is no definite evidence that she has begun a hunger strike, although there are of course still rumours to that effect in Rangoon. We are continuing our efforts to establish the nature of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's state of health. We are very gravely concerned, obviously, about the reports about her well-being. We would certainly view with the utmost seriousness any information confirming any substance to those reports.

I said on 15 October in this place that Professor Yokota would be visiting Burma as a representative of the UN Commission on Human Rights and was likely to request a meeting with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. I have been advised that she was not successful in obtaining a meeting, which does add extra weight to the concern of the international community about these developments.

In the past 24 hours or so I have initiated contact with a number of other governments that share our concern about Daw Aung San Suu Kyi to propose joint representations, a joint demarche, on her situation to the Burmese regime, and I expect those representations to take place very shortly.

The detention of the Nobel Prize winner seriously infringes internationally accepted standards of human rights and is a matter of enormous concern worldwide. We will continue both to condemn that detention and to demand in very vigorous terms her immediate and unconditional release. We will take any action we possibly can to bring that about and, in the meantime, in a number of other forums, including the United Nations General Assembly, we will be actively pursuing political action to continue the spotlight of attention on this regime.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United States Joint Facilities in Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to recent reports that, following the closure of bases in the Philippines, the United States is interested in increasing its presence in Australia. I ask: has the Australian Government received any approaches from the United States exploring the possibility of expanding the current so-called joint facilities or establishing new ones? Does the Minister agree that such a development would be detrimental to Australia's sovereignty and contrary to Australia's policy of self-reliance in defence matters and should therefore be rejected? Does the Minister agree that the existing bases should be placed under the control of the United Nations for the purpose of monitoring arms reductions by all countries, and that this issue should be raised with President Bush on his forthcoming visit?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Spindler's question is that there has been no approach. The second part of the question is highly hypothetical. I do not want to breach Standing Orders by speculating on that. As to the third part of the question, I do not agree with that, nor do I agree with the flaky press release Senator Spindler has just put out on this subject. I do not think world affairs have quite reached that point.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that, depending on the future, the joint facilities in Australia will continue to be a great contributor to world peace. As to their role well into the future, I do not want to speculate. They could go in any particular direction. At the moment, I would not agree with Senator Spindler's suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister thinks Australia's sovereignty is a hypothetical question, I would like him to tell the Senate whether the present agreement between Australia and the United States on the so-called joint facilities excludes the possibility of the United States sharing information with other countries without reference to Australia first.

—Let me pick up the point of the hypothetical question. The hypothetical question is if there were going to be an increase in the US presence in Australia. I do not need Senator Spindler, in asking a supplementary question, to distort what I have said in this chamber.On the second aspect, the United States must consult with Australia before anyone else shares information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. A recent article in the Australian Financial Review—Thursday, 31 October—questioned the need for the third runway at Sydney Airport and suggested that a more cost effective solution would be to relocate private and commuter operations to Badgerys Creek. Is this the case, and what would be the implications for this sector of the aviation industry in Australia? Does this suggestion recommend itself to the Australian Government?

—No, it does not. I read the article in the Financial Review and I would like to set the record straight in respect of a number of assertions that the article made. The third runway will be funded entirely by the Federal Airports Corporation. No taxpayers' money at all will be spent on the project. On the other hand, the construction of the airport facilities at Badgerys Creek, which I have advised this House of previously, would not be a commercially viable proposition and therefore would require some form of Government contribution.

PARA.TAB: The third runway would generate additional aeronautical revenue for the FAC in the medium to long term, simply through increasing the capacity of the airport and hence allowing access to the airport by an increased number of aircraft.The third runway can also be viewed as a key component of a broad strategy to develop the potential capacity of the airport. The overall result would be a very significant increase in revenue to the FAC.

The suggested forced relocation of commuter operations to Badgerys Creek demonstrates not only a complete lack of understanding of this sector of the industry, but also a supreme contempt for the people of regional New South Wales. Many commuter aircraft are, in fact, operated by the major domestic airlines—which appears to have escaped the author of the article—or subsidiaries on major routes; for example, the Dash 8s that are used on the Sydney-Canberra route. Large segments of the commuter market would find Badgerys Creek totally unacceptable. One-third of the market from commuter flights uses KSA to transfer to both domestic and international flights. A significant amount of traffic also comprises same day business traffic into Sydney.

Apart from pointing out the factual inaccuracies of the article, I want to reiterate something I have said in this chamber before: the Government reasserts its commitment to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport being used as a regional airport for regional New South Wales as well as for the important role that it plays in both domestic and international air traffic in Australia. The suggestion put in the article in the Financial Review would be totally unacceptable to Government. It is the Government's intention to maintain the important role of Sydney Airport as a regional airport for New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to an interview in the Courier-Mail of 1 November in which Labor Senator Bryant Burns described the Tiananmen Square massacre as `a reasonable response' by the Chinese Government to the pro-democracy protests. Given that Senator Burns is a member of the Government and was leader of an Australian parliamentary delegation to China at the time, I ask: does Senator Burns's comment reflect a change in Government policy on the matter since the Prime Minister's statement in 1989 expressing the Government's outrage at the massive and indiscriminate slaughter of thousands of unarmed Chinese pro-democracy protesters and bystanders?

—I have seen the newspaper article in question and I have discussed the matter with Senator Burns. I am assured by him that this was not the position he stated in China. I understand that he indicated to a journalist that the Chinese leadership might have believed that it was reasonable to use force to clear Tiananmen Square in view of—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to what I am saying. He said that the Chinese leadership might have believed itself that it was reasonable to use such force to clear Tiananmen Square in view of the historical and cultural background of that country. However, I am told that he did not indicate that this was in any way acceptable to Australia, and in no way did he indicate any support for the massacre of students.

PARA.TAB: As to the Government's position on these matters, I have made perfectly clear, as has the Prime Minister and other Ministers, our position on the events of 4 June in unmistakable terms. Our view remains that the actions taken by the Chinese Government in suppressing the pro-democracy movement constituted a grossly excessive use of force and a gross violation of basic human rights. Those abuses were also condemned by the governments of like-minded countries.

The lifting of restrictions, I should also say, on our relations with China does not imply in any way that the Government's position in regard to the events of June 1989 has changed. We continue to regard the violence that occurred at that time as totally indefensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I understand from a number of my colleagues who were on the delegation that on a number of occasions Senator Burns said in public speeches, not private comments, that he had an understanding in similar terms of the events, based on cultural differences. I would like to know what cultural differences justify the slaughter of 2,000 to 4,000 people because they were protesting for democracy. Will Senator Evans follow up his words here by asking Senator Burns to withdraw the remarks and to apologise to the ethnic Chinese community in this country, because thousands of them, like my family, came to Australia to flee exactly this sort of communist persecution?

—Obviously, no cultural differences could possibly justify the massacre of individuals. But my understanding, as I have clearly explained to the Senate, is that Senator Burns made no such claim. Under those circumstances, there would appear to be no basis whatsoever for an apology of the kind that is being called for.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. In light of Senator Evans's answer, I wonder whether he would inform the Senate whether he was implying therefore that the journalist who wrote the story lied?
—That is not a point of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has announced the awards under the Australian best practice demonstration program, four of which have gone to South Australian companies, to the total value of $1.7m. Can the Minister tell the Senate what the best practice demonstration program constitutes, why these companies were awarded grants, and what the financial benefits of the program will be?

—This is genuinely a question without notice. The best practice demonstration project was announced in the March economic statement. It is a program by this Government which aims to encourage, by providing some catalytic finance, a change to a new workplace culture in Australian workplaces. It aims to encourage employers and employees jointly to set the goals of the enterprise, to strive for greater productivity and, in the achievement of that, share the rewards fairly between those who have helped generate it in the workplace, the employees, and those who have helped finance the industry, the investors and shareholders, and, of course, to achieve a competitive edge in the marketplace by reducing the price of the good or service to the consumer.

PARA.TAB: The Australian best practice demonstration project offers a series of packages of financial support to companies to enable them to transfer into a best practice mode. There is a limited number of packages. That limited number of packages is auctioned to companies which are interested in making the transfer, and the auction is on the basis of those companies filing corporate plans with a commercial panel of judges. Those corporate plans show how they intend to implement best practice in their companies. The commercial panel is headed by John Prescott, the Chief Executive Officer of BHP, and it looks at what, in its opinion, will be the most successful best practice plans out of those filed.

In the first round—which has just been announced—271 companies made applications; 19 were awarded. This means that, for 19 packages of support, 271 companies have commenced the process of consulting with their workers, drawing up plans and committing themselves to best practice as benchmarked by best world standards. The companies were from a range of industry sectors and were of a range of sizes—big, medium and small. They were mainly in the traded goods sector. The level of applications was very high indeed.

It does show that in this country best practice is catching on; that Australian companies are indeed taking their employees more into their confidence; that we are reaching for higher standards; and that, as tariff protection walls start crumbling under the determinations of this Government, the traded goods area, exposed to best world competition, will be able to emerge to hold its own and in fact succeed in a globalised marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Premier of Western Australia, Dr Lawrence, has stated that the process of the Commonwealth-State financial reform, now effectively aborted, is directly tied to the leadership struggle. Could the Minister explain to the Senate why the Prime Minister considers his political survival more important to the States than the financial reform that he said was so necessary? The Premier has also said that the Prime Minister is betraying the States and that the reform is getting nowhere and getting nowhere fast. Who in the Government is capable of not betraying the States in the way in which the Prime Minister has been and is? When will the reform process commence?

—I am not aware of the details of Dr Lawrence's remarks. I am aware that she did say something about this issue. It is sometimes said that distance lends enchantment to the view. It also lends inaccuracy to the view on occasions.
—Are you going to check it out?

—I do not have to check it out because Senator Knowles referred to it in her question. The November meeting of the Special Premiers Conference will take place as arranged. There are a number of negotiating positions which, in some cases, have led to the creation of draft documents which will be the subject of discussion between the States and the Commonwealth. Many of them are at a substantial stage of agreement.

PARA.TAB: So far as Dr Lawrence may have been referring to the question of revenue sharing, as I understand it, there has been no formal proposal at any stage from the States in terms of the States actually raising income taxes themselves. This is a difficult issue which will be negotiated further. There is nothing more to be said about it at this stage. It has nothing to do with the alleged public arguments which seem to be taking place. It is a matter for negotiation between the Commonwealth Government and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with leadership?
—Not as Senator Knowles thinks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform has again criticised the waterfront reform program and recommended that Australia should follow the approach of the French Government to dock reform. In fact, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The French Government is approaching waterfront reform in a way that exposes the gutlessness of the Hawke Governments's reforms.
Can the Minister advise how the French Government's approach to dock reform differs from that in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that, through this public statement, Mr Sharp has maintained his impeccable and unbroken record of being wrong. He has not put out a single statement in 18 months which has been factually accurate.
—You are sounding like a broken gramophone record.

—I can tell Senator Panizza that I obtained direct advice from the French Government which I am about to deliver to the Senate. I was aware that no valid comparison could be made at this stage between the Australian Government's waterfront reform and the reform being proposed in France because the waterfront reform in France is at such an early stage that it is very difficult to draw any valid conclusions from it. When we did contact the French Government, it was interesting to be advised of its proposal because it appears to bear an amazing similarity to what we are now in the final stages of completing in Australia, which seems to be something that everyone has agreed on except Mr Sharp.

PARA.TAB: Current advice from the French Government is that its reforms are at a very early stage with no framework or timetable yet available, unlike Australia where the current reform program is now in its final stage. However, the French Government does foresee a two-stage process whereby the Government will initially call for port by port negotiations between unions and employers to improve productivity and to address high labour levels; I am not sure where I have heard that before. When productivity gains have been met, the Government intends to provide assistance for early retirement and compensation packages for dockers leaving the industry.

This will sound familiar to everyone apparently, except Mr Sharp. It is fundamentally the same process of negotiated reform that has already been implemented in Australia with government assistance on redundancy of surplus labour after the reforms have been implemented.

The major difference between the Australian and French waterfronts lies in the French Government's still exercising direct regulation over labour arrangements by legislation which, among other things, provides for security of employment for French dock workers. The Australian Federal Government withdrew from direct legislative control of the labour force in 1977, when the industry-wide labour pooling system was introduced. This is now being dismantled under the Government's reform program and being replaced by enterprise employment.

Mr Sharp was apparently excited by French dockyard reform because he got the idea that the Government intended immediately to abolish the security of employment provisions in this legislation. This accorded with Mr Sharp's approach to reform, which is simply to threaten workers with the sack. However, I am advised by the French Government that such legislative change is not a foregone conclusion; no decision has been taken on it. It is hoped by the French Government that negotiations between the industry parties will produce increased efficiency without any extensive government intervention. I hope that it does, too.

In Mr Sharp's view this must make the French Government apparently as gutless as the Australian Government. I do not agree with that assessment. I think the way the French Government is proposing to go, which is very similar to what we have done here in Australia, will be successful. Certainly I hope that it will be as successful as it has been here in Australia. I am sure that by comparison the French Government sees itself as proceeding along a realistic route which eventually will produce a much greater rate of reform than that suggested by the Federal Opposition here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer Senator Button to the statement by the Treasurer following the second Special Premiers Conference 12 weeks ago that the Federal Government was fully committed to handing substantial taxing powers back to the States in order to remove some of the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance, which Treasurer Kerin described as meaning `He who taxes should be the one who spends it'. Does the Treasurer still hold to this view, does it remain Government policy, and will it be the policy approach that the Commonwealth will take to the next Special Premiers Conference in Perth on 21-22 November, at which conference it has always been intended that major decisions on Commonwealth-State financial relations will be taken?

—The Special Premiers Conference is an ongoing process. At the last meeting of that conference some issues were dealt with. Further issues will be dealt with at this meeting of the Special Premiers Conference, and again at the one next year. I am not familiar with what the Treasurer said 12 weeks ago but the object of the Special Premiers Conference is to try to resolve overlapping difficulties between State and Federal governments in a variety of areas and jurisdictions. Those remain the Government's objectives and policies and the Government's position will be put at the Special Premiers Conference in November.

—I ask a supplementary question. May I ask for confirmation of what the Minister said in his response, which I do not think was clear? Is he saying that the Special Premiers Conference in Perth at the end of this month will or will not take major decisions on Commonwealth-State financial relations, as it has been intended and stated publicly from the time of the first Special Premiers Conference more than a year ago that it would?
—I think it is quite likely that it will move considerably further on those issues. Whether it will finalise decisions remains to be seen.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators are a little jealous about all this. They did nothing in the time that they were in office. There is natural jealousy; they have got to psych themselves up again. Things happen at each Special Premiers Conference and will continue to do so.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to a joint statement that he issued last week with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announcing the establishment of new provisions, improving the access for farmers to Jobsearch and Newstart allowances by the relaxation of the assets test. First, is the Minister aware that many aged people who have retired from the family farm are presently living in poverty because they are unable to access the age pension due to the assets test? Secondly, is the Minister aware that, if these older farmers try now to pass the farm on to the new generation who are currently working it, they will be caught by deeming provisions? Finally, is the Minister prepared to make arrangements similar to those that he has now made for Jobsearch and Newstart for the age pension so that those farmers currently living in poverty will be able to access it if they need it?

—The situation is that the Government will seek to amend the Social Security Act to enable some 2,000 farmers who are judged under the rural adjustment scheme to be long term viable but who can no longer take on any further debt to receive JSA.
—They will get it in five years time.

—This is from 1 January. This requires a number of changes. It requires a change to how we define unemployment, as an example, because these are not people who are actually unemployed. They could perhaps be called `underemployed' but not unemployed. Previously, they would have been disqualified on that basis. Also, we have sought to make farmers sell their farms, or put them on the market, and sell off life insurance and that sort of thing when they have gone for benefits. So we would be required to make a number of changes to give effect to this. The honourable senator seeks to add to this those people who are aged persons, who have retired on their farm and who the honourable senator says are living in poverty. I would think there are a great many more people living in poverty in rural Australia than the 2,000 farmers to whom this benefit will be extended. I do not think anyone should pretend otherwise.

PARA.TAB: The question here was to judge those payments that should go to people who were long term viable rather than have the payments used to keep people on the land when, in fact, the farm is not viable in the longer term. I do not think that aged persons can come into that category. It will be very difficult to do away with an assets test for the age pension. I do not know of any way of quarantining an assessment for that which would be in any way fair, just and equitable. I am quite prepared to have a look at the matter. I have done so several times, because the problem has been raised quite a bit, but it is very difficult in definition terms to work out how we would quarantine it to just those people to whom the honourable senator refers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Processing of Allowances and Benefits to Veterans

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that the Public Sector Union is not allowing the processing of non-pension allowances and benefits to veterans, as well as the payment of bills to Department of Veterans' Affairs health service providers, as a sign of the union's displeasure at the Government's decision to privatise the Department's computer services? What steps has the Government taken to ensure that these illegal work bans, which are affecting our elderly veterans and numerous private sector health service providers, are lifted?

—The answer to the first question is yes, the description involved in the question is broadly an accurate description of the circumstances and I am aware of all those circumstances. The second question asked what we were doing about it. Negotiations are on foot at the moment. I expect them to produce a positive result, which will enable the benefits to be paid and for the matter to be resolved in an orderly way.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. In that these work bans have now been in place for some time, will those Public Service employees who have imposed the bans have their pay reduced and, if not, why not?

—I know that the Opposition has a fascination with finding culprits and punishing them. We have a fascination with promoting good industrial relations. I deplore the work bans. I do not think the work bans are responsible actions by the union in the circumstances. The question is: how is the best result obtained in settling the matter? As I say, I expect to be in a position to say something more about that later on. How then can the situation which this dispute has caused be resolved for longer term better industrial relations in this establishment? I believe our policies and practices will ensure that in fact is the case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission handed down its decision in the national wage case last week? Is it a fact that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has approved the basic thrust of an agreement in the metal industry for productivity related wage increases? Can the Minister advise the terms of the decision and its implication for economic reform?

—The Full Bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission last Wednesday at 10 o'clock brought down a review of wage fixation principles for the national wage case. This was not a decision in which a money claim was before the Bench; it was a decision reviewing the April decision guidelines on industrial relations and wage fixing principles. It is a good decision. It is a decision that has been hailed by the ACTU, by the Confederation of Australian Industry, by the Business Council of Australia, by the Metal Trades Industry Association and by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, among others. Many of the commentators in economic journals, and responsible press commentators, have recognised this as a landmark decision and complimented the Commission for its decision.
—Paddy McGuinness?

—I said `many', not `all'. This decision opens the way for a further managed decentralising of the industrial relations system in Australia. The only people I am aware of with any political standing in this country who have not supported this decision are spokespersons for the Opposition: Mr Howard did not, Dr Hewson did not either. They stand in glorious and splendid isolation from the mainstream in being the only people to repudiate the decision.

PARA.TAB: Since 1987 this Government, working with the Commission and the social partners, has restructured all of the major awards in Australia and through the second tier negotiations has removed many of the restrictive management and workplace practices that apply. We have opened career paths by adding training into the workplace situation so that advancement now can occur because of acquisitions of skill and not just simply because of seniority or more superior placings in the managerial scale. We have, as well, modernised awards. All of those changes were necessary to create the right framework for this decision to be made. This decision now introduces workplace bargaining into the Australian workplace against that restructured background. If we had moved, as some of the Opposition talk about, to workplace bargaining immediately, without going through that restructure, it would not have worked successfully. It now will. I expect, and I think the people of Australia can look forward to, a rash of productivity negotiations now which will give the economy a productivity surge and we will come out of the recession with greater rates of productivity growth than otherwise would have been the case.

The other aspects of the decision have been referred to in the question. I believe the metal trades agreement as it is now negotiated has had the door opened for it to be consummated by virtue of this decision. I see the metal trades employers and unions are negotiating how to do that at the moment and I believe this will be an example of good cooperation in that industry sector.

As well, the decision did in fact neatly fit with my Senate statement of three weeks ago when I talked about a need for more legislative change. The decision referred to the awkwardness of the present provisions, section 115 and section 112 of the Act. I believe what the Commission is referring to relates directly to what I said in my Senate statement. This puts an onus on the Government to look at how quickly it can move to maintain the momentum for this change in an orderly way.

Members of the Opposition are the odd ones out in this. They are talking about a removal of the award system. They are talking about a removal of the Industrial Relations Commission. They are talking about a removal of trade unions. What they ought to do is read the editorial on the Thursday after the decision in which the editors of the Australian Financial Review referred to the Opposition's ideological obsessions getting in the way of the true perception of what is now occurring. We will not become like New Zealand. We will manage our industrial relations affairs in an orderly way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's response to the rejection by Serbia of the European Community's peace plan to resolve the Yugoslav crisis? I quote today's statement by ruling Serbian Socialist Party Vice-President Markovic that Serbia `cannot accept the new version of the Hague documents'. In view of this and other reports today that Serbia will refuse to sign the peace agreement approved by all other Yugoslav republics when the European Community's peace conference convenes today in The Hague, and in view of the expectation that European Community members will then impose sanctions on Serbia, will the Australian Government join in any imposition of sanctions on Serbia?

—I have already said in Question Time today, in answer to an interjection by Senator Harradine, that we are reserving judgment on an appropriate response to events in Yugoslavia until we have seen the outcome of the current deliberations of the EC in The Hague in its meeting commencing this evening Australian time under Lord Carrington's chairmanship .

PARA.TAB: It is anticipated that in the absence of agreement from the various Yugoslav republican parties the Europeans may well move down the path of economic sanctions. The issue of economic sanctions is very complicated in the context of Yugoslavia because they would be directed in the first instance against Serbia, not the other republics, which requires some kind of compensatory strategy to prevail so far as the other republics are concerned. It is not a matter of an across the board embargo on all goods going into Yugoslavia. Under those circumstances Australia would need to consider very carefully our own participation in that kind of exercise, given the compensatory mechanisms that may be involved.

In principle, however, as I have already indicated to Senator Harradine, we would certainly be very willing indeed to participate in that on the basis that it was perceived to be the only way of putting any realistic pressure on the parties. The problem is a very sensitive and delicate one, and I think we have to realise the limitations of our own influence. We have done our best to get the issue not just into the European domain but also into the Security Council. The UN Security Council is also likely to meet quite shortly to consider a report from the Secretary-General following the visit of his special emissary, Mr Cyrus Vance. It is really just a matter of waiting to see what emerges from the processes that are now in train in the way I have described.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer and I ask as a supplementary question: what particular initiatives has Australia taken, other than to support the European initiatives and a call for the Security Council to take up those European initiatives?

—Apart from making our position clear to the various parties, including a number of emissaries and delegates that have visited Australia in recent times—most recently yesterday the Prime Minister of the Republic of Macedonia—I think there is very little we can realistically do. It is a mistake in the conduct of foreign relations to try to put one's oar in all around the world in situations where manifestly one's influence will be limited, and where other parties are equally obviously taking every available course of action that presently suggests itself.

PARA.TAB: That has certainly been true of the Europeans. Every conceivable diplomatic and associated strategy has been explored with total good faith and a great deal of competence by the Europeans. That has run into a series of brick walls, for reasons we are all familiar with. The UN Security Council is now apprised of that situation. Really, under those circumstances, Australia cannot do much more than any other member of the international community in simply keeping pace with events, urging all the parties to exercise restraint, and just hoping to God that they will.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United States Defence Facilities in Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to an article in the Pacific Defence Reporter by Professor Des Ball which states that the United States Government has invited the USSR to visit Nurrungar and has discussed giving early warning data from Nurrungar to the USSR. I ask the Minister whether those statements are correct.

—Professor Ball's article in the Pacific Defence Reporter and press reporting of it are jumping to conclusions in suggesting Soviet access to Nurrungar data, and especially Soviet visits to Nurrungar. United States officials have assured us that no discussions have been held with the USSR about sharing data from Nurrungar or about Soviet visits to Nurrungar, and none are currently contemplated. However, I would like to stress that Nurrungar is a very important facility, not just to ourselves and the United States but also to other friends and allies. Just how important was dramatically highlighted during the recent Gulf war.

PARA.TAB: In recent weeks the US and Australian governments have discussed and agreed that it would now be appropriate to make public the role of the joint facility in Operation Desert Storm. As part of Desert Storm the coalition forces used space based systems to provide weather data, navigational assistance, information on the geographic disposition of forces and other related intelligence.

Nurrungar is, of course, an important part of the defence support program—the DSP—which provides early warning of missile launches, surveillance and the detonation of nuclear weapons. During the Gulf war the DSP detected the launch of Iraqi scud missiles and provided warning to coalition forces and to civilian populations in Israel and Saudi Arabia. The DSP's superb performance during that conflict confirms the flexibility and the continued relevance of a system which was designed primarily to provide early warning of missile attack against the US and its friends and allies.

I trust that the important role played by the joint defence facility, Nurrungar, in the Gulf war will further enhance public appreciation of its significance in efforts to promote measures for maintaining peace and stability, both globally and regionally. If anything, facilities such as Nurrungar are likely to be more important in the post Cold War period. They not only provide intelligence and early warning at a time when the prospect of proliferation is increasing, but also their arms control and verification function will be of greater significance to the cause of world peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. As the Minister would no doubt be aware, many farmers are currently experiencing either no income or even negative income as a result of the disastrous drought and rural downturn. Is the Minister aware of the inability of many rural families to qualify for isolated children's assistance under the assets test guidelines? Is the Minister also aware of the fact that many rural families do have assets worth in excess of the prescribed amounts for the assets test but have no income to cover school fees and expenses? In light of the extreme economic hardships these families are facing, would the Government consider removing the assets test for assistance to isolated children and base the eligibility criteria for this benefit on income alone?

—Let me say at the outset that the one thing we will not be doing—the one thing that can be seen as nothing more than being geared towards making life more difficult for people such as those whom Senator Bjelke-Petersen seems to be concerned about—is introducing a consumption tax which will impact directly on their real disposable income. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen would know, in the recent Budget the Government announced the introduction of hardship provisions which allow the assets tests for Austudy and assistance under the isolated children's scheme to be waived while a student's parents or spouse are receiving a Department of Social Security pension or benefit on hardship grounds, a Department of Veterans' Affairs pension or household assistance under part C of the rural adjustment scheme. This came into effect on 1 October 1991.

PARA.TAB: On 29 October, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen should know—though she might have been preoccupied with other matters at the time—the Government announced a widening of the hardship provisions under the Social Security Act to improve access to Jobsearch and Newstart allowances for farming families.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a bit nasty, Nick. You should apologise.

—Look, if he were honest he would ask for the keys to Boggo Road and walk straight in himself. I am not being nasty about this. Social Security will obtain reports from RAS authorities on families in severe financial hardship who are ineligible for RAS assistance but whose farms are profitable in the long term. These reports will identify those business assets that are essential to the long term profitability of the farm. Such assets will not be counted under the Social Security hardship provisions for otherwise eligible applicants.

PARA.TAB: These extended provisions are expected to operate from 1 January 1992 for a period of two years. Eligibility for the Austudy and AIC hardship provisions will automatically extend to families granted Job Search or Newstart allowances under the new social security provisions. As I mentioned, these are initiatives taken just in the last week.

It should also be mentioned that for those students not eligible for the hardship provision, the assets test threshold for 1991 is $347,500, calculated net of debt and excluding the family home and surrounds. A 50 per cent discount applies to owner operated farms or businesses, effectively raising the threshold to $695,000 for such assets. Applicants are ineligible for assistance only while asset values, less debt, remain above the test threshold and they may be granted a benefit for any period when assets fall below the prescribed limit.

Benefits are usually commenced on the basis of the estimate of asset values provided by the applicant on the Austudy application form. This, of course, avoids causing undue hardship to many students by having to wait for completion of all asset checks, including title searches and the like. Clear advice is provided in the application guide as well as the Austudy guide issued by the Department and the National Union of Students.

I will finish on the point that I made at the start: this Government has been concerned about the plight of families in the rural crisis. We have taken meaningful measures to do something about that. Those measure have been geared towards alleviating the problem.

As I said at the start, these measures are in stark contrast with what has been offered by Senator Bjelke-Petersen's colleagues—her coalition partners. She knows full well, her leader in front of her knows full well and her leader in the other House knows full well that the consumption tax—the GST—will impact enormously on these people. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is going along for the ride; we know that she does not agree with them. But she can see the direct positive effect that our measures will have on the families that she is concerned about, as opposed to the consumption tax which will impact very deleteriously on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sure that all senators have been very interested in the Minister's answer, which was about rural adjustment. My question related to the isolated children's allowance. I wonder whether the Minister had the wrong brief when he was answering me. I wanted to know whether the Government based the eligibility criteria for the isolated children's allowance on income alone.
—I am sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen might have a short term memory. At the start of my answer I mentioned the AIC. She can go through Hansard to see what I said about it.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—At Question Time on 17 October, Senator Campbell asked me a question without notice relating to the availability of capital. Senator Campbell particularly referred to some estimation by the Reserve Bank of Australia in relation to bank non-performing loans. I undertook to obtain an answer from the Treasurer. I seek to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Further to Senator Campbell's question on capital availability, I have been advised that the Reserve Bank, in its 1991 Annual Report, has estimated the non-performing loans of Australian banks to be around $29 billion as at June 1991. However, this does not mean that the banks expect to lose $29 billion, as this amount includes restructured loans, debts the banks deem to be doubtful as well as loans not earning any interest. Given that the total stock of credit outstanding by all financial institutions, as at June 1991, was $339 billion, the availability of capital has not been severely affected by the increase in the banks' non-performing loan portfolio, from $16 billion to $29 billion over the year to June 1991.

The Industry Commission, in a draft report on the availability of capital, released on 25 September 1991, stated that while economic conditions have contributed to perceived problems about the availability of capital, the banks have also had trouble adjusting to the post-deregulation environment. The Industry Commission states that the banks themselves have acknowledged that poor lending decisions in the wake of deregulation, and subsequently in some over-reaction, has contributed to the growth of bad debts over the 1980s.

However, there is no evidence to suggest that a supply-side "credit crunch" is occurring, despite the tightening of lending requirements in the wake of the growth of bad debts. The low lending figures by financial institutions are, to a significant extent, a reflection of weak demand for credit. It is also interesting to note that the September quarter CAI/Westpac survey of manufacturers shows that there has been little change in the availability of finance; only 17% of respondents believe that it is harder to obtain finance than it was in the June quarter and 72% believe there has been no change. The Reserve Bank concludes that "while finance has been less readily available than in the boom years of 1988 and 1989, it is not as difficult to obtain as in the period of credit rationing in 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to make it very clear that the article referred to by Senator O'Chee was grossly distorted. It was a gross distortion of what occurred in the conversation between me and that particular reporter. I indicated to him very clearly during a conversation that, given the culture and the history of China—the dictatorial way in which the emperors and empresses of China were able to have the power of life and death over people, and the way that the warlords over many years had murdered thousands of people in a harsh social environment where people even killed their own children rather than see them die of starvation—going through the revolutionary period—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Burns was granted leave to make a statement. The Senate granted him leave. The Senate should listen to him in silence.

—The revolutionary period was harsh and heartbreaking, with the Kuomintang and the Communist Party fighting each other. During that period there was the massacre of 22 million Chinese by the Japanese, and countries in the West stood by and did nothing.
—I raise a point of order. I suggest that this is a debate, not a personal explanation of how Senator Burns has been misreported.
—It is my understanding that Senator Burns sought leave to make a statement.
—Given all that history and background, I could understand that the Communist Party Government in China—
—You are willing to bag him—

—No. If you want to have a debate, you can have a debate, but he sought leave to make a personal explanation, claiming to have been misrepresented. He is not doing that; he is debating issues relating to the history of China, which is something entirely different. In fact, what he seems to be doing is explaining why the article would have said what it said.

—On the point of order: Senator Burns is telling us what he told the journalist in question and why it was he was misreported. That is the basis on which he is making the explanation in question, and he ought to be heard with a little grace by the Opposition.
—Order! Senator Burns did not claim to have been misrepresented; he asked to make a personal explanation.

—As a result of all that background, I could understand why the Government of China might come to the conclusion that it was a reasonable response to clear Tiananmen Square. Any Australian who would agree with people being killed at Tiananmen Square would be wrong. Any politician in Australia who would agree with that and support it would be wrong and stupid.

PARA.TAB: I remind members of the delegation of a meeting we had with the Chairman of the National People's Congress. The Chairman raised quite sharply with us the action taken in Tiananmen Square to justify the position of the Chinese Government. I made it very clear at that meeting that there was quite a lot of protest from Western countries as a result of that action. I said that those protests were correct and that I agreed with them absolutely but that I also understood that the Chinese Government could have reached the conclusion, based on its background and beliefs, that it took a reasonable action; and that, surely, working through the United Nations, we are gradually coming to a standard of behaviour that everybody should accept internationally and that both China and Australia should work towards achieving.

When I spoke to the reporter, I suggested that he should talk to Michael Baume, as a member of the Opposition who would have his own point of view and a view to express. That was done and it appeared in the article. I repeat that I have no time for, nor will I ever support, the massacre of people in that way by any country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in respect of Senator Burns's explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Baume moving a motion to take note of the personal explanation given by Senator Burns.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak only briefly to the motion, which should be unnecessary. In a personal explanation we would expect to get only the personal explanation. In fact, what Senator Burns gave us was his interpretation of the history of China that might justify the rulers of modern day China in the atrocities that they perpetrated in Tiananmen Square. Somehow or other, from that point a journalist interviewing Senator Burns—in Shanghai as I understand, after or during a dinner—was able to report him in terms that were put before the Senate by Senator O'Chee. In a most serious way, it is suggested that Senator Burns in fact condoned, or at least sought to explain away, the atrocities that occurred in Tiananmen Square. In fact, I cannot think of a more serious matter that could be raised in this chamber. Senator O'Chee correctly said during Question Time that it is a major affront to all Australians, particularly Chinese Australians and Chinese who have fled that sort of regime to seek the protections that we have in this country.

PARA.TAB: If it had been a simple claim by Senator Burns rising in his place to say that he had been misreported, misinterpreted or some such explanation as that, I think the matter should have rested at that point. But to seek to explain it away in the way that he did only fairly calls for an answer from those on this side who were also on the delegation and listened to Senator Burns, in his position as the leader of the delegation, putting a position for Australia to Chinese leaders during the course of the last fortnight. That is why I say that in the circumstances where the Government has refused leave to hear the explanation from this side of the chamber, so much of the Standing Orders should be suspended as would enable at least Senator Baume—Senator Tambling may also wish to contribute—to put his point of view.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on this matter, Mr Deputy President. What Senator Hill said rivals Senator O'Chee's performance in the pomposity stakes when we talk about this issue.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us forget the holier-than-thou attitudes over here. Senator Burns sought leave to make a personal explanation, claiming that he had been misrepresented. In his personal explanation, Senator Burns said, `What I said on this issue was totally taken out of context'. That was his personal explanation. He felt that what he said was totally taken out of context by a journalist and therefore he was entitled to make a personal explanation, which is what he did.
—But he did not do that.

—Senator Walters might not like it; that is not the issue. The issue in this Senate is whether we give leave every time somebody bounces to his feet and wants to make a pompous little statement about something.
—I might like to make a pompous big statement.

—In Senator Baume's case, it probably would be. The point is that the procedures here are quite usual. Day after day people, normally on the Liberal side of the House, seek leave to make personal explanations. We hear their personal explanations, some of which are unsavoury and grossly unsatisfactory to us. Some of them are disgusting. But we do not in that context seek leave to debate them. The Opposition should not either. Senator Burns is entitled to make his statement in the way in which he thinks fit. The way in which he thought fit was to say, `What I said was totally taken out of context'. I thought he did it well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope this debate for suspension of Standing Orders will not proceed for very long. I think we should get it over quite quickly. The Australian Democrats will support the suspension of Standing Orders because, in general, we do not believe members of this chamber should be gagged. Senator Burns in his explanation did name Senator Baume, and as Senator Baume was named it seems to me to be quite appropriate that he also should have an opportunity to give an explanation. It is quite inappropriate for Senator Button to prejudge what the honourable senator will say and describe it as a pompous statement. We will support the suspension, but we request that Senator Baume keep his explanation as short as possible. It is now 3.15 p.m. and I understand that an important event will take place in 15 minutes!

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation given by Senator Burns.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking briefly to the motion, I should say that what Senator Burns outlined to the Senate about his suggesting to the journalist that he speak to me is absolutely correct. The journalist did speak to me initially about his understanding of what Senator Burns had said. I told the journalist that Senator Burns had not stated publicly as forcefully the opinions the journalist said that Senator Burns had expressed to him, but that Senator Burns had said on public occasions that he understood the reasons for the actions in Tiananmen Square and that overseas criticism of those actions was based on a lack of understanding of China's history.

PARA.TAB: We dissociated ourselves from that part of Senator Burns's public comments by saying that our delegation covered a wide range of opinions. Senator Tambling said on one instance—I think it was on the bus one day—that he thought it was a Labor Party speech, not a delegation speech. My attempts to dissociate the coalition members from Senator Burns's comments were restrained and reasonable. Without wanting to open wide divisions between us on the delegation, which I might say was a very harmonious one, I nonetheless stressed that there were different views on this matter and, indeed, on many other matters.

I want to stress that the journalist quoted what I said absolutely and totally accurately. It might be useful for me to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the article in the Courier-Mail by Mr Ed Southorn.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: By Ed Southorn
in Shanghai
The Chinese Government had acted correctly in the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989, the leader of an Australian parliamentary delegation said yesterday.
Queensland left-wing Labor Senator Bryant Burns said Australians should not judge the Chinese `by our standards' and an Australian democratic system would not work in China.
`I believe from the cultural background of Chinese history they (the Chinese Government) were correct to respond in the way they did,' he said.
On June 4, 1989, the Chinese military under government orders opened fire on a mass demonstration at Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
`What occurred was a reasonable response,' Senator Burns said.
`The Chinese people for thousands of years have been governed by authority from above sometimes cruelly, sometimes benevolently,' he said.
He said welcoming foreigners to buy and sell real estate in the Pudong new area of Shanghai would be a detrimental step.
He said the Chinese Government should also maintain ownership of major consumer goods and services enterprises but allow more independence in their operation.
Senator Burns said China had changed visibly since a 1988 visit. `Everything seems tidier, the clothing is more varied and colourful, even the bicycles are more modern,' he said.
Liberal Senator Michael Baume, the deputy delegation leader, said there was no doubt living standards had risen.
He said the government appeared to have decided it was vital to respond to the economic pressures which contributed to the Tiananmen Square massacre.
He said the inevitable collapse of state-run enterprises would necessitate a totally new system.
He said the special economics zones which encouraged foreign investment and were a major reason for improved living standards for many would be the key to China's success as a major world competitor.
`The market society is now rife at the basic level, for stall holders in the cities to rural workers with their own plots.' he said.
The other delegation members are Northern Territory Liberal-National Senator Grant Tambling, Labor Senator Bruce Childs, Mr Graham Campbell and Mr Bruce Cowan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I want to stress that it seemed to me that what Senator Burns allegedly said to the journalist was very much along the lines of what he had said publicly and which we found unacceptable. However, I have to say that he did not publicly say specifically what the journalist says Senator Burns said to him after the cocktail party in Shanghai. Nonetheless, I stress that Senator Burns did say that overseas criticism—which includes Australian Government criticism—of the activities in Tiananmen Square emerged from a lack of understanding by other nations of the situation in China and its history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the delegation to China, I would also like to reiterate some of the comments made by Senator Michael Baume. I note that in the Courier-Mail article, which in a rather forthright way is headed, `Tiananmen Massacre was right—Aust MP'—which certainly is an inflammatory statement for a leading article—the three particular paragraphs that are attributed directly to Senator Burns are, firstly:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe from the cultural background of Chinese history, they (the Chinese Government) were correct to respond in the way they did.
Secondly:
What occurred was a reasonable response.
And thirdly:
The Chinese people for thousands of years have been governed by authority from above, sometimes cruelly, sometimes benevolently.

I find those three quotes to be very similar in context to the comments Senator Burns made in this chamber today. The notes I took as Senator Burns was speaking, where he said, `Given the culture and history of China', `the harsh social environment and heartbreaking circumstances' and `the massacre of 22 million Chinese by Japanese', indicate that he understood how the Communist Government in China may have come to its conclusions to clear Tiananmen Square in the way that it did.

PARA.TAB: I find those statements today by Senator Burns to be very consistent with what the reporter has printed in the Courier Mail; therefore, I must dissociate myself from them. I believe that, in the course of the delegation's tour, I did make it clear that on several occasions Senator Burns, as Chairman of the delegation, just went a little too far in some public comments. I certainly recall his comments in our meeting with the Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in Beijing where a number of us were, to say the least, uncomfortable with his statements.

Before the social function in Shanghai, to which the article refers, we did meet with officials in Beijing, Lanzhou, Xi'an and Shanghai. As I said, there were several unfortunate occasions. There were many other occasions when I, as a delegation member, totally agreed with the Chairman's comments. As Senator Baume has said, for the most part I believe that the delegation was very successful. It covered a lot of ground, particularly in trade related areas. We did not shy away from good, straight and honest discussion, be it on environmentally related issues in the new trade development and economic zones or on several occasions with regard to the human rights issue.

The other occasion on which I dissociated myself with statements by Senator Burns was with regard to the role and relationship between China and the United States. I recall in a meeting stating publicly that in Australia we have various perspectives with regard to political sides. That was one occasion when I did have to draw a different viewpoint.

The article in the Courier-Mail is certainly unhelpful in trying to build a very special relationship that we need to have with China. It is unfortunate if Senator Burns did reflect in this way with the journalist, Ed Southorn. I recall a number of discussions with Mr Southorn at the reception. I found him to be a very straight talker and someone who was keen to learn more about China, especially about the relationship between China and Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this rather grubby little persecution of Senator Burns continues any longer, it is important that something be said on the other side of the equation. There is a certain amount of hypocrisy and pomposity one can put up with without one's gorge rising, but I think that we have just about reached that point.

PARA.TAB: Obviously I was not present when Senator Burns made the remarks in question. From what has been said, I do not understand that anyone else overheard the conversation in question with the journalist. At best, people are reporting other conversations or statements they heard Senator Burns make in similar circumstances. Obviously, since I was not there, I cannot make any judgment about what was said, but I can make these points. The first is that, from everything I know about Senator Burns's character and commitments as a lifelong supporter of the Australian Labor Party and the values for which this Party stands, it is inconceivable that he would have said anything of the kind that was attributed to him in this headline—that is, that the Tiananmen massacre was right—with him making some judgment to that effect. Whatever one might think of Senator Burns or what he stands for, I find it inconceivable that he would have lent his name, judgment and perception and commitment to any proposition of that kind.

The second point I make is that all of us in this chamber should be aware from our own personal experience of how much things depend on the particular context in which something is said and how much accurate reporting depends on conveying everything of what is said, not some selective proportion of it.

In particular, I can vouch from my own personal experience on a number of occasions when what has been a description by me of the reactions of others has been reported as a value judgment of my own. There is no clearer demonstration of that than a great deal of the reporting on the subject of Embassy that accompanied my own visit to Malaysia. As I retailed in a speech at the National Press Club yesterday, and as I said on a number of occasions at the time, what I had said in a speech—and the text is on the public record so it can be checked—was that a series of incidents, the details of which do not now matter, were seen in Malaysia as being `offensive and on occasions downright insulting'. The way that was reported in just about every Australian newspaper was that the series of incidents in question were offensive and on occasions downright insulting. In other words, what in my mouth was an objective description of the reactions of others was reported as a value judgment that I myself was making about the offensiveness of the incidents in question.

I raised this a couple of days later with a couple of journalists. Journalist A, who shall remain nameless, said when I drew this distinction to him, `I am sorry; I don't understand the difference'. Journalist B said, `Well, yes, I accept that there is a difference, but, mate'—and I remember the conversation vividly—`you have to appreciate that the little words do tend to drop out in reporters' accounts of these things, and if not in the reporters' own account, then in the way the piece is finally subbed. And if you don't want the thing to be misreported, well, you shouldn't use colourful words like "offensive" and "insulting" anyway'.

I suspect that what happened—and I make no judgments at all about the integrity, the qualifications or the professionalism of the journalist in question—was that either he misheard what Senator Burns was saying or was trying to say, or in some way the message was lost in transmission. When Senator Burns got to his feet today and described to the Senate in his words what he had been putting to the journalist and to others on similar occasions, he was saying that in his understanding of Chinese culture and history the kind of reaction that occurred in Tiananmen would have been perceived by the Chinese leadership in question as a reasonable reaction. In other words, he was reporting, as he described it today, the reaction of the Chinese leadership; he was not making his own value judgment about the rectitude of that reaction.

That is my understanding of what Senator Burns said. Consonant with the dignity of this place and the benefit of the doubt that we usually give each other when questions of personal probity, rectitude and integrity are at stake, I believe that Senator Burns's explanation should be accepted in those terms, and that this particular episode should now cease.
