TALK.START.PARA: —Since I asked the question that led to this discussion, I would point out that the journalist in question, Mr Ed Southorn, has been in contact with my office. The contents of Mr Southorn's message I shall convey to the Senate because they are very important.

PARA.TAB: The journalist in question, Mr Southorn, said that it was made very clear to Senator Burns that his comments were on the record. The journalist did not just report the comments after the discussion, but in fact was so concerned with the contents of his discussion with Senator Burns that he spoke to the Australian Consul in Shanghai. The matter was also referred to Senator Evans's press secretary. The reporter in question, Mr Southorn—

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again.

—For Senator Evans's benefit, I shall say that again. The journalist did not just report the comments straight after the discussion, but was so concerned with the contents of his discussion with Senator Burns that he raised the matter with the Australian Consul, who referred the issue to Senator Evans's press secretary. The journalist in question says that he reported the truth accurately and correctly because he is very careful not to make mistakes.

PARA.TAB: What we see here is clearly a case where Senator Evans or Senator Evans's office knew about this and Senator Evans was provided with a copy of the article before Question Time today. Clearly, some doubt has been cast on some of the explanation we have received this afternoon in light of the very serious and careful precautions that this journalist has taken to make sure the matter was dealt with properly. Obviously, the matter was at least referred to the Australian Consul, and probably also to Senator Evans's press secretary, and there has been ample opportunity for this Government to set the record straight. I suspect the reason why this Government did not set the record straight is that Senator Evans does not believe some of the things he has just said to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee has just added a further layer to his record by accusing me now of a lack of integrity in what I have said, not believing what I have just said to the Senate. I believe absolutely what I have just said to the Senate. The situation was that there was some communication with my press secretary. I did not know it had come directly from the journalist in question. All I knew was that my press secretary told me that a story of this kind was being written. My response to my press secretary was, `Please get in touch with Senator Burns and get his side of the story; find out his account of what actually happened'. Senator Burns was travelling at the time, I think; it was over the weekend. He was contacted by my office or by someone in the past day or so, after he got back to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns gave his side of the story. I retailed that in Question Time today, when I got the question I was anticipating getting from someone. I am indebted to Senator O'Chee for his courtesy in indicating just before Question Time that he was going to raise the issue, but I anticipated, from its being on the public record, that it might be raised, and I responded as honourable senators heard me in Question Time. I also responded as honourable senators just heard me a moment ago.

There is no question of doing anything other than trying to understand how some report like this might have occurred in a context where a journalist is acting in absolute good faith, with absolute integrity, with absolute professionalism, but maybe just mishearing the way a particular point was being made. It is a very subtle distinction we are talking about, but a very important distinction from the point of view of Senator Burns's integrity. I repeat: I think the Senate ought to give the benefit of the doubt to Senator Burns's integrity on this matter and not pursue this witch-hunt any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least Senator Evans had the decency to look embarrassed about this matter. He is at sad risk of being known as the Minister for cover-ups. First there was Premier Burke and now there is Senator Burns. There are two very important points we need to make here and now. First, as the Consul-General in Shanghai was informed, I imagine that a cable would have been sent back. I ask the Minister whether he will ascertain whether such a cable exists, table it in the Senate and make it available for honourable senators to read.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that I understand that Senator Burns is to leave this country and go on yet another delegation, this time to the South Pacific for five weeks. In the light of what we have heard today, I think we ought to get some undertakings, firstly from the Minister and secondly from Senator Burns, that he will in no way embarrass this country—and I speak for ordinary Australians, not just the Government.

The statement the honourable senator made today, which he sought to make as a personal explanation, simply upheld what the journalist said in the report. I think anyone reading the Hansard will find it very difficult to come to a conclusion similar to the one Senator Evans seems to have come to. No doubt, if Senator Burns was as indignant as he says he was, at the very least he would have his lawyers demand that an apology be printed by the newspaper concerned. Having heard what I have heard in this chamber today, I very much doubt, firstly, that he will have the gall to ask; and, secondly, that the newspaper would in any way, shape or form accede to such a request.

I am angry today. I am angry because we have heard my colleague Senator O'Chee saying that he and his family came to this country to escape that sort of persecution, yet someone with whom I share this chamber has not had the decency to apologise, firstly, to Senator O'Chee and, secondly, to the Australian people, including those of Chinese origin. I consider that it is most important that we ask for that cable to be tabled—the one that no doubt is a report from the Consul-General in Shanghai. If we are told that no such cable exists, I want to know why no such cable exists, because this is the sort of matter that certainly ought to be reported to the Minister.

To accept the attitude we heard from Senator Button that we should try to make light of the incident will not do. To accept the so-called explanation that somebody may have misheard and accidentally misreported will not do either. This chamber and the Australian people are entitled to an apology and an assurance that when Senator Burns goes on this next delegation we will not be embarrassed again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to very briefly give some balance to this debate because we have just heard Senator Bishop in her usual unbalanced way hang, draw and quarter someone on the most flimsy of hearsay evidence. I would just like to say that I was on the delegation. One can say one thing about Senator Burns: `What you see is what you get'. Some people in this chamber have the ability to dissemble; Senator Burns is not like that. What he did on the second day of the delegation was to answer a very sharp criticism by the Chairman of the Chinese Congress in a very proper and dignified way, disagreeing very properly with the Chinese Government's position. Throughout the visit that sort of statement, unofficially and officially, was reported to the people; in other words, he was very consistent in what he said.

PARA.TAB: What we are asked to do by Senator Bishop is to believe a journalist. When we think of the role of a journalist in just the ordinary work that occurs here all the time—and Senator Bishop is a close user of journalists—we would know that occasionally they do not put in, as Senator Evans has said, everything that is said. What Senator Burns said is exactly the way he put the matter on all the occasions I heard him say it. What we have is a journalist who in my view has probably taken part of what Senator Burns said but not put it in the full context of what was said. So the journalist has gone, as Senator Baume has pointed out, and got a story and has taken that story and built on it in what he has written.

I believe Senator Burns because I heard him constantly in China make the same sorts of statements as he made today. I believe it is his view and, because it is his view, it is said with the honest sincerity with which he said it today, just as he said it to the Chairman of the Chinese Congress. He does not know anything else but to tell it straight and to say things as he believes them, from the heart. So, I support what he said in his personal explanation and to do any more is just to create mischief, to try to destroy the positive achievements of this delegation across the board in trying to build better relationships with China as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly as the Deputy-President of the Australia-China Friendship Group of this Parliament. There are 55 members of the group, and four of our members have just spoken in the debate. They were in the delegation that went to China.

PARA.TAB: I want to say—and I believe I speak on behalf of the entire membership of the group—that the reported remarks attributed to Senator Burns would not be supported by any single member of the Australia-China Friendship Group and that the remarks that were made in this chamber in June 1989 still remain representative of the views of both sides of the chamber. We do not see any way to excuse what was totally unacceptable behaviour by the Chinese Government in the Beijing massacre of 4 June 1989. That is the view which not only I hold but which I believe is held also by every member of the Australian Parliament. I rise only to make that quite unequivocal so that there is no possibility of misinterpreting these reported remarks as having any currency whatsoever for the Australia-China Friendship Group in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very brief comment.
—Senator Burns, before you do, it might be worth while to say that Let's Elope was first, Shiva's Revenge second and Magnolia Hall third.

—Anybody who has had a conversation with me about something I have definite views on would know that I speak very quickly. I can assure everybody that I knew that what was said in the discussion between the journalist and me could or would go on the public record. But the journalist could not have conceivably got down every single word of what I said.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Evans said is absolutely true. The difference between the allegations and what actually happened is that, while totally disagreeing with what they did, I understood why they may have come to that decision. As I said, and I repeat: I would invite anybody in this chamber or anybody else to recount any occasion on which I have not said that what occurred at Tiananmen Square was wrong and should never have happened. And I venture to say that the Chinese Government would not have wanted it to happen—there is no doubt about that.

I went on that delegation quite determined to rebuild a friendship between the Government of this country and the Government of China. To continue to carp and to continue to judge China by our standards would not have accomplished that. It is fair enough to make a very sharp criticism, as was done on a number of occasions. But there is a need to recognise that we should aspire to the standard of behaviour that we can all achieve internationally. I believe that I did that.

I repeat: at no stage have I ever supported what occurred. I went through the period in Queensland when the Bjelke-Petersen Government—friends of Senator O'Chee—sooled the police onto demonstrators because they were opposed to the Vietnam war and cleared public places with force. So I knew what it was like.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I take offence at the analogy that Senator Burns is seeking to draw between events in Queensland and Tiananmen Square. He is only worsening a situation that is already embarrassing to the Senate.
—There is no point of order.

—Very clearly, the question of someone coming to the conclusion that after one month the Chinese should clear a public place is not to suggest that they should use the army to do it. So I repeat, and I finish on this note: I have never said publicly or privately that I support what happened. I challenge anybody to say or to reveal that I have said anything of that nature in his or her presence.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senator Bishop—Mr Deputy President, I wish—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, do you have a point of order?

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—I think I will have to take a point of order in order to draw your attention to this point, Mr Deputy President: I am concerned that, when people read this very serious debate in the Hansard, they will see an announcement from you as to the result of a horse race. Yes, it is an important horse race. But is there some way in which we could have that announcement made somewhere else or not recorded or after the debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Take your seat!

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop—I seriously am asking whether that can be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take your seat when I say so! I am certain that Hansard will not put that in. I did it for the benefit of senators who were in the chamber. There is no point of order.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:

PARA.TAB: The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the absolute right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:

PARA.TAB: request the Federal Government to denounce those parts of the Convention which could undermine the parent-child relationship.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Teague (from 78 citizens) and Senator Vanstone (from 91 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:

PARA.TAB: Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is ageing. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:

PARA.TAB: pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)deplores the on-going violence in Yugoslavia, particularly the latest offensives by the Yugoslav army against Dubrovnik, Vukovar, Osijek and Kutina;
(b)supports the European Community's efforts to find peace in Yugoslavia;
(c)endorses the United Nations Secretary-General's support for the European Community's efforts at finding a peaceful solution to this human tragedy;

(d)notes that on 25 October 1991 five of the six republics endorsed the European Community's peace plan based on: sovereign and independent republics, a free association of the republics, comprehensive arrangements for the protection of human rights and special status for certain groups and areas, and recognition of the independence, within the existing borders, of those republics; and
(e)calls upon the Australian Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)endorse the European peace plan and forthwith communicate that support to the Chairman of the Conference in The Hague, and

(ii)urge Serbia, as the one republic currently holding out, to accept the European plan as providing a framework for a peaceful resolution of the Yugoslav conflict in a way which meets the aspirations of the majority of republics and provides justice and security for individuals.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend various Acts relating to law and justice, and for related purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
notes that, on the weekend of 2 and 3 November 1991, the Australian Rugby team won the Rugby World Cup for the first time; and
congratulates the captain, Nick Farr-Jones, and his team on their outstanding performance in becoming Rugby's world champions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

insists that the Federal Government, having granted $10 million over the last two years towards a workable solution for Tasmania's forests and forest industries, of which the Forest Reform Bill is an integral part, now demand that the Tasmanian Government introduce this bill without further delay; and

acknowledges that, unless this bill is passed, investment in such projects as North Broken Hill's pulp mill is strongly questioned and general investment confidence for all industries in the state is diminished.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
notes that unemployment is currently at 10.2 per cent, likely to reach 11 per cent, and there are at least one million Australians either unemployed or underemployed;

condemns the Government for presiding over a 17 per cent increase in the long-term unemployed over the past two months to 219 000, estimated by the Department of Employment, Education and Training to reach 300 000, and possibly 350 000, by the end of 1992-93;
notes that:

TAB.TAB: bankruptcies have increased by 55 per cent in the past financial year, and are now at a record level,
the Government's spending deficit for the first two months of this financial year ($5 billion) exceeds the projected budget deficit ($4.7 billion) for the whole of the 1991-92 financial year, and
Australia's Net Foreign Debt is now $131 billion, which equates to $7 600 for every man, woman and child; and

PARA.TAB: condemns the Hawke Government for engineering, in Treasurer Kerin's own words, `our most severe recession for sixty years'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

notes with dismay the closure of National Textiles spinning mill at Kotara, Newcastle, after its new owners Rocklea were able to obtain a government bounty for the production of yarn at the mill of $15.9 million;
condemns the Government for its incompetence in giving a bounty to a company and not providing proper safeguards for the way in which the recipient uses the bounty;
views with alarm the loss of 327 jobs in an industry that is a major employer of female workers in the depressed manufacturing sector in Newcastle; and

calls on the Federal Government to ensure that, when bounties are given in future, there is legislative protection to ensure that money is put to the most productive use possible through the use of more efficient production techniques and retraining of staff, rather than adding to the unemployment queue and increasing the profit levels of corporate raiders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
agrees with the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) that Australia is in the worst recession for sixty years;
recalls that the former Treasurer (Mr Keating) has indicated that this recession was engineered by the Hawke/Keating Government;

notes that the ALP Leader in New South Wales (Mr Carr) and the ALP Premier in Victoria (Mrs Kirner) continue to attack the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for his Government's failure to manage the economy properly;
notes that the ALP Deputy Premier of Queensland (Mr Burns) believes that Mr Keating is at fault, describing Mr Keating as `a wrecker and a spoiler';

condemns both the Prime Minister and the former Treasurer for being more concerned about fighting over the job of Prime Minister than showing any real concern for the million or so Australians who are without jobs;
believes that the Prime Minister has now confirmed the accuracy of his statement that `if you can't govern yourselves you can't govern Australia'; and
urges the ALP to dump both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating and appoint a leader who is prepared to put Australia's interests before their personal ambitions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
expresses alarm at the Government's lack of comprehension of the long-term effects of the present recession on the country's rural community;

calls on the Government to recognise that its long-term high real interest rate policies have condemned the rural community to a long term depression which, in turn, will delay any chance Australia has of coming out of its present recession;

notes with concern that almost a whole generation of rural Australians is, because of recession and Government policies, being denied its right to access to matriculation level and tertiary education; and

(d)asks the Government to take immediate action to strengthen anti-dumping procedures to aid our primary producers in the economic crisis, during which dumped goods are estimated to make up one third of Australia's total imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
notes that the Government's continual bickering and obsession with its internal leadership problems are having disastrous consequences for our struggling economy;

recognises that the Government's economic mismanagement is particularly evident in the depressed rural sector, where in some parts of Australia the average annual income for woolgrowers is tipped to be as low as $2000 and the market for farm related capital equipment has sunk to the lowest level ever;

acknowledges recent statements by the President of the National Farmers Federation (Mr Graham Blight) that more than 20 000 primary producers are likely to be forced on the dole as a consequence of our economy; and

challenges the state of the Government, for the good of our nation, to place the Hawke/Keating leadership struggle on the backburner and concentrate on providing some economic leadership which will result in a reversal of the present downward spiral.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
condemns:

TAB.TAB: the Government for its insensitive reaction to the plight of the rural industry in the worst recession since the 1930s, as admitted by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) when he was overseas,

the Government for its lack of urgency in providing relief measures in the disastrous drought situation in Queensland, northern New South Wales and parts of Western Australia, any measures announced to date being peripheral to the core question and irrelevant, and
the Government for failing, as yet, to legislate the measures announced in the March 1991 statement that sales tax on farm lubricants and hand tools used in agriculture would be exempted; and

PARA.TAB: calls on the Government to properly address the situation of these hard pressed rural producers and small business people and to cease fiddling at the edges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

notes that it is almost two years since the then Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced in a press release three weeks before the last federal election that the School of Artillery would be moved from Sydney to Townsville;
expresses its concern that no steps have been taken to move the School of Artillery as promised, and that there has been no mention of it by the current Minister (Senator Ray); and
calls on Senator Ray to state publicly when, if ever, this promise will be met.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)congratulates the Tasmanian Green Independents on their brilliant and highly desirable defeat of the Forests Reform Bill; and
(b)notes that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has created public debts of $450 million, and that the passage of this bill would have required further subsidy of this industry by ordinary citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for presentation of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Midford Paramount case and related matters be extended to 30 April 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the notice of motion that I have just given.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March 1991, the Director of Public Prosecutions requested that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts not proceed with its scheduled public hearings for its inquiry into the Midford Paramount case and related matters because he felt that the reporting of the hearing by the media could prejudice the fair trial of another matter before the courts.

PARA.TAB: After considering a number of matters, including the sub judice convention, the Committee decided not to hold public hearings until the matter referred to by the DPP had been resolved. On 13 May 1991, the Senate granted an extension of time to the Committee until 7 November 1991 in the expectation that the inquiry would be concluded by that date. However, the Committee was unable to commence its public hearings until 8 August 1991 and resolved at its meeting on 16 October to ask the Senate to extend the reporting deadline until 30 April 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

condemns the Government for its preoccupation with its own internal leadership problems which have delayed Cabinet and Caucus discussions on matters of vital importance to the people of Australia, especially in the area of unemployment;

notes that unemployment in Tasmania has never been higher than it has been in the last three months, and at 11.4 per cent is the highest in Australia in terms of a percentage of the population looking for work, a figure which represents over 25 000 people; and

calls on the Government to immediately put aside its internal problems and get on with the job for which it was elected, namely to govern the nation and to provide a solution to the economic malaise in which my state and nation now find themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
congratulates the Queensland and Federal Governments for making some move, however small, to advance the development of the Cape York Space Base;

notes with concern that the Australian economy has been devastated to such an extent by the recession the Government said we `had to have' that it is now expected that the company with the mandate, Space Transportation Systems (STS), will have to proceed without any Australian investment; and

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Federal Court of Australia on the report it has presented to the Parliament for tabling. I draw the attention of the Senate to point 2.9 on page 22 of the report which deals with costs of litigation in the Court. Under the heading `Filing fees' the report states:
Filing fees for matters under the Federal Court Act are fixed by the Executive under the Federal Court Regulations.
The report goes on:
There was no increase in fees during the reporting year.

That is last year. The Senate should note, as should the people of Australia, that in this year's Budget this Government, which claims to show some social justice and social equity in the way of taxes, has increased filing fees in all Federal courts by an amount of $500. If one wants to set down a matter in a Federal court, one now has to pay a fee of $500.

PARA.TAB: Before the Government made this announcement one had to pay a fee of nothing. There was no such thing as a setting down fee; this has been introduced by the Government and it is simply taxation by stealth. The announcement was given no publicity; no-one in the legal profession was aware of it at the time. Even now, there is some uncertainty about its implementation. At a time when everyone is very concerned about the costs of justice and about the difficulties that Australia is in—particularly the difficulties that middle Australians have in getting cases before the courts because of the very high cost of justice—this Government has made it even more difficult by imposing a $500 setting down fee that was not there before.

At the bottom of page 22 the report of the Federal Court indicates that it is very concerned about the cost of justice and is undertaking several initiatives aimed at reducing the cost to litigants and streamlining the recovery of costs. These include a number of measures which are listed. I congratulate the Federal Court for taking those initiatives and doing something positive about the things that are making justice so expensive for ordinary Australians. The Court deserves the congratulations of this chamber.

As the Court is doing that and looking at ways of reducing the costs of justice, the Government is imposing that fee of $500. It makes one wonder whether it is worth the Federal Court's while looking at these projects for reducing the costs of justice when this Government keeps increasing them by sneaking in these quite substantial fees that were never there before, which increase the costs of justice to ordinary Australians.

I am concerned that the people who cannot get before the courts and who cannot get justice in Australia are middle Australians. If you are very rich—if you are a multinational company—it is easy to go to court and spend what you like; if you are in the very poor category you can get legal assistance where the Government will pay your legal fees and, of course, the $500 would not matter. It is those in middle Australia, the vast majority of Australians who have grown up under the English institutions of justice, who are now being squeezed out because the cost of justice is getting so high. This Government, rather than trying to do something about that, simply adds to that cost and makes it more difficult for middle Australians to get before the courts by imposing yet another fee, and a substantial fee at that, on anyone wishing to set down a matter in any of the Federal courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Another matter of interest in this annual report is that it reveals the basis on which people have suffered bankruptcy. One-third of business bankruptcies administered by official receivers are directly attributable, according to the tables, to economic conditions as the major cause. Non-business bankruptcies make up two-thirds of the total bankruptcies, with something like 5,400 being the result of either the excessive use of credit—which, of course, was influenced by the huge interest bill—or simply unemployment. Some 2,254 people went bankrupt, the major reason being unemployment.

PARA.TAB: I stress that because we have a situation which I outlined in a notice of motion just a few minutes ago. In the past few months, while this Government has squabbled over one job—the leadership—an extra 68,500 Australians have been added to the list of those with no jobs. In the September statistics, 872,100 people are officially recorded as being unemployed, on the seasonally adjusted figures. All the indications are that those figures will substantially increase in next month's figures and later on this year, with all the experts forecasting that an 11 per cent unemployment rate, rather than the latest rate of 10.2 per cent, is facing us.

In that case, the bankruptcy figures are certain to get worse and worse, with the consequences for Australian families being more and more disastrous. It is not simply a question of speculators going under; ordinary Australians make up two-thirds of the bankruptcies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: With the indulgence of the Senate, if I transgress over the period of five minutes, it is to save the time of the Senate, because I will be debating four documents and could have taken 20 minutes had I had that privilege. During the passage of the Data Matching (Assistance and Tax) Bill late last year, the Parliament stipulated that both the matching and the source agencies table a comprehensive report on the first six months operation of the data matching program.The interim guidelines required these reports to include details of the costs and benefits flowing from the program; relevant non-financial factors; difficulties in the operation of the program; assessment of the program; and statistics relating to the accuracy of the matching process.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that, from the information I have received and examined to date, it seems that this program has been operating relatively smoothly, with a minimal amount of intrusion into the privacy of individual Australians. A large proportion of the plaudits must go to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which examined the legislation in depth and in detail, and to the Senate itself, which passed amendments that significantly tightened the operational requirements of both the matching and source agencies. As the Privacy Commissioner stated in his interim report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Act and the Guidelines impose on the data matching activity an unusual level of discipline and public accountability. In my view these requirements are justified by the degree of intrusion into individual privacy inherent in the program.

The efforts of the Privacy Commissioner and his staff who have overseen the operation of the program should not be underestimated. A prime example of their effectiveness occurred earlier in the year when the Matching Agency attempted to introduce DSS overpayment files to the data matching cycle to identify people in receipt of a benefit from one agency with a debt outstanding in another agency. The Privacy Commissioner recognised that the Act as currently drafted does not permit use of overpayment files in the data matching cycle and the Matching Agency was made to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Despite this example, the efforts of the designated staff in the Data Matching Agency should not be underestimated. From my examination of the Privacy Commissioner's interim report, it is obvious that significant efforts have been made to separate the data matching program from the Department of Social Security's normal operations. In light of the Opposition's qualms about the security of the computer systems to be used in this matching, I am gratified that substantive measures have been undertaken to ensure the security of the information produced by this program.

While the available evidence may give honourable senators reason to be generally satisfied with the first six months of the operation of this Act, I believe a number of matters should be brought to the attention of the Senate. Firstly, it should be realised that the data matching program is still in its infancy. To my knowledge, a comprehensive data matching run has not yet been undertaken, hence the fact that two of the agencies, namely the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, have no results to report to the Senate.

The first cycle did not entail income matching, while the income matching which was attempted during the second cycle had to be aborted due to technical problems. The lack of a comprehensive matching cycle means that Parliament is not yet in a position where it can properly assess the financial implications of this program, a matter of conjecture during the implementation of the legislation last year. Thankfully, the Privacy Commissioner will give us that opportunity in 12 months time before the sunset clause takes effect.

Secondly, it is important that all senators are aware that the data matching guidelines governing the operation of this program were tabled in the Senate on 8 October as a disallowable instrument. While they do not differ greatly from the interim guidelines, there is one important change to them. New guideline 7.4 allows source agencies to create permanent registers for the purpose of excluding individuals from being selected for investigation. Last year the Parliament was adamant that it would not allow the creation of a new separate permanent register or data bank of information relating to individuals whose information had been subject to the program. A significant portion of the Senate Committee's time was taken up discussing this concern. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) was adamant that no new register would be created. Hence the existence of interim guideline 7.1.

I understand the operational problems entailed in preventing an individual from needlessly being investigated time and time again. However, it concerns me that guideline 7.4, as it currently stands, allows for the register to be maintained by source agencies. I am yet to be convinced why it is not preferable for both operational and privacy reasons to have the matching agency receive updated lists of irrelevant re-selections from source agencies.

Finally, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Social Security intends collecting many of the remaining required tax file numbers by way of a direct transfer between it and the Australian Taxation Office. Only last week a document leaked by the Taxation Office to the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Howard, highlighted the continuing problems relating both to the fraudulent receipt of tax file numbers and the sloppy administration in the issuing of these numbers. I have provided the Privacy Commissioner with a copy of this document. He has continued to express concern about the integrity of the TFN. Despite the fact that such interdepartmental transfers appear to have legislative strength, the Senate should be very wary that appropriate safeguards are in place to overcome the problems that will result from the low integrity of the tax file number.

In conclusion, I wish to say that I would like to have the opportunity to witness a data matching cycle first hand. On the whole, I commend the officials who have been involved in the first six months operation of this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the data matching program report for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Honourable senators will note that in that report it is stated that the data matching program is to identify those persons receiving payments to which they are not entitled. The problem is that at present veterans who are entitled to payments are not receiving them. That is very largely due to current industrial problems in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. So, quite apart from trying to identify people who should not be receiving payments from the Department, we now have a situation where people who should be receiving payments are not getting them because of industrial action illegally being taken by the Public Sector Union in the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The Department's national computer centre is immobilised due to those work bans and this situation has been proceeding now for something like 13 days. At the moment all non-pension benefits and payments to health service providers have been stopped, and it means that there is a very real threat that the health agencies that are currently providing podiatry services, domiciliary nursing services and doctors may in fact end up withdrawing services to veterans. I remind honourable senators that we already have enormous unemployment problems in this country. Some of these domiciliary nurses in fact may be supporting families as sole parents. They may be the sole income earner in a two-parent family. It is disgraceful that people who have been providing services to the Department are not getting paid and people who are entitled to allowances because of their war service are not receiving payment, all because this computer centre is not doing the work it was set up to do.

Today in the Senate in answer to my question Senator Cook said he deplored these work bans and that the action of the PSU was not appropriate in the circumstances. But he was not prepared, as the Minister responsible for industrial relations for this Government, to tackle those Government employees who are not prepared to do the work for which they are being paid. It is ironic that, in a submission arguing for the retention of the national computer centre in the public sector, that union stated that one of the penalties of commercialisation would be `the loss of a loyal and dedicated staff who understand what the Department and its clients need'. What a sick quote that is in light of the fact that union members are preventing those clients from getting the services that they need. What has happened to the loyal and dedicated staff? Is it an ideological issue, whereby the union takes priority over the needs of the people who fought for our country?

I think the actions of the PSU show a total lack of understanding of the needs of the veteran community, and I am astonished that a department with a history of caring for veterans has allowed the situation to develop to this stage. I am particularly concerned that we have the Minister responsible for industrial relations in this country prepared to sit back and let this thing continue when it has already gone on far too long. The union may have an argument with the Government over the privatisation of these computer facilities. That is not something which should be used to jeopardise the financial entitlements of people who fought for our country, nor for the people who provide services to those veterans. That is what has been allowed to continue for far too long.

While we may be interested in what is happening to the data matching program in the Department of Veterans' Affairs and in knowing whether it is going to be able to identify people who are receiving payments to which they are not entitled, we are much more seriously concerned at this stage about those people who are entitled to payments who are not receiving them while the Government sits idly by. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—For the information of honourable senators, I table a copy of a letter received by the President from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister outlining recent initiatives taken to improve the timeliness of responses to parliamentary committee reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 10 of 1991-92—Project Audits—Departments of Social Security and Employment, Education and Training—Administration of the Work Test for Unemployment Benefit; and Department of Social Security—Computer System for Unemployment and Sickness Benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the report of the Auditor-General entitled Audit Report No. 10 1991-92 Project Audits Departments of Social Security and Employment, Education and Training—Administration of the Work Test for Unemployment Benefit Department of Social Security—Computer system for Unemployment and Sickness Benefit. It relates to a very important part of government activity at the moment. It relates to the very high number of people who are on unemployment benefit as a result of the recession that the Government said we had to have, and which the previous Treasurer was proud to say that he engineered.

PARA.TAB: This audit report shows that the concerns which the Opposition has been expressing for quite some time about the unemployment benefit and the administration of the unemployment benefit are clearly soundly based. This report by the Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: An audit of the initiatives taken between 1988 and 1991 to improve the effectiveness of work/activity testing, and of the liaison between the two Departments—
that is, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training—
showed that:

PARA.TAB: measures introduced in 1989 and 1990 had not all been successful in meeting the objectives and budgetary savings set for them
staff in the CES network continue to hold the view that work/activity testing is not compatible with the primary job placement role of the CES, and

the initiatives adopted by the DSS in 1990 to interview in greater numbers shorter and medium duration beneficiaries, and to make better use of related information and services from the CES network, although soundly designed, were not well implemented. This implies that related increases in staffing were not used effectively for the purpose provided.

SPEECH.PARA: It is hard to imagine a more damning report on such a vital issue than this Auditor-General's report. The measures have failed in what must be the most rapidly expanding area of government activity, that is, trying to look after the record numbers of unemployed people who are requiring assistance of one kind or another. The report goes on:
On 1 July 1991, the enhanced Newstart and Job Search Allowances commenced. They, too, call for continuing close liaison between DSS and DEET, but have eliminated some of the previous problems.

As a result of that, the Auditor-General has made a series of recommendations about how this liaison—which has been so unsuccessful in the other areas I have referred to—could, in fact, be done better in the future. The report continues:
The ANAO intends, within the next one or two years, to review the progress achieved in the areas covered by these recommendations.
The facts are that millions of dollars are involved in this. For example, the report reveals:
The introduction from 1 July 1989 of the revised procedures—
that is, for the work test—

was expected not only to double the number of Work Test breaches notified by CES to DSS to about 25 000 a year, but also to increase from 27% to as much as 100% the proportion of breaches resulting in UB cancellations by DSS, thereby leading to annual savings of $15m.
The Auditor-General reports:
The number of Work Test Reports raised by CES in 1989-90 did not increase significantly, if at all, compared with 1988-89.
According to DEET records, only 44 per cent of those reports—instead of 100 per cent—resulted in the cancellation of unemployment benefits. The Auditor-General says:
As a consequence, the forecast savings of $15m do not appear to have been achieved.
This is the continuing story throughout this report.

PARA.TAB: On the question of improved liaison between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service, it says that proposals were agreed to by the Government in April 1989. They were expected to double the number of work test reports issued by CES each year and, as I have said, to increase to as much as 100 per cent the proportion of work test breaches resulting in cancellations of unemployment benefit. However, the ANAO found that the number of work test reports raised by the CES did not increase significantly, if at all, and unemployment benefit cancellations arising from these reports were substantially fewer than estimated. Hence, the forecast savings could not have been achieved.
In other areas, with regard to the work test of persons who, post 13 November 1989, reduced employment prospects by moving, the audit conclusions were:

SPEECH.PARA: The two initiatives referred to in this section

were directed to target groups with particular characteristics associated with movement between geographical locations. Substantial difficulties were encountered at operational levels in the CES in applying the approved criteria in individual cases. The second of the two initiatives, relating to itinerants, was not proceeded with as planned, although a pilot study is said to be underway.
Here we have another clear failure in the Government's attempts to resolve problems arising from claims by people who are highly mobile seeking unemployment benefits.

PARA.TAB: Another element of the report dealing with initiatives implemented by the Department of Social Security during 1990 said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the audits in both States—
that is, both the States involved in this particular audit—
disclosed that significant departures from procedures had occurred at regional offices. In particular:
.wide variations existed between regional offices in the percentage of beneficiaries selected for intensive interview
A range of other departures from procedures existed.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow Minister for social security is in the chamber, I think it would be appropriate if I deferred to him as he may have a more intensive view of this report than I have. I would like to complete what I am saying by noting the Auditor-General's conclusions on the 1990 initiatives to try to improve things. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO concluded that shortcomings in the implementation of these policy initiatives at regional offices resulted in a standard of outcome less than could have been achieved if the Integrated Review Model procedures had been implemented more enthusiastically.
That is the continuing story, I suggest, of the failure of these two organisations to get together. The Audit Office concluded:
a number of issues, as set out in the recommendations—
which followed—
are fundamental to the successful administration of the Newstart and Job Search Allowances. . . .The ANAO suggests that these recommendations be given the closest possible attention.

I think every senator should ask the Government to ensure that these recommendations to correct serious problems, as outlined by the Auditor-General, be accepted, particularly the general conclusion which states:
a principle weakness in the implementation of the Work/Activity Test has been the procedure requiring CES staff to make recommendations to DSS which (adversely) affect a client's entitlement to UB.
The report goes on:

As departmental records show, the policy and procedural changes that were instituted in 1989 did not achieve the expectations for increased numbers of Work/Activity Test Reports, and prima facie did not increase significantly the number of resultant cancellations of UB.

I admit that the Government has set itself a huge task by creating such a high level of unemployment. There is no doubt that the Auditor-General finds its method of resolving these problems to be unsatisfactory to an unacceptable degree. I certainly urge the Government to accept the recommendations of the Auditor-General in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Audit Report No. 10 1991-92 confirms what anyone who has made even a cursory examination of the degree of cooperation and liaison between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service would already know to be true. The Auditor-General's findings on the administration of the work test for the unemployment benefit are best summed up by the opening paragraph of the Australian National Audit Office's accompanying media release, from which I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO today called on the Departments of Social Security and Employment, Education Training to improve their liaison and cooperation in administering programs for the unemployed.

As the official number of unemployed moves closer and closer to 900,000, this report could hardly be more timely. This is particularly true when it is also remembered that the number of long term unemployed in Australia is now over 200,000 and climbing rapidly—so rapidly that the Department of Employment, Education and Training now estimates that by the end of next financial year there may be up to 350,000 Australians who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer.

PARA.TAB: This important report is helping the Government to make an assessment of whether these two departments have the necessary skills, expertise, training and coordination to cope with the massive number of unemployed people in Australia. When one considers that the current record number of unemployed is occurring at the same time as the two departments are implementing the recently enacted Newstart legislation, one can understand that the timeliness of this report is more evident.
I am certainly not surprised that the Auditor-General has urged that ongoing attention be given to:

SPEECH.PARA: providing training for staff involved in Newstart, particularly in conducting the intensive interviews and the preparation of activity agreements.

Less than five months ago when the Newstart legislation was debated in the Senate, coalition senators expressed grave concern about the ability of the DSS and CES to implement these changes in an efficient manner. On 4 June, in my speech during the second reading debate, I stated:

When the full effect of those who have lost their jobs during this recession is felt, it is not unthinkable that the number of long term unemployed could reach 300,000 in the first half of 1992. This is the scenario facing a Commonwealth Employment Service which will be required to negotiate, update and check compliance with Newstart agreements that have been made with each and every person who has been unemployed for longer than 12 months. This will place an enormous strain on the staff and skill resources of the CES, but we have been given absolutely no indication of the number of recipients of Newstart agreements, nor has there been any convincing argument to show that the CES has sufficient resources to undertake this task effectively.
Further on in that speech I said:

I have been told that the officers undertaking negotiations will be at the ASO4 level. They must have an intimate knowledge of the process of negotiating these agreements and they must have the relevant people skills: patience; ability to listen; a genuine interest in the client's well-being; and an ability to communicate on the same level as the client.

Rather than saying, `I told you so', it is fairer to recognise that the Auditor-General has not directly criticised the implementation of the Newstart program by the CES but rather has stated that training in the implementation of Newstart be given the closest attention. In other words, he has recognised the very same concerns in relation to the effective implementation of the Newstart legislation as were put forward by the Opposition five months ago. He has recommended that quality assurance processes be developed in relation to the quality of CES interviews, Newstart activity agreements and assessments of compliance with the agreements.

PARA.TAB: I am not surprised that the Auditor has urged that particular attention be given to the liaison between the DSS and CES for Newstart eligibility and continuing entitlement. Five months ago, when the Newstart legislation was causing considerable unrest in some parts of the community, it was revealed that a crosschecking of the records of DSS and CES found that 45,000 CES clients who were supposedly receiving the unemployment benefit were not actually receiving it. A number of reasons, some plausible and some implausible, have been offered to explain this discrepancy. However, the glaring problem that this revelation highlighted was the fact that the CES often fails to monitor whether people who are registered with it have found employment, even when such people have notified the Department of Social Security that they have found work.

There has been much song and dance lately from the would-be Labor leaders, the ACTU and Labor State Premiers that this Government should do something about the appalling unemployment situation. The Opposition remains adamant that the Government must immediately commence implementing the sorts of economic reforms which are required to turn around this massive unemployment problem.

However, the Government should not forget that it is also very important to run its welfare and training programs for the unemployed in the most efficient way possible. This audit report is a reminder that there is still ample room for improvement both in the CES as well as in Senator Richardson's supposedly, in his own words, `trim, taut and terrific Department'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Auditor-General to which my colleagues have just referred is a devastating indictment of the inadequacies of both the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service in so far as the enforcement of the activity test is concerned. If one wanted to look for a better example of the sort of failed approach that people such as Senator Cook constantly endorse, one would find it in this area.

PARA.TAB: Despite all of the attitudinal testing programs and re-education courses that CES employees have been exposed to, this report makes it very clear that there is a high degree of intransigence, verging on insubordination, in the Commonwealth Employment Service. Despite what their political masters might say, the rank and file simply do not see it as their place to be engaged in any form of activity testing. They think they are much more important than that and that their job is one of placement. That is what they are on about, despite the fact that there are very few jobs available these days.

Although ANZ figures suggest that something like 13,000 jobs a week are still available, if one goes into a CES office, as I have done on a number of occasions, one finds that it is like a morgue. There is virtually nothing on the boards and there is nothing to do. Yet we have the spectacle of these employees saying that they ought to be concentrating on job placement. They have time on their hands and they are perfectly placed to conduct activity testing if they were so minded. But the fact is that they are not.
In delightful bureaucratic understatement, the Australian National Audit Office makes it clear that this has reached the point of no return. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO concluded that, notwithstanding the substantial efforts devoted to improving review activities, the degree of success in achieving an appropriate level of performance in regional offices, and achieving a degree of consistency in performance levels between regional offices, has not been as successful as may have been expected.
That is a delightful understatement. It continues:
CES staff have held a strong belief that work testing and the consequences that flow from it are not compatible with the primary job placement role of the CES.
The report goes on:
DEET informed the ANAO that:
The belief of incompatibility between work testing and the job placement role of the CES was acknowledged as prevalent within the CES network, but was not a belief shared by senior management.

In other words, open warfare is being carried on with a government not in the slightest degree interested in resolving it in a proper manner. In most instances, the Government is simply allowing the PSU to ride roughshod over it as that union is now in the process of doing in relation to the Department of Veterans' Affairs dispute over the contracting out of computer facilities. Undoubtedly we will see that happen in this area.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that the CES by its actions has forfeited any claim to ongoing relevance. The fact is that 62 per cent of DSS and CES officers are already collocated. We have had many claims that this process is moving apace and that moves towards full amalgamation are being expedited. The fact is that they are being frustrated constantly by the CES. This simply underlines the need for a fundamental overhaul and a rationalisation of activities. An independent CES in these circumstances is a luxury that we cannot afford.

I would have thought that if ever there were an indictment of the pace of change which this Government is so fond of endorsing, despite the fact that we fall further behind the pace every day, it would be this. There has been an inordinate amount of lead-up time and every opportunity to re-educate the troops, yet here we have a report that has come in months after the activity tests are supposed to be in place and enforced under the Newstart agreements. We have virtually a strike on our hands. That should not be tolerated, yet this Government seems quite relaxed about the fact. It has turned its active employment strategy into a farce. It has been replaced by an act of Public Service resistance strategy in particular areas—not much less than a guerilla campaign in places such as DVA. This makes it clear that the CES has no claim to stay in the game. It is no longer relevant to an active employment strategy if one is serious in pursuing that objective, and this process could be taken over readily by the Department of Social Security.

For the first time in some years, the number of males registered as in receipt of Jobsearch allowance and Newstart allowance is some 15,000 in excess of the current number of males registered with the Australian Bureau of Statistics as unemployed. That situation has not pertained for quite some time. It is not explained by any discernible shift to male part time employment, which might otherwise provide some explanation for the figures. But it suggests that the activity test is simply not being enforced and that what we are seeing is a continuing reluctance, bordering on refusal, to cooperate in a policy which supposedly has been determined by the Government and senior officers of the Service but which the rank and file refuse to implement. I would have thought that that was signing one's own death warrant, but it has not happened to date. Certainly it does not justify any more expense on attitudinal change, staff training and the management effort needed to achieve the necessary degree of attitudinal change. According to the Audit Office, it is sheer self-indulgence, not likely to get anywhere, not necessary and well past the point when it should have been relevant. For all those reasons, the Auditor-General's report makes crystal clear the deficiencies and what should happen with the continuing separation of these two services in future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to put arrangements in place for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1991-92, consistent with the decisions taken at the Premiers' Conference and Loan Council meeting on 31 May 1991. The Bill will replace the State Grants (General Purposes) Act 1990 and its provisions closely follow those of that Act.

The current estimate of general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory under the Bill totals $13,734 million, or about 13 per cent of estimated Commonwealth budget outlays in 1991-92. As such, these payments constitute a major element of the Commonwealth's budget. In combination with the global borrowing limits agreed at the Loan Council meeting, they also have a major bearing on the spending and borrowing of State governments.

In recent years there have been significant real reductions in payments to the States and in the size of their global borrowing limits. These reductions in payments and borrowings have been a key part of the Commonwealth strategy to ensure a continuing process of fiscal consolidation by encouraging restraint in expenditure at all levels of government but, at the same time, targeting that restraint so that the burden is shared equitably and sensibly.

We acknowledge that in recent years the States have borne substantial real adjustments in the level of Commonwealth assistance. Against that background, and in response to requests from the States for greater certainty in funding levels for the purpose of planning their medium term budget strategies, the Commonwealth agreed at the 1990 Premiers' Conference and Loan Council meeting to maintain the level of general revenue assistance in real terms for the three years 1991-92 to 1993-94. This commitment was subject to the qualification that Australia not suffer a major deterioration in its economic circumstances.

At the 1991 conference, the Commonwealth agreed to honour that undertaking, notwithstanding the sharp slowdown in economic activity and the consequent deterioration in its own budgetary position. In return the States undertook to focus their adjustment efforts on restraint in current outlays and to consider increases in taxes and non-routine increases in tax charges only as very much a last resort. This undertaking has been honoured by the States in their 1991-92 budgets, and the Government is confident that excessive increases in State taxes and charges will not threaten to erode the substantial progress we have made in reducing inflationary pressures.

Most of the assistance to be provided under this Bill is in the form of general revenue grants, which are currently estimated to be $13,382 million in 1991-92. By far the larger part of this amount comprises financial assistance grants, but it also includes special revenue assistance to the Northern Territory and a separate new, interim, category of assistance, namely `identified road funding' which gives effect to the October 1990 special Premiers' Conference decision to untie local road funding.

Consistent with the arrangements in previous years, financial assistance grants, special revenue assistance and identified road funding will all be adjusted for the difference between the actual increase in the Consumer Price Index in the year to the March quarter 1992 and the forecast at the time of the Premiers' Conference, so that the real level of assistance agreed at the conference is maintained.

Financial assistance grants are to be distributed on the basis of the Grants Commission's updated per capita relativities based on the five year review period included in the Commission's 1991 report. As in recent years, the relativities are applied to a combined pool of financial assistance grants and the base level of hospital funding grants.

As noted earlier, the Northern Territory is to be provided with special revenue assistance in 1991-92. Similar special assistance has been provided to the Northern Territory in each year since its inclusion in the pool of general revenue assistance for the States. In line with the intention to progressively move the Northern Territory to a financial basis comparable with the States, the base level of this assistance has been reduced from $50 million in 1990-91 to $40 million in 1991-92.

Turning to the identified road funding to be appropriated under this Bill, while the greater part of the funds for local roads that are now untied are paid to local government there remains a small amount of these funds which, under the agreed arrangements for 1991-92, are to be paid to State, rather than local, governments. This Bill will authorise those payments. The overall distribution of these funds between the States reflects the existing distributional principles pertaining to previous tied grant arrangements. The arrangements for payments to local government bodies in 1991-92 were incorporated in amendments to the Local Governments (Financial Assistance) Act passed by Parliament last June. This will make a modest, but nonetheless significant, contribution to enhancing State and local government budgetary flexibility. The final arrangements to apply beyond 1991-92 will be determined with an eye, inter alia, to the implications of other such changes in Commonwealth-State financial relations which might be agreed in the context of the current special Premiers' Conference review processes.
The Bill also provides for the payment of $296.8 million in interest free capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory. This is the same amount as provided in 1990-91.

No provision is made in this Bill for payments of general purpose assistance to the Australian Capital Territory (Act). However, provisions in Appropriation Bill No. 2 allow for analogous payments to be made to the ACT.
Mr President, this Bill is an integral part of the Commonwealth's financial relations with the State Governments and the budget.

During the committee stage of the Bill in the other place, the Government amended the Bill, to complement an amendment within the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. The amendment as part of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill is in response to a request from the Victorian State Government to transfer the State's share of the responsibility for funding the higher education program at the Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture to the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth has primary responsibility for funding higher education. Victoria's funding of a proportion of the college's higher education program therefore represents a departure from funding arrangements which apply to other Commonwealth funded higher education institutions. The Victorian Government is preparing to introduce legislation to enable the college to become part of the University of Melbourne as agreed by the institutions. The college's funding arrangements represent the last remaining issue to be resolved in order that this merger may proceed.

The amendment to the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill reduces the financial assistance grants, in the case of the State of Victoria, by the amount of some $2.5m. The effect of this amendment, in conjunction with the financial adjustment to increase the maximum grants to higher education institutions as part of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, is to providce for the college's higher education program to be funded fully through the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 as from 1 January 1992.
Together, the amendments to the two Bills will mean no net change to total Commonwealth outlays.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
