PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee D which relates to the Department of Administrative Services. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind honourable senators that our debate is a continuation from previous discussions. Some weeks ago we were discussing the business plan of Asset Services. The point that we had covered was the question of the reduction in the work force, which I believe has been answered. A comment is noted in the business plan that one of the ways to minimise cost is to institute better buying practices for materials. I was interested to know what Asset Services means by `better buying practices'. What is wrong with the existing practices and what is the program for improving them?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that one or two aspects of better buying practices, which we are presently looking at, involve discounts for bulk purchasing and the use of credit card direct purchase where appropriate and where considered to be cost effective.
—I presume that the Department was already engaged in bulk purchasing, so what will be different from the existing situation?
—Essentially, it is a matter of negotiating better prices for bulk discount. Senator Parer is right when he says that we are presently engaged in that practice; it is a matter of improving it.

—In relation to subprogram 1.6, I notice in an answer given to me in respect of the Australian Valuation Office that the Northern Territory has the highest average revenue per valuer of $147,700, while in another answer given in respect of the percentage of work done by the AVO for other departments `nil' is shown for the Northern Territory. Is all the work or income being credited from the Northern Territory to South Australia, thus creating what appears to be a loss of $135,000 for the Northern Territory—although it has the highest revenue per valuer? It appears that this is being credited to South Australia, creating a loss for the Northern Territory, thus reducing the South Australian loss.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures in the left hand chart indicate the cost of having the employee based in the Northern Territory—removal, accommodation costs and so on. That figure is not the all-up figure. I am told that the income for the Territory is $1.3m or thereabouts. So the two tables do not necessarily encompass each other. But the costs on the left hand side are at that level because of the increased necessity to rotate people in the Territory.
—Will the Minister explain in a little more detail this matter of rotating people in the Northern Territory? How many valuers are in the Northern Territory?

—There are about eight valuers up there. Valuers are sent to the Territory for different functions and different purposes. On the point that Senator Parer raised about revenue being allocated to the South Australian branch as opposed to the Northern Territory branch, I will seek further clarification from the officers, as we have not addressed that matter as yet. I will provide the information to the honourable senator in the next half hour or so.

—I thank the Minister. The reason I raised this matter is that the revenue value is so high in the Northern Territory and so low in South Australia. I think it is the lowest figure of all the States, yet it does not reflect the loss situation for South Australia. I will be happy if the Minister can do that. I did not really expect that sense of urgency in the Minister's response; I just simply want the matter clarified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that we do rotate some half a dozen personnel in the Northern Territory in the course of a year. That has resulted in the increased cost as indicated on the chart. I am also informed that revenue raised in the Territory is not in any way allocated to the South Australian division, though some costs are offset back to South Australia by, I presume, personnel coming up from South Australia and working in the Territory.

—I now turn to program 2, `Supply services', and subprogram 2.3, `Comcar'. From responses given and the impasse that continues with regard to casuals and award work practices, it is apparent that it is only a matter of time before we see a union—this time the Transport Workers Union—destroy the jobs of its own members. I raise this matter because in reference to Comcar in its draft annual report the Department indicated that agreement had already been reached with the TWU while in debate during the hearing of the Estimates Committee the point was made that in fact this apparent agreement had not eventuated. I would like to know where that agreement now sits in respect of Comcar and casuals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter has gone before the Arbitration Commission. We have the authority to employ 90 casual drivers, 30 of whom will be employed in the ACT. Applications are being processed for those jobs, and some people have started in Canberra already.
—What is the status of the apparent agreement with the Transport Workers Union at the time of the draft annual report which has not eventuated?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There were what we could call fine-tuning problems which we had not anticipated. That is why the matter went to the Arbitration Commission, I think on 18 October, and it was substantially resolved on that day.

—One observation made is that with Comcar there is approximately one supervisor for every three Comcars. I would like to know whether that situation is being addressed in view of the new management of Comcar and what the status is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Parer would know, and as we discussed in the Committee process, the management of Comcar has been the focus of an evaluation by Price Waterhouse Urwick. We have had preliminary discussions with PWU and discussions on a preliminary report of which I think the final version will be coming to me on the 12th of this month. As part of their process, they have managed to determine that there is about 10 or 15 per cent excess capacity in the management side of the organisation. It may in fact go to 20 per cent, but 15 per cent is a reasonable figure to anticipate them coming to us with. So, the area has been one of concern, and we have focused on it by the use of outside management consultants. The final report should arrive soon and it would be my intention to have that report implemented as soon as possible. I would expect, given the sorts of tasks that are involved, a target date of something like February next year or thereabouts should be set by us. However, I believe February is a reasonable time to implement that aspect of change to the structure.

—Could I preface my remarks on Comcar by saying that when I was involved in local government we were required to consider many large budgets and very controversial issues, and most of them used to go through the keeper of the accounts with council. But whenever the question of cars was raised, it always became an issue that everyone knew something about. I noted in the Australian of 16 October that in your party room, Madam Temporary Chairman, it supposedly took 45 minutes of the allotted 90 minutes of Caucus to deal with complaints about the threat to the luxury chauffeured limousine service. It went on to say that members whinged about having to take taxis instead of white LTDs.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about the Comcar situation, like your colleagues, I presume. I believe Comcar provides an excellent service in ways which I do not believe taxis can. The drivers work late at night and in particular provide security which I do not believe hire cars can. Certainly security of the passengers and the quality of the drivers are first rate. They are required in some circumstances to drive at high speeds. The reason I raise this is that I had the luxury of having had an opportunity to test out its new skid pan simulator in Hobart recently. I am pleased to say that I have a certificate to prove that I have passed most of the tests applying to those car drivers, not that I would ever be a threat to them. However, I would like to compliment Comcar on the purchase of the $40,000 skid pan simulator which I believe it will be hiring out to other areas of government for driver training. It goes to show that the Comcar operation does require an extra skill of its drivers and does provide security, as I mentioned earlier. I feel quite sorry for Comcar because many of the losses incurred have been brought about by the sale of assets and in having to lease back cars and premises.

Following on from Senator Parer's question, I ask about the casual drivers. Is it right that Comcar has purchased 15 new Holden Commodores for use by casual drivers? These are questions I was going to ask last session. The position may have changed since then. Are they in storage and being kept there until this particular matter of casual drivers has been resolved?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that a couple of months ago about 15 cars were bought and, as I have already indicated, those drivers are now coming through the system and those cars are being used. The honourable senator, having made those comments, can be sure his car will arrive on time, unlike Senator Ray's. However, I think he raises a pertinent point. When one looks at the cost of providing the service to the Commonwealth, the figures indicate that, from the financial year 1985-86 to now, there has been about a $4m reduction in providing the service. So, things have not been moving, as would appear in the press, in one direction at all times—in a bad direction. There have been some efficiency gains of the order of $4m over that period and that also should be placed on the record.
—Has Comcar purchased any other Commodores around Australia in anticipation of this deal being worked out for casual drivers?

—Yes. I am informed that in New South Wales one or two have been delivered in recent times in anticipation of casual drivers coming through but, as I have said, the casual drivers are coming through now. These cars obviously will be needed for that work.
—If that is the case then, the Minister must be reasonably confident of coming to an agreement with the unions so Comcar can employ these casual drivers at the rates he wants?

—As I have already mentioned, the matter did go before the Arbitration Commission on 18 October. There is an agreement and that agreement is now being implemented. So, we are not confident; it is already in place.

—Senator Parer also mentioned the matter the Minister commented on during Estimates about there being one administrator for every four drivers. When Mr Dawson assumed control of Comcar operations did he bring in additional staff with him? If he did, were existing administration staff redeployed?
—I am advised the answer to both questions is no.

—On page 47 of the Estimates Hansard Mr Dawson referred to the charge-out rate for taxis being very similar to the cost of Comcars. The Minister also confirmed on page 44 that one of the most daunting costs to be absorbed by Comcar is the cost of contracting out. I note that there seems to be an increasing use of taxis for the shuttle service here—or at least last time we were here there was—and, given the statements by both Mr Dawson and the Minister, can he explain why more taxis have been used?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are to take this back to the genesis of the problem, Comcar, as the Committee would know, has been an evolving organisation and one that has been commercialised over recent years. As part of that process it has had to work out new accounting and billing procedures; it has also been involved; and it is evolving with greater access to computerisation.

PARA.TAB: One of the aspects that has been focused upon in the scrutiny that I and others have applied to Comcar is to segment the sorts of work that Comcar does and to work out where the losses and profits accrue. In that process it is fair to say that we have discovered that in contracting out we may have been subsidising other departments by not charging sufficiently for the service we provide. That is a matter that has been focused upon now and could have come to light only with the greater scrutiny of the sorts of products Comcar provides and what we charge for them.

As I also said in the committee process, it would be easy for us to raise our prices to cover those charges. However, it is imperative for us to ensure that prices are increased only when we have taken all steps to ensure that the organisation is as lean and as efficient, particularly on the management side, as it could be. That is why at this stage work is still going on to scrutinise the sorts of products that are provided and where the losses accrue, to ensure that, in the sorts of work we charge for, at the end of the day we do not lose on contracting out and that those sorts of situations do not continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that both the Minister and Mr Dawson said that the charge-out rate for taxis is very similar to the charge-out rate for Comcar, why do we have an ever-increasing use of taxis on the shuttle service, such as occurred in the last two-week sitting period? Was there a particular reason for that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the instance Senator Calvert mentions, the last two-week sitting period was very much a transition period where we were anticipating work for casuals.
—The same thing happened last night.

—Yes. One of the problems with the Comcar service is that it now depends increasingly upon more sporadic work. Over recent years a decision has been made that, where government departments have access to transport, they can use facilities such as Cabcharge or hire cars. It is fair to say that, because of that, much of the bread and butter work, much of the backbone of the work of Comcar, has gone to other areas.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances where we have the sporadic demands of Parliament sitting, without a lot of the work we had in the past, it would be totally inefficient to maintain the sort of organisation we had in the past which would have catered for the peak work load demanded by the House sitting. That is essentially why, given the increase in the burden on Comcar because of the sporadic nature of the work, we have had to move towards casuals.

As Senator Knowles mentioned, it happened again last night. We are increasingly picking up the 30 casual drivers we think we need to cater for a lot of the work that is going on here. Short of maintaining an expanded army of Comcar for the peak period that is demanded when Parliament sits, we have little option. We cannot maintain a high level of work force in this place to satisfy the demands of the Parliament and then have that staff with little to do when Parliament is not sitting, for instance. The mix between permanent, full time, permanent casual and private contract work will evolve to a settled formula over a short period, but we really have no option.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent times there seems to have been an ever-increasing use of hire cars and taxis at night when they know we are leaving Parliament at a certain time. Very few Comcars are being used, and I wonder whether that has been brought about by the insistence on the 10-hour break that has to be given to Comcar drivers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would expect that that is a factor involved and it is a step that has had to be taken. As Senator Calvert would know, in the past if a 10-hour break was not utilised by a driver the wages for the next day were at double time. We have had to ensure that the 10-hour break has been enforced. That may mean that in the transition period there are fewer Comcars available, but the casuals are intended to soak up a lot of that work.

—What does having to pay overtime have to do with it? Is there a conscious decision not to use Comcar drivers at night because they have to be paid overtime and cheaper rates can be obtained by using taxis and hire cars?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a conscious decision to reduce the loss of the organisation as much as possible. Where we have a double wages bill the next day, obviously that increases the costs of running the organisation. When the organisation is running an $11m or so loss, those sorts of costs are very hard to carry, and in fact should not be carried if other ways of doing it can be found. That, I think, is the short answer.
—What rate do you pay for taxis?

—While I am getting that information, I should also place on the record that the occupational health and safety legislation makes some matters imperative in terms of a 10-hour break. That was one reason, if not the main one, that guided our decision to cut out any work that did not involve a 10-hour break. As to the rates charged by taxis, obviously they vary in every State. We can provide details for Senator Calvert.

—I am pleased that the Minister mentioned the health and safety aspect of the 10-hour break; I thought that had slipped him by. Obviously there are also cost reasons for now enforcing the 10-hour break, although I do not disagree at all that it is necessary for the health and safety of the drivers; it should have been done a very long time ago. However, if that is the case, what is now being done to ensure that the cab or private hire car drivers have had a 10-hour break at some stage in the 24 hours before driving?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that an award prevails in the transport industry, although the extent to which that is applied by employers is another matter. We probably have all had the same experience driving home late at night from this place or in other cities. There is an award but we cannot enforce it; it is very much up to the union and the drivers involved. An important aspect is that in many instances we are talking about owner-drivers. In those circumstances, they can complain to no-one but themselves. We cannot enforce it.

PARA.TAB: This also raises a problem that should be placed on the record. It is very easy to compare Comcar prices with, for instance, the private sector and say that we might charge $4 or $5 an hour more or whatever. However, more often than not we find that those with whom we are compared do not apply the award rates and conditions. So there is not a level playing field in a comparison of Comcar's charges with those in the private sector. I should not say that as a broad generalisation because obviously it does not apply to everyone in the private sector, but we are finding that amongst some competitors. We are also finding instances of predatory pricing, where prices are being reduced in order to obtain a component of work, but with either consequent price increases or anticipated consequent price increases further down the track. The end result is that Comcar is being squeezed in the process.

All of these matters are before us, and come before us continually. The manager of Comcar, the Department and I really cannot take a general approach. I would like to stress one point: when we look at Comcar and the rationale for its existence—Senator Knowles made mention of the fact that we are the ones who may suffer when the drivers do not have a 10-hour break—we have to keep in mind that the service is not just here for parliamentarians; it is not just a delivery service of bodies to and from this place. The Commonwealth also has to maintain this capacity for security reasons. For instance, a government has to maintain a transport capacity for special visits such as the forthcoming visit of President Bush. This capacity is needed, whether the visits are made by presidents, royalty or whoever.

Government needs to maintain this organisation for those security and associated reasons. One of our challenges will be to try, in the accounting process that is demanded of Comcar and the Department of Administrative Services, to work out what is needed to enable this organisation to maintain a level of service which is quite necessary in all the circumstances that people have mentioned this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened very carefully to what the Minister has said about the cost of hire cars vis-a-vis Comcars. Would the Minister mind explaining further to the Committee why Comcar fails to make a profit when it enjoys a tax exempt status presumably for its vehicles, parts, fuel, licences and so forth? Would the Minister mind clarifying for me exactly what the tax exempt status for Comcar relates to? If Comcar enjoys an enormous tax exempt status, how can the hire car operators continue to charge us less per hour and yet still, presumably because they are in business, make a profit? As a business person, I cannot quite fathom that situation. I would be delighted if my business were given a tax exempt status. Hire cars operators can pay all their taxes and still run at a profit and remain in business; Comcar cannot.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could tell Senator Knowles in the space of two or three minutes why Comcar does not make a profit, it would make my life much easier. I go back to the point I made that over the past five years there has been a $4m reduction in current dollar values in the cost of running the organisation in terms of its loss. There has been an improvement overall and this should be placed on the record.

PARA.TAB: During the past 20 minutes or so I have gone through some of the reasons why Comcar should not be judged against its competitors. All sorts of levels of service and capacity have to be maintained by the organisation. For instance, if we kept on staff only the number of drivers that we need for the level of work that is always on hand, Comcar could run at a profit. However, if we did that, we would have nowhere near the number of drivers that are required whenever Parliament sits. It would mean that there would be nowhere near the capacity that might be required for special visits.

The sporadic nature of the work, the fact that we do not have owner-drivers and the fact that we do play the game by the rules to ensure that customers' security is protected makes Comcar a little different and imposes costs on it. The fact that Comcar has to go through a process such as this, where it is accountable not only to the Parliament but also to a Minister and is subject to a degree of scrutiny, also imposes costs on the organisation.

It is worth while going back to the point that I made earlier. Hire care drivers get paid a percentage of the take. We should keep in mind that hire car prices vary around Australia. In some instances a profit is not made. I am told that there have been a number of recent bankruptcies in the industry in New South Wales. It is not an easy industry to assess. More importantly, as I said before, there is no level playing field. On the one hand one might say that Comcar does not pay tax on fuel or other items but on the other hand there are other costs. Comcar has a problem in that it has a sporadic level of work for which it has to make some allowances in its overall cost structure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so long ago someone—I think it was Mr Dawson—sent a letter to the drivers saying that they had to be more innovative and creative and so forth to increase business. I am at a loss to know how drivers who are given a job and sent from point A to point B and from point B to point C are expected to do that. How is Comcar expecting the drivers to become more productive on a daily basis? Are they meant to go down St George's Terrace, pick up a drunk standing on the corner and charge him $75 an hour?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is probably one of the most futile suggestions that I have heard in terms of picking up work. Productivity depends on a number of things. For instance, last week in Adelaide a driver told me that he had alerted his customers to a number of services and booking procedures that could be used. I have not had a chance to talk to management to see what has been done in this regard. Senator Knowles's question and my answer has probably put management on notice to follow up such suggestions.

PARA.TAB: I think it is fair to say that there needs to be a focus on marketing. There needs to be a focus on ensuring that a lot of people who should be customers of Comcar are aware of the services provided and the rates charged. In some instances, I do not think they are. The question of marketing has been focused on by PWU. I anticipate that it will be dealt with in that organisation's report to me. This is something that management as well will also have to look at.

Marketing does not stop at the personal level; the whole organisation has a role. However, I think drivers can be helpful and more productive if they have direct contact with customers. I think that covers the thrust of the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My background is in marketing

SPEECH.PARA: but, like many of us, I am also a consumer. I have to say that the marketing of Comcar leaves much to be desired on a purely monetary basis. For example, when I go to the bush in Western Australia I have the choice of taking a Comcar or a hire car. If the hire car costs the taxpayer considerably less than a Comcar, I will take the hire car every time. The reality is that Comcar is pricing itself out of the market.

PARA.TAB: I do not care how much marketing Comcar does. If at the end of the day Comcar costs more for the same job, people will try to make their dollar go further and take the less expensive service. Maybe that is what is happening here. I might just ask another question: what is the ratio of supervisors cum managers to drivers in Canberra and on a State by State basis?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to show that there is a bit of innovation around the place, I am advised that we will quote Senator Knowles special rates for country trips. I expect that she will be alerted very soon to whatever those rates are. In fact, we can tender on a trip by trip basis. That flexibility is there and is being made available. Probably what Senator Knowles has instanced this afternoon is that we should broadly alert members to the availability of that sort of facility. We will provide Senator Knowles with information with respect to management vis-a-vis drivers. It is one of the factors the PWU has been asked to consider. That information should be available.

—I have a question with respect to Comcar that was not answered in the Estimates. I raised the question of third party provision with respect to Comcar in the context of a veteran passenger who was injured in a collision between a Comcar and another vehicle. The question was raised as to whether Comcar was in fact covered by third party insurance. I have not had an answer to that question at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that an answer has been provided—I do not know whether it is sufficient. The Department of Administrative Services has advised that prior to August 1991 the Commonwealth carried its own insurance risk in respect of third party personal injury arising from an accident involving a Comcar. The policy was in accordance with the provisions of Department of Finance direction 21 and the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959. Comcar has leased its vehicles from Fleet since July 1990 and, therefore, does not own them. Third party person insurance has been arranged for Comcar in all States and Territories with effect from the beginning of August 1991, with the exception of Western Australia. Negotiations are currently being held to extend third party personal insurance cover to Comcar vehicles in Western Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the answer.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer read as follows—
SENATE ESTIMATES COMMITTEE—D
Senate Hansard Page No. D49
Sub-program Name:COMCAR
Sub-program No.:2.3
Subject:COMCAR
Senator PARER asked:
With reference to the subject of passengers of COMCAR on a State by State and Territory by Territory basis annually since 1985:
(1) What provision is made for protection of third parties in Commonwealth cars in case of injury or accident.
(2) For how long has this policy stood.
(3) How many instances of injury or accident have been recorded by the department.

(4) Of these, in each of the following categories: (a) Governor-General; (b) Prime Minister; (c) Minister; (d) parliamentary office holders; (e) the judiciary; (f) Senators; (g) MHRs and their staff; (h) statutory office holders; (i) visiting dignitaries; (j) Commonwealth departments and administrative bodies; and (k) repatriation beneficiaries, how many passengers have claimed compensation and how many have been compensated.
(5) Of these, how many have been compensated to the level of their claim.
(6) For each claim, what has been the time lag between lodgement of the claim and eventual receipt of compensation.
(7) How many claims have been denied by COMCAR and on what grounds.
(8) What compensation has been made for property damage by COMCAR.
Answer:
The Department of Administrative Services has advised that:

Prior to August 1991, the Commonwealth carried its own insurance risk in respect of third party personal injury arising from an accident involving a COMCAR. This policy was in accordance with the provisions of the Department of Finance Direction 21 and the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959. Since July 1990, COMCAR has leased its vehicles from FLEET and therefore does not own them itself.

Third party person insurance has been arranged for COMCAR in all States and Territories (with effect from the beginning of August 1991) with the exception of Western Australia. Negotiations are currently being held to extend third party person insurance cover to COMCAR vehicles in Western Australia.
Any Commonwealth employee suffering personal injury while travelling in a COMCAR in the course of their work or duty would be covered by workers' compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very well aware that in Hobart Comcar is making a commendable effort to obtain outside work. I know it has approached some of the airlines to see whether it can transport their flight attendants from the airport to the city—which makes sense to me. Comcars usually take people such as myself out to the airport and go back to the city empty. It would be good if Comcar could arrange something like that. Are Comcar operators in other States making similar efforts to obtain outside work to defray their costs?
—The short answer is yes.

—I have received advice—I am not too sure how accurate it is—that a letter was recently circulated by management to Comcar drivers which was critical of the way the drivers were treating members and senators. I think the letter said that they were treating politicians too much like royalty. Does such a letter exist?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does. I am not too sure of the precise words. The word `royalty' was mentioned. I think it is fair to say that no-one in this place expects to be treated like royalty, but the letter could probably have been better worded.
—Who sent the letter? Where did it come from?
—It was from Mike Nelson and it was delivered to State managers.
—Could the Minister make a copy of that letter available to me?
—I am surprised that Senator Calvert does not have it already. I will try to get a copy for him.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—There being no further questions on program 2, we move to program 3, Government Services; subprogram 3.6, systems and technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to systems and technology, I refer to one aspect that may not technically be legitimate in that it refers to page 2 of the report. One of the questions that is continually raised—I will leave it to the Minister to decide whether he wishes to answer it or stick to the rules—in systems and technology is that of unlimited liability in respect of common use contracts. When I raised the question in Estimates, the point was made to me that unlimited liability was in fact a requirement of people who dealt with the US Government.

PARA.TAB: I am raising the matter here because it appears that the answer is not correct. Information I have subsequently received states that the experience of the major suppliers of information technology equipment to agencies of the US Federal Government has been one where both parties have excluded contractor liability for consequential damages in common use contracts. The information further states that there is a general rule and some specific agency contracts ask for some sort of specific damages warranty. There is a similar situation with the Government of Canada, where specific contract requirements occur for the inclusion of unlimited liability provisions, but not as a general rule.

I seek clarification of that. On the information we received in Estimates we would gain the impression, perhaps falsely, that unlimited liability was a standard procedure in respect of people dealing with agencies in both the US and Canada.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question Senator Parer raises is one that has been bashed around for some time. The consistent advice the Australian Government Solicitor has been giving us is that a fair and just standard for liability in IT contracts is to let the common law principles apply to both contracting parties. We have moved slightly from this principle in a few recent contracts by placing a cap on liability for some elements of the risk, although common law principles still apply to the major elements of risk.

PARA.TAB: As AGS advises, the underlying principle is that the best way to protect the Commonwealth's interests is to let the courts decide what is reasonable damage. As has been indicated a number of times, the Department has sought advice on this issue from a number of major insurance brokers. I am informed that it appears that insurance is generally available, and reasonably priced as well. There has been some question about the availability of insurance cover.
With respect to the US, on pages 71 and 72 of the Estimates Committee hearing Senator Calvert referred to the US Federal Government. I will quote the sequence of questions and answers on page 72:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Taylor—Some States in America do apply similar conditions—
meaning similar to the ones we apply here—
Senator PARER—I am referring to the Federal US Government.
Mr Taylor—Most of the contracts are done on a State by State basis and there are varying provisions for liability.
Senator PARER—I understood in the United States that, specifically, the consequential damages are excluded and liabilities are limited to the value of the contract? Is that not the case?
Mr Shevchenko—No, that is not universally applied in all the States of the United States. In fact, in some of the States in the United States, companies are not allowed to limit the liability.
We went on to discuss the UK. I do not think there was an intention to mislead. From the record, there was no misleading.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—We now move to subprogram 3.7.

TALK.START.PARA: —After some questions from me and Senator Parer on the matter of overtime for Senator Powell's staff, the Minister said that the Department would revisit the matter and pursue it that way. I ask the Minister whether he has revisited that matter and whether he has any further answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that officers have in fact revisited the matter. They have analysed the claims for overtime and have found that those had all been authorised in accordance with procedures.

—I raise the question of the existence in subprogram 3.7 of the National Media Liaison Service. As honourable senators would be aware, one of the key purposes of Estimates committees is to enable senators to scrutinise expenditures and the operations of a department within a portfolio. I make the comment—because it has been referred to in the report to the Senate of Estimates Committee D—that we have this most unusual situation where the National Media Liaison Service is funded within the Department of Administrative Services but is not responsible to the Minister for Administrative Services.

PARA.TAB: This is basically an untenable position because it means that, even though we are aware of the funding through the Department of Administrative Services, we have no capacity to question the Minister in respect of the operation of the National Media Liaison Service. Similarly, even though the National Media Liaison Service is responsible to Minister Kelly, people on other Estimates committees—because there are no appropriations in it—do not have the capacity to question the Minister in respect of the operation of the National Media Liaison Service. It is obviously a most unsatisfactory position. I ask the Minister whether the responsibility for the National Media Liaison Service will revert to him or whether the funding of the National Media Liaison Service will go to DASETT.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that the process that has been adopted here is one that has been in place for all political parties. Laurie Oakes wrote an article in the Bulletin of 15 August 1989 entitled `People in Glass Houses'. He talks about the preceding organisation to NMLS, which was the Government Information Unit. That organisation was also structured and paid for in the same way. Basically, it has been done this way because the staff of the NMLS are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act and, as a consequence, the Department of Administrative Services pays for them. As I say, it is not something that we have put in place to make anything more difficult; it is a process that has been applied and does apply for staff of members of Parliament, be they backbenchers or Ministers.

—I would like to go on further in respect of the payment to the staff of the Leader of the Australian Democrats, which comes under subprogram 3.7. I put in a reservation about this matter. We hear a lot about honesty, the opposite of which is corruption. We have heard a lot from the Democrats in the past about `keeping the bastards honest'. In more recent times, the Leader of the Democrats has referred to the other parties as being beyond redemption. Of course, he is correct in reference to this worn out Labor Government that, through its Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it has forfeited any claims to honesty and integrity. But honesty and integrity are fine words. The test, however, is what happens in practice. The worst form of corruption is when the public purse is being pilfered for purposes which are not related to the Parliament and/or the electoral responsibilities of members of parliament. That is the reason for the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland, which attracted so much attention.

PARA.TAB: In Estimates committee hearings, the matter of Mr Bill Scetrine, who was on the staff of the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, was raised. Over a nine-month period, he received an amount of $59,212.77 in overtime; $2,965.50 in meal allowance; $17,723.40 in travel allowance; and a Comcar charge of $8,834.91. That makes a total of $88,736.58 just in extras. If one adds to that the approximate salary for nine months, it reaches a total of $112,736.58. There have been all sorts of stories around the corridors of this place about the final resting place of some or all of that money. As they are unsubstantiated rumours, it would be improper for me to air them here under privilege.

However, there can be a fine line between what is right and what is wrong. While there is nothing illegal about it, what is morally wrong is that Mr Pass—who, as I understand it, is the Leader of the Democrats in Victoria—was on the payroll of the Leader of the Democrats and collected some $18,000 in overtime. The question should be asked of Senator Coulter: who is beyond redemption? I suggest to Senator Coulter that before he throws mud he should clean up the cesspool in his own backyard.

During Estimates, the Minister made the point that while it would not be proper to investigate the Scetrine affair himself—and I agree with that—there were mechanisms within the Department to do so. I ask the Minister what those mechanisms are and what the progress has been to date.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Calvert covered this question, I must say more briskly than Senator Parer did. He referred to the Scetrine overtime claims and the fact that during the Estimates committee process I indicated that we would revisit it, and we have done so. The person in charge of this area in the Department has, as would normally happen, analysed the claim forms and has advised me that they were all in accordance with procedures. The advice I have had from the officer is that the matter is still under consideration.

—To what extent can the responsible officer within the Department carry out investigations? Is it simply a matter of seeing that the authorisation is signed or can the officer undertake further investigations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have recently discovered in these sorts of matters—and the Blunt case is one that comes very much to mind—in the first instance departmental officers obviously scrutinise the conduct, the activity, and they then raise it either directly with the member or with me. For instance, as we found in the Blunt matter, if there was a feeling that the investigations could not proceed too far if they continued to be conducted by officers of DAS, then other mechanisms could be utilised. In that case, the advice was ultimately that we take the matter to the Australian Federal Police.

PARA.TAB: In this case, as I have said, the claim forms have been scrutinised and the advice is that they seem to be in accordance with procedures. If officers believe that there should be any further avenues of investigation by any other organisations, I will get advice on that. In terms of possibilities, one is essentially looking at either the Federal Police or the Fraud Control Unit within my Department as being the two major alternatives. But I would imagine in these circumstances that if a matter needs further investigation and cannot be resolved in the first instance—and I think a number of times matters are resolved before they even go to the inquiry or investigation stage—then we have those avenues available. I would not act unilaterally to pursue any further course of investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, but I wonder about the status of the matter. Is the matter closed as far as the Department is concerned, or are investigations continuing?

—The short answer is that it is not closed. As part of that short answer, the scrutiny so far has indicated, for instance, that no 26-hour days have been worked. As I said, the claims are in accordance with procedures, but the matter is not closed and the officer handling it needs to take some further steps to satisfy his mind that action may or may not be taken.
—Have you gone so far as to seek the advice of the Federal Police?
—The answer is no.

—I made the point in my introductory remarks about its being rumour. I said therefore that I would not repeat it in this place because the matter was privileged and it would be improper to do so. But the rumours around this place are such that I wondered to what extent Senator Bolkus's Department is able to investigate those stories by means other than just simply the people who signed the piece of paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very dangerous as a sport or an activity of this place to conduct inquiries into rumours, to branch off into witch-hunts, without the basis of any substantial evidence. I think Senator Parer would understand the imperative to have evidence before one goes off pursuing individuals on the basis of rumours. If that were the name of the game, then probably none of us would be here.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to Senator Parer that if he does have anything of substance—and I know and appreciate the fact that he does not want to raise it in an open forum—maybe the best course of action would be for us to talk about any evidence he might have and pass it on to the relevant investigating officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Going back to property services, even though we went through these in dot point form and the Minister gave me a quite satisfactory answer, I want to ask a question. I know Senator Bolkus will not have the answer with him, but he could take it on notice. He gave me a reply after the required date in regard to the database on property holdings. I am grateful for that reply. What was not included in that database of property holdings was vacant land owned by the Commonwealth. Could the Minister give me details of that vacant land to add to the list of properties that are not vacant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can provide that. I also take this opportunity to incorporate an answer in Hansard. I apologise to Senator Parer for not having done this before. Some time in the last week we were here Senator Parer asked a question about a company called Condux and a bridge link between Sussex Street and Kent Street in Sydney. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988 the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services identified a need for additional accommodation in conjunction with the relocation of elements of its operation from the Commonwealth Centre in Chifley Square, Sydney due to its sale by the Commonwealth.
A new building at the rear of 333 Kent Street, the existing leased premises, being the whole of the premises known as 120 Sussex Street, was identified as suitable for the purpose.

Part of the negotiations for the lease of the building were that a pedestrian bridge be constructed to link it with the existing accommodation in order to facilitate the efficiency of use of both buildings by the one Department.

The agreement on the bridge provided that the developer of 120 Sussex Street (Condux) will have full responsibility for the construction and maintenance of the bridge, with the Commonwealth paying amortised cost of the bridge over 10 years as part of the overall leasing arrangement with repayments at about $40,000 per annum on the basis of an estimate of $168,500 for bridge construction.
In addition to the amortisation factor, a licence fee of $20,000 per annum is being paid to the Lessors of 333 Kent Street for ground rent/air space.
This agreement is regarded as a standard commercial transaction in the commercial environment.
A payout of the amortisation principal on the bridge link was made in June 1991 in th amount $145,154 to Arthur Anderson and Co receivers for Condux Limited (in liquidation).

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—That concludes consideration of subprogram 3.7. We proceed to program 6, the Australian Electoral Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it suits the convenience of the Senate, Senator Tate might now take over from me. I think Senator Tambling might find it a more pleasant experience than some he has had in the past. The Department seems to be having the same sort of problem with the Australian Electoral Commission as I do. It has been trying to contact it without much success. But the officers have just arrived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some issues connected with the Australian Electoral Commission that arise out of questions on notice with regard to the operation of the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service. A very comprehensive 16-part question and answer was tabled as part of the considerations arising from the Estimates.

PARA.TAB: In looking at the answer to the question on notice, I believe that further issues need to be pursued, particularly with regard to the operation of the community electoral assistants that have been both identified and trained by the Australian Electoral Commission. I also note that recently in the Parliament we had tabled a special report dated September 1991 on the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. That report has been considered by the Senate and I am sure that a number of issues will continue to tax senators and members of the House of Representatives, the Government and the Australian Electoral Commission.

In turning to the detail of the answers provided, I note that the community electoral assistants are paid only for their training and for the periods in which they are hired for the duration of elections. In one of the answers—I believe it is in 5(c)—it is noted that as at 30 August 1991 in excess of 400 community electoral assistants were in place in Aboriginal and Islander communities and organisations. The answer at 5(d) goes on to say that it is anticipated that by the end of 1991, 13 1/2 staff would be employed full time by the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service.

Very obviously, over the period since 1984-85 we have seen—as the Commission acknowledges—in excess of 400 of these people hired or trained and put into the field. In fact, in the current year it is anticipated that 13 1/2 staff will be carrying out these duties full time. I also note that in the seven or eight years of the operation of this scheme, the Commission has expended $7.27m on this program. Therefore, it has been an expensive exercise training and facilitating the operation of this scheme, and 400 of these people are now in place in organisations. How many of these 400 people who have received training are known to the Commission to be still operating effectively in assisting the Aboriginal communities throughout Australia? In what areas of Australia have they been identified as working?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Commission is still able to make contact with the 400 people, although the degree to which they are called upon will vary according to whether there is an election or some such matter—for example, if a visit from an AIEIS officer is coming up, these people are contacted. They form a permanent pool of people who can be called upon. They are regarded as effective as persons within the community who are knowledgeable in this area. They are able to be called upon according to varying requirements, as I have said, depending on what activity is being undertaken in the particular area concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of the 400 people are currently on the mailing lists of the Electoral Commission? What regularity of contact, retraining and up-dating of information is maintained with these people who, the Commission acknowledges, in effect, carry out unpaid work under the program on various occasions? Could a list of those 400 personnel be provided at a later date? I do not want to have people identified by name but by the communities and electorates in which the Commission maintains contact with them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, a list can be provided in the way that Senator Tambling seeks, rather than by personal identification. Apparently, there is no mailing list. An AIEIS officer who needs to make contact in a particular instance does so by an individual visit, by telephone or perhaps by individual notification by mail or fax, rather than by being provided with a central mailing list.

PARA.TAB: I do not think I have been given an answer by the officer as to whether there is continuous training or re-training, or making sure that these people are kept up to date; but if community electoral officers or assistants do remain on the books and indicate a willingness to do so, I suppose the AIEIS officer takes responsibility for updating them and bringing them up to speed in relation to any electoral matter with which they ought to be conversant.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to receiving the list of the people who are still in constant contact and updating their information. I also note with regard to the 13 1/2 staff positions that it is anticipated will be on the books for 1991, that 3 1/2 of these are located in capital cities: Sydney, Brisbane, Perth and the half position is allocated to Hobart. Therefore, it would be hard to identify the electorate based activity of those particular officers. I have been able to ascertain that the remaining officers are located in Canberra; Broome; Townsville; a person is based in Alice Springs, obviously for the electorate of Grey in South Australia; Port Hedland; Darwin; Tenant Creek and Alice Springs—all electorates that are held by the Labor Government. Are their activities exclusive to these particular electorates?

PARA.TAB: I gather from reading the general information contained in the detail of the question that much of this activity takes place in what can be identified from Bureau of Statistics material as the seven major electorates held by Labor in Australia. They are, in numerical order of population size: the Northern Territory, Kalgoorlie in Western Australia, Leichhardt in Queensland, Kennedy in Queensland, Grey in South Australia, Herbert in Queensland and Hinkler in Queensland.

I am unable to ascertain from any of the information that has been provided in the answers that any activity is taking place in what I can identify as the seven largest electorates in Australia, by Aboriginal population, which are seats currently held by the Liberal or National parties. They are, again in order of population size: the seat of Gwydir in New South Wales, the seat of Parkes in New South Wales, O'Connor in Western Australia, Riverina-Darling in New South Wales, Maranoa in Queensland, Dawson in Queensland and Cowper in New South Wales. In the operation of this scheme, has there been any activity by this program in any of those seven largest Opposition-held seats?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the decisions were made basically to give priority to remote area Aboriginal communities. The other factor taken into account was agreement with the State or Territory government concerned. For example, I am advised that in Queensland agreement came rather late and then it was in relation to the former reserve areas. In New South Wales, agreement has finally been forthcoming and in this Budget moneys have been provided for one officer who will work out of Sydney, but who will be covering a number of divisions. In other words, the allocation of personnel was not made on the basis of divisions; it was made according to criteria basically weighting remote areas, and/or depending on agreement with governments which has been slowly forthcoming.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that all 14 electorates I nominated can be identified as remote, rural, disadvantaged and the most significant Aboriginal populations in Australia. What concerns me more is that the activity of the Australian Electoral Commission, in eight years of operation with a budget in excess of $7m, has been focused primarily in those seven seats held by the Australian Labor Party. That is a serious omission and is a serious disadvantage to the Aboriginal constituents of Australia who ought to be well served. In some way, it invites comparisons and questions of political involvement in the processing of how these decisions have come about. Similarly, if one looks at the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the numbers of Aboriginal people identified by electorate in the capital cities, one will see that it is very easy to note that there is no large migration of Aboriginal people back into the capital cities. Yet obviously that is the focus.

PARA.TAB: I will be pleased to receive the list of the identifying 400 positions of trainees to see where the training and evaluation for these people rests in respect of the majority electorates, whether they are located in the seven significant Labor Party seats, and to what degree there has been an emphasis in activity. I note in the detailed answer to the question referring to the workshops that have been carried out that they also arise in Labor held seats of the Federal Parliament.

If I can change the emphasis slightly, I note that there is to be an expansion of the activity in this area to concentrate on State and local government priorities. Again, I can appreciate that the local government area is similar to the ATSIC consideration. I fully expect the Electoral Commission to concentrate activities in local government areas that can be identified as having significant numbers of Aboriginal voters. What identification work has the Commission carried out to identify those local government municipalities in Australia? How have they been identified by Aboriginal population and voter numbers? How have the priorities been worked out for future activity in that area? Is it to arise only in the seven significant Labor held Federal areas that have received the obvious advantage of this very significant and important program to date?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the significance of involvement under this program with local government elections has perhaps been somewhat misunderstood. It is simply that the emphasis will remain on Commonwealth elections but that attention will be given, within the areas already designated, to local government election matters as they arise, as persons take an interest in them or, I suppose, as an election is coming up. But it is not that a separate detailed program has been devised based on local government areas with respect to the education of Aboriginal persons within those areas as to their rights and opportunities under the voting regime that might apply there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —My final point on this issue relates to a suggestion that arises from the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service which was tabled recently. Page 57 of the majority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: that, as suggested to the Committee by representatives of New South Wales Aboriginal groups, greater use be made of mobile polling booths in urban areas to make voting easier for Aboriginal and Islander electors in those areas.

Has the Commission taken any action to initiate work with regard to mobile polling in urban areas? If so, what special considerations would be made in that regard to ensure that this is not discrimination against the general electorate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, that report was only tabled recently and the Government has not yet responded to it. The sorts of considerations about discrimination within urban areas to which Senator Tambling has adverted would be proper matters for the Government to take into account when composing its response.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Is there anything else relating to the unanswered questions that were listed for this section of the Department of Administrative Services? If not, that completes consideration of the Department of Administrative Services.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee D. Consideration of the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services was concluded just prior to the dinner adjournment. I will now call on the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise some issues under the heading of general matters. We have before us a report of some six paragraphs on the Employment, Education and Training portfolio. My question relates to the brevity of the report and its lack of comprehensiveness.

PARA.TAB: Three of the six paragraphs relate specifically to employment, education and training. Paragraph 10 on page 3 is an appreciation of the offer by Dr Neil Johnson to brief members on the factual matters relating to the Department's report. Paragraph 11 relates to foreign entry of students into Australian education institutions and some of the problems that have been raised in regard to processing. Paragraph 12 refers to the relationship between DEET and DILGEA, and particularly the lack of compatibility between the computing systems in those departments—and that is it. After that, the report goes on to deal with ATSIC.

Given that we have spent up to 12 hours in the Estimates Committee with DEET and that during that time we covered seven programs, 22 subprograms and 45 components of those programs, I find it amazing that the report to the Committee of the Whole lacks such comprehensiveness. What is the rationale behind picking some of these areas and leaving out others? Why were these matters relating to overseas students and the relationship between DEET and DILGEA the only things that were picked upon for comment in the report?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney is asking the wrong person. I assume that Senator Tierney is referring to the report of Estimates Committee D. The selection was made by the Committee and not by the Minister. I understand that the honourable senator may wish to put his comment on record but it is not a matter to which I can respond.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for that indication. I want to put the matter on record because it relates to procedure. We have received a report entitled Estimates Committee D Report to the Senate. We have also received a number of additional volumes which all specifically relate to questions that were asked. One would think that, given that we covered an enormous range of questions and that we ranged across seven programs and 45 components, we would have something in summary in this report to the Committee of the Whole to reflect correctly what had happened during the proceedings. I find the report to be very selective. I cannot work out the rationale as to why certain things have been selected and why other very important issues that we raised in general have been left out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The consideration in Estimates Committee D of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was, as usual, very comprehensive. A number of issues were canvassed and a number of points have been made on the portfolio. I appreciate the efforts of the staff of ATSIC in handling answers to questions on notice which came in both during the estimates process and subsequently and which are very satisfactory in terms of providing information. I commend to honourable senators an appraisal of those questions and answers. Although many issues were covered, it is a pity in that they did not receive the media attention that can give a positive aspect to much of the work that is being undertaken by many people throughout Australia in this important portfolio area.

PARA.TAB: There will always be areas of criticism because of the controversial nature of this large and important portfolio. The evolution of development in many Aboriginal communities is not uniform, nor should it be, and many problems will arise. The main matter that this chamber has a responsibility to address is the fact that the portfolio figures indicate that there is well in excess of an estimated expenditure of over $600m on the portfolio related activities in this area. That is a large investment of taxpayers' funds. From time to time there will be criticisms where projects fail, where administration may not be effective or where, for other reasons, maladministration, ineptitude and in some case even fraud take place. We must address these matters.

When I say that the portfolio identified area is in excess of $600m, I point out that there is a considerable amount of additional expenditure in the Aboriginal community that is proper, routine and additional. I refer to expenditure related to the Department of Social Security, the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, to give two easy examples, and the many other portfolios from which Aboriginal people receive benefits, as do other Australian constituents.
One of the issues that I wish to address critically concerns a question that I placed on notice about the reconciliation of the program

SPEECH.PARA: performance statements and the other indicators that were available in various other Budget related papers. I had trouble trying to reconcile the financial figures in both the Budget related papers and in the program performance statements for 1991-92. That, of course, was reflected in my questions. In answer to my questions, I have received eight pages of detail, which is quite comprehensive, in attempting to reconcile the portfolio expenditure with the Budget related papers. I feel that it is a pity that it was necessary for the Commission to have to produce such detail when this information ought to have been readily available and readily reconcilable between the program expenditure performance statements and the more comprehensive statements in the Budget related papers.

PARA.TAB: I highlight for the benefit of the Senate, for the attention of the Auditor-General, for the attention of the officers of the Department of Finance and, in particular, for the attention of the financial administration personnel of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission my concerns that this portfolio area, which has been controversial now for a number of years, ought to be able to provide better information at this stage of Budget development. Whilst the very comprehensive eight-page document is certainly available to anyone who seeks to look at it, there were two tables in this particular issue, on page 2 and on page 7, which I think were important statements in attempting to reconcile the papers. I have not had the opportunity to discuss this with Senator McMullan, but I would seek leave to incorporate in Hansard these tables which are direct takes from the much more detailed answer that was given. I think they provide examples of the necessary reconciliation, as I have commented, and the need to have this information readily available. I seek leave to have these tables incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Arising from the more detailed answer and, as I said, the eight pages of reconciliation detail, I want to bring a couple of questions to the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). In response to question No. 5, the answer was given that:

PARA.TAB: ATSIC has been informed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics since publication of Budget Related Paper No. 7 that its Aboriginal statistics project was overlooked.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask why that happened. I believe that the excuse of being overlooked is not sufficient. I seek to ascertain how such an error could have been made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither the officers available nor I know the details about the precise matter to which Senator Tambling refers, so we will take the question on notice and provide the answer as promptly as possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to a question that dealt with an official source of a number of statements of disadvantage and discrimination which had to be attended to and which are stated as justification for various expenditure programs, there is reference to an article by Dr Tesfaghiorghis and Dr J.C. Altman entitled `Aboriginal Socioeconomic Status: Are there any evident changes?'. I gather that this refers to information that was presented to the Royal Commission Inquiry into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I am not aware that this document has ever been published, yet the information in it is now being used as important justification and clarification with regard to programs of the Commission. Would it be appropriate for that paper subsequently to be made available, through the Estimates Committee or to the Senate, in order to have it properly recorded as a document of the Senate on which we can rely? Also, have the statements in that document been tested for consistency with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and are they backed up by the various research programs of the North Australian Development Unit of the previous Department of Social Security and the North Australian Research Unit of the Australian National University?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the paper has been published and we can certainly make a copy of it available to Senator Tambling. If any other senator would like a copy, he has only to indicate that to ATSIC, me or the Minister responsible and we will certainly make it available. The response concerning the reconciliation, et cetera, is not precisely an ATSIC matter. It is properly a question for the independent research centre. I know that it is funded by ATSIC, but it is an independent research centre. When Senator Tambling reads the paper he may want to raise some questions with that body. He should raise them directly with the research people, who I am sure will be happy to discuss these matters with him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having dealt with the issues arising from the reconciliation of the various documents put forward, I would like to pursue several other matters with regard to some questions that I asked at the Estimates Committee with regard to the activities and financial administration of an Aboriginal organisation at Tennant Creek, the Anyinginyi Congress, which basically is a health provider for Aboriginal people. I was given a four-part comprehensive answer with regard to the various stages of budgeting, objectives and evaluations of the programs at that time. During the Estimates Committee discussions I also raised with the CEO of ATSIC the matter of the obvious need in this area to engage in a more comprehensive audit and consideration of this organisation.

PARA.TAB: I was left with the impression at the Estimates Committee that that inquiry was to proceed immediately and without delay and with a great deal of necessary attention. At what stage has that inquiry now reached? I am also keen to ascertain whether there has been any link between the Anyinginyi Congress inquiry in Tennant Creek and the issue that has arisen in the Northern Territory media in the last week with regard to alleged misappropriation of more than $1m with regard to the Jurnkurakurr Outstation Resource Centre and, in particular, an ATSIC inquiry commissioned of the firm of accountants—Pannell, Kerr Forster. First, is there any link with Anyinginyi? Secondly, what is the state of the ATSIC's inquiry into this second organisation, Jurnkurakurr Outstation Resource Centre, and does ATSIC have any particular concerns in that regard?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before going to these two particular matters, I am advised that ATSIC is not aware of any particular link. I will deal with each of these separately to the extent that I have advice on them, but my understanding is that ATSIC currently does not believe there is any link between the two.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the Anyinginyi Congress, there are two elements in the response: firstly, the Congress is scheduled for health performance review as part of ATSIC's cyclical assessment process, and this review will be undertaken in accordance with normal procedures and will commence as soon as a suitable independent consultant can be assigned. With regard to the second aspect, which relates more directly to the matter Senator Tambling raised about the specific allegations concerning the financial operations of the organisation, the accounting firm of Pannell Kerr Forster will undertake a separate review of accounts of the Congress. Originally the review was to commence today, 5 November. However, due to traditional mourning ceremonies within the region, the accountancy review will now commence in the week beginning 11 November. That is the information I have on the first matter.

With regard to the second matter—if Senator Tambling will forgive me, I will call it JORC for want of opting out of the pronunciation of the original Aboriginal name—there has been concern about continued breaches of grant reporting conditions and, as a consequence, ATSIC has imposed additional conditions on JORC with a view to a full financial and performance review of its operations in June of this year. That review identified further breaches of ATSIC grant funding and led to a submission to the ATSIC meeting No. 12 in August this year. The Commission at its meeting in August determined that JORC could continue to receive funding subject to certain stringent conditions, one of which was that the regional manager needed to be satisfied that financial and physical reports are available to indicate that the grant moneys are being correctly applied.

The Office of Local Government Tennant Creek branch recently initiated a review of JORC management following receipt of a substantial list of allegations of mismanagement. On the basis of advice received from the Office of Local Government, the Commission served notice on JORC that further grant releases were being withheld and that it intended to commission the firm of Pannell Kerr Forster to carry out a detailed investigation in view of continued breaches of Commission grant conditions.

The investigation commenced on 9 October. On 24 October the report was provided indicating that JORC had used Commission moneys for unapproved purposes and that there was evidence of gross mismanagement and deliberate breaches of grant conditions. On 30 October the Commission sent two of its senior central office staff to Tennant Creek to work with local staff to develop a strategy to address the findings and recommendations of the Pannell Kerr Forster report, that is, the accountancy firm's report. This report from the officers was received in the Commission's central office yesterday and is currently being considered. Commission decisions on the report, I am advised, are imminent and there is an awareness of the need to take immediate action. I am also informed that the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations, who has responsibility for administering the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976 under which the JORC is incorporated, is issuing JORC with a notice under section 68 of that Act requesting the public officer to show cause why the Registrar should not investigate JORC's affairs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answers and ask whether copies of the various reports into the operations of JORC could be made available to the Senate.
—I will check with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and certainly raise that question with him and, if he is happy about it, I shall make it available.

—I also wish to establish whether there is any link between the Anyinginyi Congress investigation and the Jurnkurakurr resource centre inquiry and any reports to ATSIC of problems with the administration of grants made by ATSIC or any funding, whether it be loan funding if necessary, to community governments in the communities of Elliott or Borroloola in the Northern Territory, which I also understand are administered from the same office of ATSIC in Tennant Creek. At the same time, I would be keen to establish whether there are reports to ATSIC with regard to the maladministration and misappropriation of funds under the three community development and employment programs which are very significant in the Barkly region to three communities. Are those particular programs also under inquiry and investigation? Is there any known link between those organisations, particularly Jurnkurakurr, which services the outstations of the Barkly region?

—The officers are not, nor am I, aware of any particular programs of the sort Senator Tambling referred to with regard to Elliott or Borroloola or with CDEPs in the Barkly region. I will of course make sure that someone checks and if there is any subsequent information I will make it available. However, I am not aware of any such problems.
