—Can I ascertain whether any staff officers of ATSIC who have been based in the Tennant Creek regional office in the calendar year 1991 have been transferred from that office to any other office of ATSIC, and has that transfer in any way been linked at all with suggestions of maladministration with regard to any of these particular programs?

—I am advised that there has been staff movement but there is always a high level of turnover, as I am sure Senator Tambling would be aware, in such offices in Tennant Creek and similar regions. However, I am not aware, nor are the officers aware, of any link between any staff turnover and the matters under investigation.

—I look forward to receiving the information that Senator McMullan has indicated will subsequently be reported on this particular matter. It is obvious to me as a senator for the Northern Territory that there is an obvious and major and significant problem in the Barkly region and the Tennant Creek office of ATSIC. The fact that it is acknowledged that there are necessary inquiries in the case of the Anyinginyi Congress and the Jurnkurakurr outstation resource centre is of major concern. It would appear that it is acknowledged that misappropriations are in excess of $1m in at least one of those programs which is now under major inquiry and review.

PARA.TAB: Of course, when events such as this come to our attention, the tragedy is that the persons affected most are the Aboriginal people who rely so heavily on the services of these organisations. Anyinginyi Congress was established to provide essential health care for the Aboriginal people of Tennant Creek and the Barkly region. The Jurnkurakurr Outstation Resource Centre was established to provide a necessary infrastructure and community services facility for thousands of Aboriginal people in a remote, isolated and often desert type area. For such allegations even to be made and subsequent problems to arise means that it is these very Aboriginal people who live in such isolated and unfortunate circumstances who are missing out on the benefits of the funds that have been appropriated through this Parliament.

The other two programs that I alluded to, which the Parliamentary Secretary was not able to provide information on at this stage—that is, grant funds for municipal and local government functions at Elliott and Borroloola, and for three very significant employment related programs of the CDEP in the Barkly region—are also in question. Here are two areas of municipal functions which it is important to recognise go to the very provision of essential health services—be it public health facilities—and other community services. Whilst the CDEP is, in effect, a workfor the dole situation, it provides excellent facilities in many areas. The fact that these have all had to be called into question raises some major problems.

I hope that they are receiving the close attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner; the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon; and my Senate colleague Senator Collins; all of whom, I am sure, share with me a major concern when we talk about the misappropriation of millions of dollars in this particular area. I hope that in the next few days we will see this matter addressed.

I did seek from the Minister's office earlier this week a briefing on these particular matters. My staff requested it initially, I subsequently followed up with more formal requests and I was annoyed that today, following subsequent follow-ups, I received a message that I would now have to put my comments and request for a briefing on this matter in writing. I would have hoped that because the matters are so very serious Minister Tickner would have responded much more promptly, and sought to acknowledge that this is a very serious service delivery matter that could affect not only the lifestyle, but also the very lives, of many people who may well be threatened if health care is not properly delivered. I hope that we will get a satisfactory report from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at an early date.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The very nature of the material we are discussing means there is not a lot I can say in response to Senator Tambling's contribution—essentially, he was making a statement for the record—but I do want to say two things. I acknowledge the seriousness of the two initial matters which he raised and to which I gave a comprehensive response. They are serious and worthy of consideration. In the other two areas I cannot at this stage even confirm that the problems to which Senator Tambling refers exist. We all have to be a bit careful about leaping from real problems in one area to assuming that all the expressions of concern and allegations that one hears—and we all hear them in lots of areas of public life—are necessarily accurate. That is not to say they are not true either; it is a matter of saying let us show some discretion about that.

PARA.TAB: It is proper to say for the record that it is important to recognise that ATSIC officers are not necessarily at fault when third party organisations within their areas encounter difficulties, any more than others of us who are responsible for particular areas can monitor every action of every individual within our areas of responsibility. I do not want to leap to opposite conclusions and say that because I do not have any evidence that there is a problem, there is not one. I simply want to make sure that we are not leaping from two real concerns to assuming that every other potential area of concern is as serious as the allegations made about it. I will undertake to ensure that the matters raised are properly pursued and that there is a proper response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few general comments on the ATSIC program. I noticed in this year's Senate Estimates Committee hearings that ATSIC officers stated in response to questions that certain funded programs were the responsibility of former departments of Aboriginal Affairs or the ADC, and that ATSIC is not responsible. I appreciate that ATSIC should not be held responsible for some of the failures of DAA and ADC, but it goes against the grain a little if ATSIC continues to make what certainly can be perceived in some areas as the same mistakes as the DAA.

PARA.TAB: The other two matters which I wish to comment on relate to the responses given to the questions I placed on notice. My staff went to considerable lengths to ensure that questions were divided into program, subprogram and component order, as were the wishes of this Committee. Consequently, I was a trifle unhappy to see that ATSIC answered questions in a format which was very difficult to match with the questions, as the program numbers in some cases were not provided. The work of the Committee of the Whole is severely hampered because a number of questions asked of ATSIC and DEET have not yet been answered. In future, the Committee should take care to ensure that the bulk of questions have been answered and that a certain amount of time has elapsed to ensure that adequate attention has been paid to the answers provided.

Senator Collins is now the Minister at the table and I can tell him, in case he is not aware of it, that I was able to have a very brief discussion with Senator McMullan. A number of my questions dealt with the training for Aboriginals program—TAP—and the officers responsible for that, as part of DEET, have now left. Senator McMullan was kind enough to agree that these questions should be placed on notice, so I place those questions on notice. I have a number of questions on the ATSIC program ranging from land management to law and justice. I have had the chance to have a brief, informal discussion with the officers. My questions will require somewhat fuller answers than can be given by the Minister at the table and it might be better if I put these questions on notice as well.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Is that convenient, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—There being no further questions relating to ATSIC, the consideration of the estimates of the Department of Employment, Education and Training has now concluded. I call on the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. (Quorum formed) The Committee is considering the estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. There being no questions, the question is that the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Collins) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee E be adopted.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The Committee will consider the expenditure for the Attorney-General's Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions relating to page 2 of the Estimates Committee E report to the Senate about the Attorney-General's Department. There is a general reservation by the whole Committee in relation to Copyright Agency Ltd. During the Estimates Committee questions were raised as to whether the Attorney-General's Department had had any negotiations with Copyright Agency Ltd, a private company set up in this country which collects copyright licence fees from a variety of people, not the least of which are our tertiary institutions, and then allegedly distributes those licence fees so collected to the people who earn them.

PARA.TAB: For some time there has been concern that, because the copyright laws in Australia contain a particular exception relating to journalists, they might wish to claim what I understand—the Minister will correct me if I am wrong—to be some sort of residual copyright that the journalists have in articles of theirs that are printed in newspapers. By that I mean that if Michelle Grattan were to write articles for the Age and was paid a salary package and if the articles were used for anything other than reprinting in the Age or within the newspaper group by which she is employed, the general law is that, unless she has contracted out of that, she has some copyright in those articles.

This has particular consequences for a wide variety of people who might like to use photostat copies of the articles in question. The journalist need not be Michelle Grattan; it might be Beverley Sutherland Smith, who is the food writer for the Age. Unless Beverley Sutherland Smith has a particular contract with the Age, that newspaper would not be able to publish a collected series of her works without having some additional negotiations with her as to the copyright left in the articles because they are being used for something other than printing in the Age.

One immediately thinks of people in the Parliamentary Library as being the sort of people who might be affected by this. Everyone in this chamber and anyone listening would be aware of the use parliamentarians make of photostat articles from the newspapers. Not only the Parliamentary Library provides such a service; a lot of departments also have their own libraries and their own newspaper clipping services. Articles that are relevant to departmental purposes are clipped from newspapers across Australia. They are photostatted and distributed throughout the department, perhaps to various members of the perceived client group, and certainly to the Minister.

Copyright Agency Ltd has not been set up by the Government; it is an independent company that has, as I understand it, the signatures of about 300 journalists, which certainly does not include all the journalists in this country. Through the Estimates Committee we found that it has approached the Attorney-General's Department and said, `We want to negotiate with you about the copying of our articles'. The initial gambit was that it wanted 10c per page. This is not an easy matter for a variety of reasons. For instance, not every article written by a journalist carries that journalist's by-line. How is someone to know whether something that is being copied is an article the copyright agency for which is held by Copyright Agency Ltd. If there is no by-line, we do not know who wrote it.

As I understand it, the Copyright Agency Ltd response to this is, `Just give us 10c a page for every page and then there will not be that problem'. That is fine for the Copyright Agency Ltd, but it is not fine for the journalists who have not signed up with this agency. They might say, `Over and above what you give to them, if I can show that that is my article I want some money for it'—to say nothing of the copyright element that is left with the newspaper proprietor in the photocopying of these matters.

As I am informed, Copyright Agency Ltd has said that it wants 10c a page. Madam Temporary Chairman, if our only motivation were money, you and I should resign from our jobs; if we could get 10c a page for every photocopy of every newspaper article in this country we would be millionaires overnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or copies of your pamphlet.

—Indeed. I am glad the Minister raised that: or copies of the pamphlet I produced. No doubt, Madam Temporary Chairman, you are familiar with this leaflet, which has been very popular—in fact, a sell-out. If the Minister wants more copies I will get a few done for him.

PARA.TAB: That reminds me that a journalist informed me that aNiMaLS—the National Media Liaison Service—distributed copies of it. The aNiMaLS people were a bit coy when asked about it in earlier Estimates. They said that they thought the ministerial office might have done it. I do not think the journalist who spoke to me was lying. I am well aware of the fact that aNiMaLS frequently copies, if not my booklet then a lot of work put out by members of the Opposition, members of the Government and a whole lot of other people, without a whisker of concern for who owns the copyright. That is a matter for aNiMaLS to worry about. When asked about this, they said that it was not their problem; they did not actually clip articles. I am not sure that that is the whole truth, but that is what we were told. They deal with a clipping agency, the name of which escapes me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monitair.

—Monitair has an arrangement with Copyright Agency Ltd, so it is all okay—a clear misunderstanding by the aNiMaLS as to what is okay and what is not. If I make an arrangement with Copyright Agency Ltd, all it will do is cover me for the use of the copyright for the journalists for which it is agent; it will not cover me for every other Tom, Dick and Harry journalist around. It will certainly not cover me for the use of the work of Senator Macdonald, Senator Hill, Senator Reid, Senator Walters, nay, even the work of the good Minister. It will not cover me for that; but if it did cover me for that—that is, everything that I ever wanted a photostat of in my life—which only a halfwit or a grade 2 child who had had this half explained to him would imagine to be the case, it would certainly not cover anyone to whom I passed those articles. The understanding of aNiMaLS is, `Oh well, we have got it from someone who is covered'. It is questionable whether that is so, but it thinks that, because it has got it from someone who is covered, it is covered too. That is clearly not the case.

PARA.TAB: I have referred to this at some length because I want to highlight the degree of concern there should be over anybody negotiating with Copyright Agency Ltd as though it were the agent for all authors, as though an agreement with it as to copyright covered an agreement for all the people for whom it is not agents. It does not.

That is the first point. The second point is that it just happens to be a fortune or misfortune—I am not sure which; my view fluctuates on this on a day to day basis—as to the regard in which the legal profession is held in this community. By and large, it is held in high rather than low regard, and Copyright Agency Ltd knows that. That is why it has started to negotiate with the Attorney-General's Department. If it can say `The Attorney-General's Department—the people who have some say and some sort of guidance to offer in the construction of copyright law in this country—has agreed that we should be paid 10c a page', it would be no surprise to me if other departments and government instrumentalities did not fall over like ninepins.

Who would they be to say that the Attorney-General's Department was wrong? They would have to have pretty confident legal advice to say, `The Attorney-General's Department—a bunch of whackers yet again'. I do not say that that is the common view; it certainly is not. I raise it because it is a very uncommon view. I expect that other departments and government instrumentalities would think very seriously about saying no to something that the Attorney-General's Department has said yes to. In the Estimates Committee I found that the Attorney-General's Department has commenced negotiations with Copyright Agency Ltd. I am very concerned about that because of the precedent it creates for every other department and government instrumentality, let alone private enterprise. I think it is an appalling situation.

As I have been told, the Copyright Agency Ltd has dropped the 10c a page, whether or not it has the agency for these people, and we have forgotten about that technicality. Despite the fact that Copyright Agency Ltd is claiming this money on the basis of a technicality, it forgets the technicality that it does not have agency for everyone. Madam Temporary Chairman, if you were able to speak from the chair, I would ask you what you think it was asking as an alternative. I would be very surprised if you guessed that it was asking for 10 per cent of gross income instead.

At a time when we have people on both sides of the chamber—some more than others—busting their minds about how to make this country work and how to get a one per cent or 2 per cent increase in productivity, when we have nearly 10 per cent unemployment and are trying to work out how to get employment going, we have a crowd of private individuals who have set up a company, called themselves Copyright Agency Ltd, marched into the Attorney-General's Department and said `We would like 10c a page, but we will accept 10 per cent of the gross income', and are still being entertained in that Department. There is something wrong with that.

I want to know whom the Attorney-General's Department thinks Copyright Agency Ltd represents. If it opens the door to these people, who else will it open it to, and who has it decided, in its wisdom, it will close it to? What exactly is it going to do in relation to this very serious matter?

I conclude by saying that this matter was raised in the United Kingdom about four years ago. It was decided that the journalists did not deserve this residual copyright. In fact they have an exception at the moment in the copyright law. They have this residual copyright in a way that a lot of other people do not. It is a matter that needs to be nipped in the bud. I will be delighted to hear what the Minister can tell me about why the Attorney-General's Department is negotiating with these people. Whom does the Department think Copyright Agency Ltd represents? What investigations has it made as to the amount collected by Copyright Agency Ltd from all the tertiary institutions in this country, compared with the amount paid out by authors? How much is either sitting in the funds of Copyright Agency Ltd or has been siphoned off for other purposes?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the matters raised by Senator Vanstone merit careful weighing by the Attorney-General's Department, which in this respect is not being picked off by this particular organisation as a beachhead into the Commonwealth. Rather, as I understand it, the Attorney-General's Department has been carrying out some very preliminary and not very substantive negotiations with a view to better placing the Commonwealth as a whole, in its various agencies and departments, to discharge its proper obligations in regard to the holders of copyright.

PARA.TAB: I guess that there is some attraction in the idea that if we can channel lawfully required payments into one organisation, which can then disburse them to its members or to those on whose behalf it acts, that is an efficiency gain—at least so far as the payment to that one organisation rather than to many authors is concerned.

I understand that nothing has been agreed or substantially negotiated as to a price per page, or matters of such detail. I am quite sure that the officers in the Attorney-General's Department are aware of the limitations of the organisation in so far as it can represent only those who claim to be members of it or those who have given it some authority on their behalf.

As to the latter questions raised by Senator Vanstone, officers of the Department have no knowledge of this organisation taking moneys out of tertiary institutions and perhaps holding them in some sort of account without the proper dispersal to those on whose behalf it purports to collect the moneys. That matter should be considered in so far as it might arouse proper misgivings about the claimed deficiencies and representative capacity—real practical capacity—of the organisation to disburse the moneys that are paid to it. On the whole, all I can say is that this is an attempt by the Attorney-General's Department to see how the Commonwealth might discharge its lawful obligations. Having been alerted so eloquently by Senator Vanstone, I am quite sure that the Department will not be naive in its continued negotiations on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I understand the Minister correctly to say that the Attorney-General's Department understands that the Copyright Agency Ltd does not have the agency for more than about 300 journalists, that there are others who hold copyright and, therefore, that any negotiations with the Copyright Agency Ltd relate only to those authors for whom it has agency?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we are not simply talking about journalists, we are also talking about other authors. This particular organisation could be nominated as the body which authors and journalists ought to belong to if they are to share in the dispersal of the moneys properly paid by the Commonwealth by way of copyright payments in respect of the use of the materials. I am also informed that these matters have by no means been settled. As I understand it, there is no absolute, final position that this organisation will be the sole, absolute representative of all authors and journalists whose material is used by a Commonwealth department or agency.

—Why does the Attorney-General's Department say that this is the agency to which journalists and authors ought to belong should they wish to claim what I am referring to as residual copyright—and I assume the Minister understands what I am talking about. Since when has the Commonwealth said of any agency, `Listen, if you want to claim this right, you ought to belong to this little group here that has set itself up as being the specialists in this field'. Does the Commonwealth say in respect of some sort of product liability, `If you want to claim it, you ought to go to Sly and Weigall or this legal firm or that legal firm'? Of course it does not. Is the Commonwealth saying that at the moment because, as I understand it, this happens to be the only crowd that has set itself up to act as an agent? In fact, anybody could act as agent to collect these fees.

PARA.TAB: Why should an author or a journalist have to appoint an agent? There is no legal requirement for them to do so. I understand the Minister's original point that there is an attraction in having one body through which to dispose of this problem simply—I am attracted to that argument myself—but it is not the law that one body shall act as agent for all bodies that are entitled to collect this money. One does not have to have an agent if one does not want one, and one certainly does not have to have the Copyright Agency Ltd if one does want an agent. Why does the Minister say that this is the body to which people ought to belong? Is it because by a happy accident it has the monopoly in the market at the moment, and the Minister and his Department are happy to encourage that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, Senator Vanstone has exaggerated and misstated my simple statement. I was simply saying that that was the way in which the Department was approaching this very preliminary and early stage in the negotiations. I give great weight to the sorts of considerations which Senator Vanstone has raised. Certainly, the authors and journalists of Australia cannot be hijacked by a group purporting to represent them and act on their behalf in these negotiations. That is absolutely right. If this were to be, if not the exclusive, certainly the premier, primary or most common channel through which payments were made, I do not believe the Commonwealth could reach that point without being absolutely satisfied that, as far as authors are concerned, this body is properly constituted to fulfil their expectations of representation.

PARA.TAB: I am told by officers that the point has not been reached where this body has been designated as the exclusive representative to which all payments will be made. Obviously, it has the attractions which Senator Vanstone has recognised. I have not been fully briefed on these matters, but I am far from saying—and I do not believe the officers differ from me in this respect—that this organisation has already secured an absolute position in these very early stages of negotiation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear that from the Minister, although all it convinces me of is that he is far from saying that the sky is not black. We all know it is not black. The fact that the Attorney-General's Department realises that, is a good thing. These people are clearly not the agents for the whole range of people entitled to claim copyright.

PARA.TAB: I have two questions in relation to this matter. The first is: what investigations have been made by the Attorney-General's Department, and what are the consequences or the outcomes of those investigations, as to the propriety—that is not quite the right word, but it will do for the moment—of the Copyright Agency Ltd in the sense of being an agent for its principals? In other words, what investigations have been made into the amounts of money it collects and the amounts of money it pays out?

If no investigations have been made as to the legitimacy of this organisation and the manner in which it carries out its duties as an agent, why is the Attorney-General's Department continuing to negotiate with it? I ask that because earlier on I asked how much it was collecting from tertiary institutions and how much it was paying out and, as I am advised, it is a very large amount that is being collected and a paltry sum that is being paid out.

Some people in this chamber might be less concerned if the sum was collected from the Attorney-General's Department. I would not be, because I would see that as coming from the taxpayer anyway, but some people would be much more concerned if they realised how much was coming out of our tertiary institutions and being paid to these people and how little was being paid out. I would have thought that some knowledge of that would be helpful to the Attorney-General's Department to know the substance of the people it would be dealing with.

Senator Tate indicated to me that the officers here have little or no knowledge of that. That worries me, because the Copyright Agency Ltd, by virtue of the fact that it is, as I understand it, the only body that has set itself up as a specialist collecting body, may well have established some sort of practical, if not legal, monopoly and as a consequence of that its bona fides are not questioned. As the Copyright Agency Ltd is taking money out of educational institutions, I think that its bona fides should be questioned.

The second question is: Is the Attorney-General's Department now working on the copyright legislation that we have in place to consider whether this problem could be resolved by following the United Kingdom and removing the residual copyright currently available to journalists in this country which is not available in the United Kingdom?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the question of the propriety of the current operations of this organisation, misgivings were raised by Senator Vanstone—and I think that she was careful not to do anything more than raise concerns that had been put to her, obviously, by persons—
—I make no allegations.

—No, but the concern raised is a proper one. Because it is so evidently proper, it is one that the Attorney and his officers would properly take into account when determining whether this organisation was worthy of being nominated as a proper representative or agent on behalf of whatever proportion of authors or journalists might be properly comprehended by it, so that it could be regarded as a body through which payments could be channelled. I have no doubt that when the officers read this transcript, they will probably take the issue into account. But the officers with me tonight have no personal knowledge of the matters which Senator Vanstone has raised.

PARA.TAB: In regard to Senator Vanstone's second point, I do not know of any proposal within the Department to investigate the situation in the United Kingdom. She said that the right of residual copyright had been taken away—by statute, I take it. No such proposal is currently being examined by the Department. But once again, since Senator Vanstone has alerted us to it, it would be worth at least having a look at how the system operates in the United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a query that relates to a matter raised by the Committee of the Whole, that is, parliament and the privacy principles. Perhaps I could deal with it briefly and then, if any other Committee members want to raise matters on earlier programs than program 3.12, which is the first program on which I have made a reservation, I will give the floor to those people. I wonder whether there is something that the Minister can offer in relation to the reservation made by the Committee of the Whole as to parliament and the privacy principles which, as I know the Minister knows, relate to the use by members of parliament of equipment and resources provided by the Commonwealth to store information on all the electors in their electorates.

PARA.TAB: This information can be of a very personal nature. A telephone poll using Commonwealth provided facilities can easily follow the lines of, for example: `I, Joe Bloggs, am ringing on behalf of Senator ABC, who wants to know what you think about the situation at the moment. Are you personally affected by the unemployment in the country?' `Yes, I am unemployed.' That can go down. `What do you think about Mr Webster's private member's Bill as it relates to Medicare funding of abortion?' Someone can, on a one-to-one basis, give an answer as to whether they think Medicare should fund abortions or not.

People might give some information as to their medical or employment history; they might give information that relates to their family in the sense that they see themselves as being the child of a sole parent or part of a divorced family; they might give some sort of family law history. All of this can quite easily be stored on any of the machines provided by the Commonwealth.

The Minister may not know, because his ministerial duties may take him away from such mundane matters as the capacity of the machines provided by the Department to his Senate office in Tasmania, that each of the three machines can easily store an entire Federal electorate and an A4 page of information on each elector. That can be done.

There is some disagreement at the moment between me and the Privacy Commissioner—I think no-one else is involved—as to whether members of parliament could be covered by the privacy legislation. I think that albeit it was not intended they should be, the wording is such that they could be. But that matter is inconsequential to the real substance of it, that is, what are we going to do to control ourselves in the way we store information on citizens? We are quick to say in this place what everyone else should do about protecting information on individuals that is collected by other people. I have heard very little raised in this place about what should be done to protect the information that we collect on individuals; I regard this as a very serious matter.

In conclusion, before I ask the Minister to respond, I say that I understand the difficulty in seeking to apply privacy legislation to members of parliament and, as the Act reads at the moment, I would not want to apply the whole Act to every aspect of the activities of a member of parliament, not the least of which would be constituent inquiries.

I raise as an example that I may write to the Minister in some capacity about a constituent and he may provide me with information that he may or may not be prepared to provide to the constituent. But if, by virtue of some legislation, the constituent is able to dip into my files, then the Minister is going to be apprehensive about what information he provides to senators and members. That is going to be a bad thing for everyone in terms of the representations we can make to Ministers of whatever government and the replies that we can get.That is not what I am talking about and I think that because the Minister has been at the Estimates Committee hearings, he knows that my concern is about the storage of information for electoral purposes, all of which might be quite innocently given and quite innocently used. But that is true of everyone else who collects information as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senate Vanstone has raised a matter of considerable importance, that is, the issue of the use by members of parliament of computing equipment supplied by the Department of Administrative Services for use in their electoral offices. It can be put to the sorts of tasks which Senator Vanstone outlined, such as setting up a profile of the electorate and getting quite considerable banks of information in response to telephone surveys of particular members of the electorate.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, Senator Vanstone was provided with certain legal opinions which indicated that the Privacy Commissioner, at least, does not judge that the sort of record-keeping practice of members of parliament, based on that poll file type activity, falls within the Privacy Act principles. But I think that the Commissioner has also indicated that he certainly has the capacity under the Act to encourage voluntary compliance with those principles.

As we know, there is a very important committee called the Privacy Advisory Committee. It comprises the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Skehill, who is a Deputy Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department; a high-ranking officer of the Department of Social Security; a member from the ACTU; a member from the Civil Liberties Council in Victoria; and a member from the legal centre at Redfern or perhaps the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney; and a data processing expert.

At the request, I think, of the Privacy Commissioner, that Committee will look particularly at this matter at its next meeting. So it is on the agenda; it is being considered. As I understand it, the Privacy Commissioner either before, or certainly on the basis of, the discussion at that meeting, intends to write to the Presiding Officers of the Parliament—that is, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives—in order to advance this idea that there might be voluntary compliance with the privacy principles.

The honourable senator has pointed out some limitations that might be necessary if we, as parliamentarians, are to give proper service to constituents in dealing with government—whether Ministers, various departments or agencies of government. Out of discussions with the Privacy Commissioner, his advisory committee and the Presiding Officers, we might expect to get a move in the direction in which the honourable senator is suggesting and advocating whereby parliamentarians, if not bound legally, subject themselves to a regime which is consistent with the privacy principles, at least in so far as they collect information from members of their electorates in the way that the honourable senator has described.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to two general matters which relate to one of my reservations—the fifth reservation entitled `Program Performance Statements and Social Justice Issues' on the blue page after page 5 of the Committee's general report. This matter is also mentioned in the second paragraph of my letter. The program performance statements on page 14 raise social justice matters.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister may remember, these matters were referred to during our examination of the estimates. One of the questions was: if the Government is so interested in social justice issues, what is it doing about making access to justice more available to those to whom it is currently not available? I think I raised the example of Mr Romeyko's do-it-yourself divorce kit. I asked why the Department was not doing more in this area. The officers—Mr Rose et al—pointed out that a lot of these are not matters of Federal law, and I understand that. But to the extent to which they are Federal law, what is the Attorney-General's Department doing about producing—in any languages it chooses as being appropriate because of our multicultural approach, which I endorse—leaflets which explain to people what their rights are and how they can access them themselves without going to the legal profession?

At the Committee hearing this was not seen as being the problem of the Attorney-General's Department. But I think it is the Department's problem. Too many Australians simply cannot afford to use lawyers. To the extent that the Attorney-General's Department and a committee of this chamber cannot fix that problem, we have to do other things to ameliorate it. One of the things we can do is explain to people the circumstances under which they do not need a lawyer; the circumstances under which they can do it themselves. We can do that by making those circumstances clear to them and outlining in very simple language the procedures that need to be undertaken.

What is being done in that respect at the moment? If nothing is being done—or even if something is being done—can the Department do more to encourage people not to take the law into their own hands in that negative sense but to use their power to act as individuals without getting legal advice which they cannot afford?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The range of activities undertaken by the Department of the Attorney-General and the various portfolio agencies does not, in many instances, lend itself to the sort of assistance which would enable what one might call ordinary members of the community to pursue their ordinary legal rights—and I am putting aside the family law area for a moment.

PARA.TAB: An exception to that would be in the area of consumer affairs where I have taken great pains over the last year or so to have information made available in community languages in the media—whether it be in written publications, radio slots or, in some instances, on SBS television. I have tried to acquaint various major ethnic groups, and some smaller ones, of their rights as consumers and the way in which they might, using consumer affairs officers at either the Federal or State level, assert those rights if necessary. But, basically, I wanted to make them aware of their rights. Quite often there are cultural impediments to their understanding that, indeed, they do have rights and that they might assert them without great fear or trepidation in our sort of community.

To that extent, I have certainly launched campaigns involving Greek, Spanish, Vietnamese and the Chinese speaking communities and two or three other major language groups in Sydney and Melbourne informing them of their rights. We have received very considerable coverage in the various ethnic press and radio outlets. I believe that this has been, at least in part, effective. So there has been some attempt.

So far as the family law area is concerned, the Family Court itself has been attempting, through various programs, to reduce the costs consequent upon the breakdown of marriage. I could mention some which at least reduce the exposure of an unfortunate couple to the legal system; certainly, they try to avoid protracted litigation which is such a burdensome and crippling cost, on top of the disastrous consequences of separation as to property and other matters. The use of a system in the Family Court which bypasses, in a timely fashion, judicial determination of the dispute between the parties is to be encouraged.

As the honourable senator would know, a certain amount of conciliation goes on in the court. But of more interest is the fact that a pilot mediation program, using mediation-trained counsellors and registrars to complement the conciliation services provided to litigants and potential litigants, has commenced at, I think, Dandenong and Parramatta. It will be interesting to see how that might assist in reducing the costs of traumatic breakdown.

I believe that the joint working party on costs, which was established in 1990 at the initiative of the Chief Justice, and people from the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, the Attorney-General's Department and the Law Council of Australia, are providing some assistance in terms of the honourable senator's objectives. So various things are being done. I could perhaps table a paper on initiatives to reduce the cost of justice, provided by the Principal Registrar of the Family Court of Australia. This might be of assistance to the honourable senator in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I will read that with interest. I understand from Estimates committee hearings and other places the interest the Chief Justice of the Family Court has in reducing what is loosely termed the cost of justice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I now have some supplementary information. I have just received some other notes from officers that some legal aid commissions do provide do-it-yourself divorce kits and classes. They enable people to come to a group meeting to learn about the process and procedures. So that is one instance precisely relating to the point Senator Vanstone is raising. I understand that the Administrative Review Council multicultural agenda project is on access by ethnic groups to various appeal rights within the administrative review system. So work is also being done there.

—I am pleased to hear it. I certainly do not regard the role of the Department as being the enemy of the legal profession and, therefore, that its role should be trying to take work from the profession. Nor do I think the Attorney-General's Department should see itself as the protector of the profession and, in that sense, necessarily as the benign enemy of the public. It should be doing everything it can to see that people who cannot afford the whim of a solicitor can access the system without it. To those who can afford a solicitor, irrespective of whether they need it, half their luck.

PARA.TAB: I would be pleased to see if the Minister could see his way clear to agreeing that every annual report issued under the auspices of the Department—that is, under which the Minister has some control—in future has in it a heading `Cost of Justice' or `Access to Justice' and that it lists what that agency or section of his Department has done in the preceding year to turn its mind to this matter. It may not be that the Department as a whole will be producing do-it-yourself divorce kits or whatever—there is a very useful place for that—but there is also a place for the AAT, the High Court of Australia, the Federal Court of Australia, the Family Court of Australia and anyone else who comes under the Minister's wing to be required annually in their reports to say what they have done about these matters.

Last but not least—I do not ask this as a question but really offer it as a request to be taken into account for the next Estimates hearings—I would like some further explanation of why we are continuing with the reversal to pleadings in the Family Court. Since the Estimates Committee E hearings, I have been back to the practitioners I know. They make not very complimentary remarks about what I told them I was told, which was that the legal profession had agreed to a reversal to pleadings and that it agreed it would reduce the cost of justice. The Minister will remember that we were told that some practitioners would put in 30- to 40-page inflammatory affidavits and that pleadings were introduced to stop that and therefore reduce the cost. These inflammatory affidavits set off a snowball that could never be stopped. I understand that.

But most of the professions say that most of them were not doing that. None of them says that it ever agreed that a return to pleadings would reduce the cost of justice. They all agreed that it is paying for better private schools for their children than they ever imagined they would be able to afford. They wonder why we are continuing with it. I leave that matter until the next Estimates Committee, unless the Minister would like to say something about the return to pleadings issue which has been a disaster. Finally, will the Minister agree that every annual report produced under the auspices of the Department, so far as the Minister or his Department can direct them, makes a reference each year from here on in—until we are all happy that the cost of justice is what it should be—to what that body is doing to reduce the cost of justice?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I will comment on the first matter raised by Senator Vanstone. We will leave it to the next Estimates Committee, but we are now forewarned. I agree to pursue the other matter and to hold discussions with the Attorney and the Secretary of the Department to see what is possible in relation to Senator Vanstone's suggestion. I do not undertake that that will occur in the next batch of annual reports, but it is a worthwhile consideration which could well be incorporated in the reports of the Department and various agencies and courts.

—I thank the Minister. I understand that Senator Macdonald now has some questions. I say in response to the Minister that it will be interesting to hear which bodies the Attorney-General's Department is responsible for are prepared to say that there is nothing they can say each year about what they are prepared to contribute to reducing the cost of justice. That list will be very interesting.

—I have one very small question about subprogram 2.2. I also have questions about subprogram 3.4. That is all I intend covering. I know that Senator Harradine has some questions on programs about which he has reservations, as does Senator Colston. Senator Vanstone will also ask more questions. Are we doing these in order as we go through?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—I have a list in front of me and it would be preferable if we stuck to it so that other senators might know what is going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just trying to help you, Mr Temporary Chairman, and other senators who might be getting ready to speak, to understand what is happening by announcing what I intend to do. In respect of subprogram 2.2, my only question is to ask the Minister whether he or his advisers have any current report on how the investigations are going.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The current position is that investigations are under way. It is a priority of the Australian Securities Commission that requires a variety of interviews and the collection of documentation. It is not expected that the investigation will be completed until after December 1991. This has been exacerbated mainly by the fact that witnesses are spread all over the place. But it is hoped that at least one brief will be available by 31 December 1991; that date has been aimed at. I will not go into the details on the public record but, if Senator Macdonald wished, I could indicate what that brief might be about. That is the process under way at the moment.

PARA.TAB: It may be that some other briefs will not be completed until March 1992. If it proves that that timetable is able to be modified in some way, I will let Senator Macdonald know. I will instruct officers to keep him informed as to whether that timetable looks like changing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say for the Hansard record—because neither I nor Senator Tate mentioned it—that the investigation I am talking about is the Australian Securities Commission investigation into the Ravenshoe mill payments, about which I made a reservation.

PARA.TAB: I thank the Minister for what he has just reported. I had some correspondence with the Securities Commission in relation to a matter that came up where the Commission indicated—I think it was in Estimates—that it would assist the creditors to pursue the directors if its investigations revealed that the directors of APS mills were liable in law to creditors. The Australian Securities Commission indicated that it would assist those creditors in pursuing whatever remedies they may have. As a result of that, I wrote to the Commission asking what the creditors needed to do to make the Commission aware. The Commission replied by giving me a phone number, which I have passed on to most of the creditors.

I had a meeting with some of the creditors in Ravenshoe during the last break. Some of them said that they had telephoned the Commission but that the Commission had not seemed terribly interested in their debts. I did tell the rest of them to continue to make the Commission aware of those debts so that the Commission would have full and factual details. I do not think that I necessarily need a response from the Minister on those points. I simply put that information on the record. It may well be passed on to the Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond in the sense that, given the fact that these contacts were made after a submission and representation on their behalf by a senator, I would be disappointed if a more forthcoming response were not experienced by those who did make contact. But it may be that those who made contact understood the necessary reticence in relation to legal proprieties for a lack of enthusiasm for their plight. Nevertheless, I believe that Mr Robinson and the statutory members have been dealing with these matters. It may be that officers could contact him tomorrow morning to ensure that those who are dealing with inquiries on this matter are dealt with in a way that gives some indication—which I believe to be the case—that the ASC regards this matter as a priority.

—I do not want the Minister to take what I have said in the wrong way. I am not making a complaint. The people I am dealing with are not people who are at all skilled in this respect. It was just that it was reported to me that it was not Mr Robinson who was dealing with their claims. It was reported to me that it was a junior investigator. It may be that the investigators may need to explain themselves a bit better when talking to these people.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—We come to subprogram 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —My reservation relates to discrimination in industrial matters. The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) will remember that in the Estimates Committee questions were raised about one's right to join a union or not to join a union. As I recall, it was clearly established that one has a right not to do so if one does not wish to do so. I was a little apprehensive about this being so gleefully agreed to because for so many Australians that does not appear to be the case. For many Australians the workplace that they enter has a sign reading `No ticket, no start'.

PARA.TAB: If it is true that I have the freedom to associate, which can mean nothing if I do not have the freedom not to do so, I raise the question as to what the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is doing about informing people of their rights in this area. I know a number of areas in which it has prepared leaflets in any number of languages to tell people their rights. I was interested in what the Commission has done in this area. As I recall, not much was being done. Can the Minister highlight what assistance the Commission can be in the case of a person who goes to it and says, `I have the freedom to associate and, therefore, the freedom not to. I have been refused a job solely because I refused to join a union, and that is the only reason I have been refused a job. What will you do to help me in this matter of discrimination against me?' That is a question to which I would appreciate the Minister's answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a lot of information. It appears that 26 complaints on the grounds of trade union activity have been received by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission since that ground was declared by regulation under ILO convention 111 in January 1990. I believe that that has been signified to the Committee secretariat. There have been 26 complaints on the grounds of trade union activity since that time. I understand that a brochure has been produced by the Commission. Unfortunately, I do not have a copy of it in my brief but this is certainly an active area so far as the Commission is concerned.

PARA.TAB: It is also clear from an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that non-membership of a union is included within the term `trade union activity'. I believe that gives scope for the sort of exercise of the functions of the Commission which Senator Vanstone is seeking to investigate, but I do not know anything about the 26 particular cases. Clearly, some of them might comprehend that particular aspect of the ground of trade union activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek the details as to any of those matters; I do not have any knowledge of any one of them. However, I am interested in the leaflet that has been prepared, and I am sorry that the Minister does not have a copy of it.
—Have you got a copy?
—No.
—We will supply you with one.

—I thank the Minister. I am sorry that that will probably be after my opportunity to question the Minister about these matters has passed. Nonetheless, April will come around and we will meet again on perhaps not such a sunny day.

PARA.TAB: I am interested in knowing how many leaflets have been prepared, where they have been distributed, in how many languages they have been prepared and the print run of that leaflet compared with the print runs of other leaflets informing people of their rights. Although a leaflet might have been prepared in relation to the ILO convention, what aspect of the leaflet deals with the right not to join a union? Is it quite explicit or is it just skirted around? That is why the presence of a leaflet would make this discussion a lot more helpful.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, as I do not have a copy of the leaflet with me, I cannot answer Senator Vanstone's question. I will undertake to provide the answers as to the numbers, the distribution and the contents of the leaflet. Perhaps I could do so after Question Time tomorrow or something like that. I am quite happy to put the answers on the record earlier than next April.

—I would be happy with that. If I understand the Minister correctly, he agrees that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission accepts that people who believe that they are discriminated against because they are not prepared to join a union, have a case which the Commission will have some interest in on their behalf. If that is the case, as a consequence of an ILO convention, does the Government accept that one need not join a union if one does not want to? Is that government policy carried out in the Public Service and in every government business enterprise and, if not, why not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I would be trespassing well outside my field if I were to answer the consequential results of the application in the terms that I have indicated of ILO convention 111. But it is a fact that the Attorney-General's Department has informed the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that the addition of the grounds of trade union activity to its jurisdiction embraces the matter of non-membership of a union. In fact, from the point of view of this portfolio, the question of non-membership of a union is comprehended within the jurisdiction of the Commission. What flows from that in regard to the employment policy of the Commonwealth is a matter which I would defer to other portfolios. I suggest Senator Vanstone seeks advice from them.

—I will do that at the earliest opportunity, but I wonder why the Attorney-General's portfolio felt comfortable in making the pronouncements that it did on equal opportunity and the way in which it saw its role in advancing that area of development in our industrial relations scenario, yet does not see a role for itself in advancing this area of development in the industrial relations scenario. What is the difference between the two? Am I being discriminated against because of my sex or because of my choice not to join a union? To me they are the same thing. I have been discriminated against. If the Minister's Department is against discrimination as defined by various bodies, including the ILO, why is the Minister not prepared to take up this cause in the way in which he is prepared to take up others?

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I may add another question to save getting to my feet later to ask extra questions. Would the Minister indicate those permanent staff members of the Attorney-General's Department who are not members of a union and what is the practice of that Department? Can someone join the Attorney-General's Department at all levels, not just at the senior ones, and not join a union? How many people are there in that position? I suspect that it will relate to how many women there are above that glass ceiling in the Department that really is not there, but which everyone can see when we go to Estimates Committee and there are no women sitting behind the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no requirement, if one is an officer of the Attorney-General's Department, to be a member of a union. As I understand it, no question is asked about membership of a union, so the figures are not compiled. It is not a matter of concern to the management of the Attorney-General's Department whether a person is a member of a relevant union.
—So they could all resign tomorrow and you would be in no trouble?
—I certainly would not be in any trouble.
—The Department would be.

—The Department would not be in any trouble because it is not the policy of the Department to require officers of the Department to be members of any relevant union. I can see that that has taken the honourable senator by surprise and has shocked her, but that is the fact, I am told.
—Let's try it on. Let's advertise the fact that you can join Attorney-General's and not join a union.

—I am sure it is one of the attractions. As for the role of the Attorney-General's portfolio in this matter, we have made it our policy to support the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We have offered an opinion which indicates that it ought not to take a restrictive view of the meaning of trade union activity. We believe that that is supportive of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in continuing its very important role in Australian society. I believe that the Attorney-General's Department has discharged its role very admirably in regard to its support for the very existence of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which honourable senators will recall the Opposition wished to destroy as recently as a year or so ago, and in ensuring that its jurisdiction embraces trade union activity by adoption of the additional ground flowing from ILO convention 111.

—I feel that we are skating on thin ice here, and I say that as a member of a trade union for nigh on 40 years and as an original member of the committees established under ILO convention 111. I should very much like to have a copy of the legal opinion of the Attorney-General's Department to which the Minister referred. When the Minister talks about freedom of association, to which provision of ILO convention 111 is he referring, or is he referring to a previous international instrument? Further, in looking at the historical aspects of this question, would the Minister and the Attorney-General's Department examine the submissions that were made to the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations, of which I was Chairman?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers with me are not able to provide a full answer to Senator Harradine in respect of the extension of the jurisdiction of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I believed that it lay in ILO convention 111; but, at Senator Harradine's suggestion, obviously that would need to be checked and verified in case the extension of the jurisdiction of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission does depend on what the honourable senator called a previous international instrument. That can be checked out by talking to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or to departmental officers sometime shortly.

PARA.TAB: As to the provision of the legal advice from the Department to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, I see no difficulty in that being provided to Senator Harradine. We will check it with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It was provided to the Commission, but I do not see any difficulty. I am sure that will be provided. As to a perusal of the Committee's report, or the proceedings—

TALK.START.PARA: —The submissions made.
—Yes, as to the submissions made to the Committee that Senator Harradine chaired that might be relevant, I am sure that will also be a matter of interest to the Department.

—My remarks now are not directed to those employees who, because of conscientious objection to membership of a trade union, are given an exemption from joining a trade union. The Minister will understand the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act in respect of that matter and the provisions of the various State and Commonwealth industrial tribunals in respect of that matter. Is it being suggested by the Attorney-General's Department to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that certain provisions of Federal or State awards that give preference to union members in respect of certain conditions of service are invalid?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers with me are uncertain as to their capacity to give a definitive answer to Senator Harradine in respect of that question; therefore I think it would be safest to take it on notice. It is really asking a very fundamental question, which I guess amounts almost to a legal opinion. I think that question ought to be taken on notice and proper consideration given to it. A response will be provided to Senator Harradine and to the chamber.
—I am sorry, Minister, I have been moving around the chamber discussing other matters with other people. Have you just agreed to give us the opinion?

—Yes. I want to qualify that. The Department supplied the opinion to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, so I will have to ask the Commission, but I cannot imagine that there would be any difficulty.
—If the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission refuses, will you then agree to ask your Department for an opinion on the matter to be provided to the chamber?
—I think it is the same thing.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—As there are no other matters on subprogram 3.2, we will return to subprogram 3.1.

TALK.START.PARA: —Referring to page 104 of the additional information received by Estimates Committee E volume 1 as tabled in the Senate by the Chairman of that Committee, I asked a question on notice of the Attorney-General's Department relating to CEDAW and the CEDAW Monitoring Committee which asked Ireland questions relating to abortion.

PARA.TAB: Incidentally, I preface my further question by indicating that is not only contrary to the provisions of the convention but also an insult to Ireland. Recently, I was part of a delegation to Ireland and I took the opportunity of visiting the chief health statistician to examine some of the health statistics in that country. I am aware that some proponents of abortion suggest that abortion is a necessary health measure for women, particularly women who may have larger families.

It was interesting to observe that the maternal and child health statistics in Ireland are amongst the best, if not the best, in the world. Of course, there are no abortion facilities in Ireland. I preface my question to the Minister —and it is a very serious question—by making that point because it is fresh in my memory: I was there the month before last. My question to the Minister is: where in the Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women or in the travaux preparatoires is the word `abortion' used, let alone any provision which would give to a monitoring committee the right to quiz member states as to their provision of abortion facilities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, it is not for me particularly to defend the way in which CEDAW interprets its charter or operates in fact. It is an independent body which is not subject to direction, as I understand it, by states parties and certainly not by Australia. An interpretation which it gives to its charter is a matter for it and if states parties were totally unhappy with its particular interpretation they could withdraw from the convention. I say that as a preliminary. In other words, I do not think I should stand here as defence counsel for CEDAW. I am not assuming that role.

PARA.TAB: However, I do understand that the request for information on abortion laws was made by CEDAW to all states parties. I do not think Ireland was singled out or discriminated against. The brief which I believe was provided to the Committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee requests all States Parties reporting to it, pursuant to Article 18 of the Convention, to provide information concerning the "legal regulation regarding abortion, its legality and enforcement of the law".

Guidelines have been issued as to the types of information the Committee wants to receive and these are set out in the Manual on Human Rights Reporting, Under Six Major International Human Rights instruments.
The briefing note then goes on:
The Committee requests the information on abortion laws in regard to Article 12 of the Convention which provides:

"1.States Parties shall take all appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against women in the field of health care in order to ensure a basis of equality of men and women, access to health care services, including those relating to family planning.

2.Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 1 of this Article, States Parties shall assure women appropriate services in connection with pregnancy, confinement and the post-natal period, granting free services where necessary, as well as adequate nutrition during pregnancy and lactation.

As I understand it, that is the article in the convention on which the Committee relies in asking states parties to provide information regarding the legal regulation pertaining to abortion, its legality and enforcement of the law. However, I would agree with Senator Harradine that the term `abortion' does not appear and, in so far as that request is made in reliance on article 12, that is a matter for CEDAW to defend if states parties refuse to acknowledge that was a legitimate inquiry based on that article.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it a fact that the Attorney-General's Department is the relevant department giving advice in respect of CEDAW and other conventions dealing with international human rights instruments?
—Yes, that is right.

—Therefore I come back to the question because it is relevant to the Department whose Minister you represent here today: does the Department consider that article 12 provides the opportunity for the CEDAW Monitoring Committee to request information from member states or reporting states in respect of their abortion facilities?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the Department has given a formal opinion on this matter. However, my briefing notes say that article 12 of CEDAW deals with issues of women's health. A nation's policies and practices concerning abortion may well be relevant to women's health. That is as far as the Department is prepared to go. It also says that the questions about the legal regulation and incidence of abortion do not necessarily imply or endorse any one view as to the merits of abortion. They seek information as to an operation in the reporting states parties' territory which, whether common or rare, legal or illegal, has potential implications for the health of women in that state party. I believe that is as far as the Department is prepared to say the CEDAW committee is properly asking those sorts of questions.

—There are two questions that arise from that answer. The first relates to the question of women's health per se. Firstly, is the Minister suggesting that the monitoring committee of the Convention to Eliminate Discrimination Against Women is able to ask that question? Secondly, I refer the Minister to the article which his Department referred him to which says that states parties shall take all appropriate measures to eliminate discrimination against women in the field of health care in order to ensure on a basis of equality of men and women access to health care services, including those relating to family planning. It talks about discrimination between men and women. It is the first time that I have had it inferred here or anywhere else that a man can get an abortion. Would the Minister please answer the question?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Article 12 has more to say than simply paragraph 1 obviously; it also has paragraph 2 within it. Within that is contained a question of services in connection with pregnancy. It is in relation to that particular health service that the question of the appropriateness of questions simply seeking information about the provision or the incidence of abortion within a society have relevance. It is not to say that abortion is to be promoted, extolled or indicated as an appropriate or desirable service in connection with pregnancy or anything to do with a woman who has conceived a genetically new human life. It is in connection with the whole of article 12 that the Department believes that CEDAW is able to indicate a relevance of the question relating to the provision of abortion in a society to its charter in article 12 of the convention.

—Is the Minister therefore saying that the Department excludes paragraph 1 of clause 12 as being a provision upon which the CEDAW monitoring committee can rely in asking questions of member States on abortion?

—I do not know that I am particularly well qualified to say that one can read article 12 in such a disjointed way. The whole of the article needs to be taken into account. The way in which the CEDAW committee has regarded its capacity to ask the sorts of questions it has on abortion laws is based on its understanding of the whole effect of article 12. However, I would not wish to indicate that it should be split into two on this matter.

—Is the Minister suggesting that the questioning by CEDAW and the development of a body of information and practice has no relevance in international law and, therefore, is of no consequence to either the Government or the Department?

—I am not saying that. I am simply saying that the question of the sorts of inquiries which CEDAW might make on the basis of its understanding of the convention is not so evidently completely without foundation in the convention that the Department believes that there can be no possible basis for the sorts of questions which are put to states parties in regard to the legal regulation regarding abortion, its legality and enforcement of the law.

PARA.TAB: It is not to say that that question would be put by this Government if it were constituted as the sole monitoring committee and it formulated the questions that might be appropriate to an examination of whether States' parties have complied with the articles of the convention.

This Government is simply saying that, in so far as CEDAW has asked that question, it appears to be able to be given a base in article 12. But we reiterate that the committee makes these determinations on the questions it asks as an independent body with a mandate under the convention and not, for example, by way of direction by the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said that it is not for him to defend the actions of the CEDAW Monitoring Committee. He repeated that the committee makes its own decisions about these matters. I ask the Minister quite seriously: is that not of considerable significance when it comes to the development of international law? Does the Department not know of the Vienna Convention and particularly article 31(3)? Could the Minister advise the Committee of the Whole of the implications thereof?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have article 31(3) of the convention in front of me. If Senator Harradine wishes to acquaint the Committee with the terms of 31(3), we will see whether we can respond. For the purposes of Hansard, I ought to say that this has been a matter of continuing discussion over many Estimates Committee hearings between me and Senator Harradine. I have tried to respond as fully as is possible in every instance, but I regret that I do not have the convention with me this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is why it is so important. I would have thought that the Department would have people here who would know the information I am seeking. I gave notice of this matter. I said that I made a reservation to the Committee's report on only two matters—this and another one. If the Department does not have the particular officer here, I cannot be blamed, nor can the Committee be blamed. It is a very important matter. I will have to take the time of the Committee to explain to the Minister what the situation might be.

PARA.TAB: Article 31 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties is quite relevant because a committee's interpretation could result in actions by states relevant to the interpretation of the convention. I shall give the background for saying this. As the Minister has said in his reply, as a treaty organ established under article 17 of the CEDAW Convention, the CEDAW Monitoring Committee is competent to interpret the convention so far as is necessary for the performance of its functions. As the Minister has said, under article 18 of the convention, it seeks information from states parties concerning the legal regulation regarding abortion, its legality and enforcement of the law.

Ultimately, however, the interpretation of the convention remains the prerogative of states. The committee's interpretation is undoubtedly capable of affecting states' reporting requirements and their internal and external practices. Moreover, whilst the committee's interpretation is not binding per se on the states, over time it may establish and reflect the agreement of parties concerning its interpretation. It follows, therefore, that a committee's interpretation could result in action by states relevant to the interpretation of the convention.
Article 31(3) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties is relevant in that it provides in relation to the interpretation of a treaty:

SPEECH.PARA: There shall be taken into account, together with the content:
(a)any subsequent agreement between the parties regarding the interpretation of the treaty or the application of its provisions;
(b)any subsequent practice in the application of the treaty which establishes the agreement of the parties regarding its interpretation;
(c)any relevant rules of international law applicable in the relations between the parties.

From that, it is quite evident that the interpretation made by the CEDAW Monitoring Committee in relation to this article could have a quite significant effect on the question of abortion world wide. If it is suggested that clause 1 or clause 2 of article 12 is appropriate to be used by the CEDAW Monitoring Committee so as to enable it to demand of reporting states the situation as to abortion facilities in those states, the Department and this Government are either saying that abortion is a legitimate form of family planning or that they do not care what the CEDAW Monitoring Committee does.

PARA.TAB: This is important not only for this particular convention but also for all those other conventions, the articles of which enable the establishment of a monitoring committee that can wander throughout the world seeking and demanding information from various member countries and ratifying countries, thus building up a body of interpretation and law which will go into the international body of law and be pointed to in court cases in various countries throughout the world.
