Quite clearly, this is an international monitoring organisation, not elected by the people of the various ratifying counties, unelected, not answerable to the various governments, wandering around the world establishing a body of interpretation that ultimately can be used within those countries and pointed to in those countries to establish a particular practice—this without reference to the electors to whom we all have to go, to whom we all are answerable.

This is a very serious and important question for abortion. It is also very important for a number of other conventions, the articles of which enable a monitoring committee to be established. I do want and do require from the Government and from the Department their view of article 12. Does the Department say that article 12 is an appropriate article which should be used by the monitoring committee to ask ratifying countries questions about their abortion facilities? That is what I want to know. Do the Department and the Government say that this provision in the CEDAW Convention is appropriate and should be used by the monitoring committee for that purpose? If they do, will they please tell me where in the convention, where in the travaux preparatoires—the aids to the interpretation of international law—the word `abortion' is used and under what circumstances?
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m, I put the question:
That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long are we going on for? This is news to me.
—I am not in possession of that information.

—I would have liked to have been informed. I had heard that there was a possibility of the motion being negatived, but only if we had gone through a fair degree of a particular Estimates committee, and we have only just started this Estimates committee.
—I understand that it is intended that we continue for a while.
—Until when?
—I simply cannot tell you, Senator Harradine.
—I would like somebody to tell us.
—Is there anybody who can tell us? Have any decisions been made?

—I cannot exactly tell the Committee a time. It is very difficult in this place to estimate times in relation to debates. We are on the Attorney-General's Department and we will try to do the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and finish at that.
—That is not on. We will be here until 2 o'clock in the morning.
—That is the proposal at this stage. We can review it at a later stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already indicated to Senator Harradine that, so far as I am aware, the convention does not contain the term `abortion'. (Quorum formed) I have tried to indicate to Senator Harradine that the term `abortion' does not occur in the convention or, so far as I am aware, in the travaux preparatoires relating to the initial phases of negotiation and deliberations on the final document.

PARA.TAB: The Department is of the view that for the monitoring committee to seek information and to ask questions about the provision of abortion within a particular state party is not precluded by the form of article 12 and can be sufficiently based in it. I have also indicated that that is a question that might not be asked by other monitoring committees, or by this Government if it were the monitoring committee. I am simply saying that it is open to the monitoring committee, in the opinion of the AG's Department, to ask that question.

Senator Harradine's comments about his concerns about the approach of CEDAW on this matter asking states parties questions about abortion, based on the language of article 12, and how that might spill over into an interpretation of other international conventions and treaties which adopt the same language, remind me of the discussion that we had in November of last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the rights of the child, yes.

—Exactly. I think I made the distinction then which I am making now. It was suggested by Senator Harradine saying that the activity of CEDAW was promoting abortion and that he wanted to guard against an interpretation of like provisions in the Convention on the Rights of the Child that no promotion of abortion would take place. I indicate that if, indeed, CEDAW moved to the promotion or advocacy of abortion, that would be a different question, properly posed, in relation to whether that could be based on the convention. In simply seeking information about the provision of that particular operation within a state party's jurisdiction—presumably in relation to reports submitted by the state party for consideration by CEDAW, although I am not absolutely sure of the exact process—I believe that the interpretation of the Department is reasonable.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Harradine that if the interpretation put by CEDAW led it, for example, in its report on a particular state party or in some general report, to promote or advocate abortion, we would be facing a completely different inquiry as to how that could be properly based in the convention which the committee was established to monitor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the documents with me because I did not realise that this debate was coming on tonight—if I had been given the chance, through the decency to adjourn at the right time, I would have had them tomorrow—but I assert that the CEDAW Monitoring Committee is doing precisely that. Would the Minister agree that the CEDAW Monitoring Committee should question a particular country as to its law requiring two doctors, rather than one, to certify that abortion was indicated? Would that not be regarded as an attempt to liberalise abortion facilities in that country? If this were the development of an international body of interpretation of the law, would that be appropriate?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have indicated that, so far as the Department is aware, what the CEDAW committee has sought in relation to the provision of abortion in this society is information relating to the incidence of that particular operation in the jurisdiction of the state party concerned. My answers have been based on that premise of seeking information. If the committee is going beyond that—into promotion or advocacy of a particular regime in relation to the provision of abortion services or operations within a state party's jurisdiction—that would raise a different question. As I have indicated, that would have to be more clearly founded in, for example, article 12 than I have considered it to be.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of whether any particular very precise question put to a state party could be interpreted as advocating a particular course of action or a particular way in which laws should be framed to allow for abortion to occur, I would obviously have to look at the instance concerned. But I assume that it is open to a state party to say in respect of a question that is posed that it is ultra vires or beyond the limits of the jurisdiction of the CEDAW committee and that it will not provide that particular information. That would not entirely deal with Senator Harradine's point but, nevertheless, the question has been asked by the committee. I believe that the answers I have given, both now and back in November last year, are directed only to the seeking of information-type activity by CEDAW and not promotion or advocacy of any particular regime relating to abortion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has indicated that a country could refuse to provide information to the monitoring committee. On page 105 of the document to which I previously referred, the Department gives a response that indicates that the committee requested that the state reporting should provide a list of information. The second paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: Reports should further include information on the legal regulation regarding abortion, its legality and the enforcement of the law, including any sanctions imposed, and any court cases registered in this regard. Reports should indicate how many abortions are performed annually in the reporting State, legally or otherwise, and under what conditions, and what the country's policy is on this matter.

The Minister has said that a state party to the convention could refuse to answer that question. I ask the Minister what the attitude of Australia is in respect of those questions. Does Australia refuse to provide that information? And if not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Australia's first report to the committee complied with the reporting guidelines of the committee. All I can say is that that leads to an inference that if that question were put to Australia, it was answered. I do not have Australia's report with me. I can obviously check on that.

—I have. It even reports on the State of Tasmania. The Government and the Attorney-General's Department are responsible for this. The report bemoans the fact that nearly all women wanting a termination in the State of Tasmania have to travel interstate. That is what this Government, under the Attorney-General's Department interpretation, is saying to the CEDAW Monitoring Committee. A further supplement to the report dated November 1987 says this about Tasmania:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative provisions outlined at page 121 of the CEDAW report are still current. However, the reference on page 122 that "nearly all women wanting a termination (in Tasmania) have to travel interstate" is no longer correct.

I come back to the clear question that I asked before. We are told in the response that article 12 of the convention is the basis for that question. What provision in article 12 does that refer to? Do the Government and the Department require the CEDAW Monitoring Committee to ask questions of reporting states on abortion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going around in endless circles. I have never said that the provisions of the convention require the CEDAW Monitoring Committee to ask those questions. I have simply said that it is not precluded from asking those questions. I have in fact specifically said that others may not ask those questions; that they may not feel the necessity to, or feel compelled or required—to use Senator Harradine's terminology—to ask those questions. But in so far as it is possible to ask a question relating to a request for a description of the provision of abortion in a state party's jurisdiction—and I did distinguish between promotion and advocacy in respect of a simple description—I indicated that that would require much more consideration.

—The Minister has said that the CEDAW Monitoring Committee is not required by virtue of article 12 to ask the types of questions to which I refer. Does that mean, therefore, that the Department and the Government consider that the provision of article 12 does not require the monitoring CEDAW Committee so to do?

—I tried to indicate that I do not believe that there is any compulsion on the committee to ask for a description of the provision of abortion services in the jurisdiction of a state party, but I believe that it is open to the committee to ask for such a description and that is what has been the case.
—That is what I am asking. Why does the Minister believe that it is open to do so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is a possible interpretation of article 12 that when one talks about the provision, for example, of service in connection with pregnancy, in some instances—and those instances would be open to moral and legal definition—the provision of an abortion in a society could be properly described as a service in connection with pregnancy, for example, where the life of the woman was assessed by competent medical practitioners to be definitely threatened by the continuation of the pregnancy. If that were the case, that would be an instance where the definition in article 12 would allow for questions to be asked about the provision of abortion, but not to the stage of advocacy or promotion, which I am not addressing. I am simply dealing with the provision of information.

—Will the Minister therefore examine all of the records of the CEDAW Monitoring Committee in respect of the questions relating to this issue of all of the ratifying and reporting countries? I am asking him to do that in view of what I said before and the implications of article 31 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties. As indicated there, it is clearly possible for the types of interpretation of the treaty over a period of time to have quite considerable effect, to be relied upon, for example, in argument in court or various other forums. Therefore, I believe that it is important for the Minister, the Government and the Department to examine the reports of the committee and to give me a response in respect of those.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a huge task to undertake. I do not know how many reports from various states, parties to the convention, would be lodged with the monitoring committee per year—I do not know for how many years it has been operating, for that matter—but I presume that they are available in English in some United Nations repository, so I guess they can be obtained by the Australian Government.

PARA.TAB: As to an examination of them, I am not quite sure, but we will look at Hansard and see precisely what Senator Harradine wishes to proceed from that examination of all the reports. I do not know the exact logistics of doing that or whether it would be easy to do that in a short time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having regard to the statement that was made by the Minister that he—and generally the Government—would regard the CEDAW Monitoring Committee's questioning of reporting countries which had an inference of abortion advocacy as being beyond that monitoring committee's power, I point out again that there is a very similar provision in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Would it not be ironic if the development of interpretation of a provision very similar to the provision in the Convention on the Rights of the Child asked for information on abortion facilities in the various reporting countries? Would it not be ironic if the very similar provision in the Convention on the Rights of the Child were interpreted as being one where the CEDAW Monitoring Committee can go around the world asking questions in a manner of advocacy?

PARA.TAB: That is why I am asking the Minister to look at what the CEDAW Monitoring Committee is actually doing in this regard. Is it going around asking the ratifying countries questions about abortion facilities? Those questions could be interpreted as being a prod, as it were, to countries to establish abortion facilities where they are not established, or to liberalise them where they are established.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be ironic if the Convention on the Rights of the Child were interpreted in that way. I think we indicated in November last year—I cannot recall precisely, but I think Senator Harradine was concerned about article 24 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child—that nothing could be found in the article or in the travaux preparatoires which indicated that the question of abortion had been thought to be one which would be raised in that area. But we will take on board what Senator Harradine has asked. I have indicated that it is a very major project indeed and, in so far as resources can be devoted to it, that certainly will be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I have a couple of quick questions. The response that the Department gave to me says:

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the Committee are elected for a term of four years. The members of the Committee receive emoluments from the United Nations resources on such terms and conditions as decided by the General Assembly having regard to the importance of the Committee's responsibilities.
Is the member from Australia Justice Elizabeth Evatt?

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe she is; she certainly was when we last met.
—When receiving emoluments from the United Nations for her work on the CEDAW Monitoring Committee, does she take leave from her job as chairperson of the Law Reform Commission?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe I have answered that question on previous occasions. I do not have the question and answer in front of me, but I believe you have asked this—perhaps it was in November last year or even earlier this year—and answers were provided. I am reasonably confident about that; but we can provide the answer if we have not already done so.

—As I indicated previously, I have a couple of questions in relation to subprogram 3.4, `Provision of legal aid and family services'. They relate to the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council, about which I made a reservation. I have received some answers to questions that I raised at the Estimates Committee hearing, which were not available at that time. At the Estimates Committee hearing I was pursuing a line of questioning which had been raised with me by a constituent regarding the general allocation of funds for Queensland. I do not want to sound parochial, but this is the States House and because I represent Queensland I am concerned about the information that was given to me in writing to the questions that were taken on notice.

PARA.TAB: A certain amount of money is divided up between the States for marriage counselling in Australia. I want to pursue with the Minister the questions I raised at the Estimates Committee hearings. Relatively, Queensland seemed to be getting the raw end of the stick when it came to marriage guidance and marriage counselling. It was mentioned or agreed in the Estimates Committee that for every dollar spent on marriage counselling a further $7 was saved by the Australian taxpayer and the Australian public in the costs of divorces, problems with children and those sorts of things. The Minister did not agree with my figures, but he agreed in principle with the suggestion I was making.

The answers given to me in writing have shown—I pick a couple of items at random to emphasise my point—that Tasmania, for example, which has 2.66 per cent of the population, receives 4.1 per cent per capita of the total amount available. Tasmania receives $1.09 per capita for marriage counselling. By contrast, Queensland has 17.07 per cent of the population and only receives 13.8 per cent of the total amount available. Put another way, that means that Queensland receives 57c per capita.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not married to a Tasmanian.

—I take Senator Baume's point; maybe one would need a lot more if one were married to a Tasmanian. I simply emphasise that in Tasmania one receives $1.09 per capita for marriage guidance counselling and in Queensland one only gets 57c per capita. That is a fraction more than 50 per cent. I was wondering whether the Minister can explain why there is such a wide variance in the amount that Queenslanders receive compared with that received by Tasmanians. Is it that we in Queensland are less deserving or is it that we are better family people and we keep our marriages together better than in other parts of the country? Possibly the Minister might be able to give some explanation on the per capita division of the funds available for marriage counselling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I ought to indicate that the Commonwealth has had to deal with an historical base of counselling organisations and others providing services in the various States. I would not for one moment say that there is an absolutely equitable—if we talk in terms of per capita being the sole criterion—distribution of funds in this area around Australia. I believe that with regard to marriage counselling, if we look at family services as a whole—we now include marriage education, mediation services, parenting skills projects and so on—Queensland, whilst still not doing as well as other States, is not doing as badly as the figures indicated by Senator Macdonald might lead one to conclude.

PARA.TAB: Total family service grants from the Commonwealth in 1991-92 were $16.502m. It resulted in Queensland receiving 73c per capita against the average of 85c per capita in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. There is still a difference, in other words, but I believe that it is not as drastic as if one looked simply at the question of marriage counselling. It is true that there is a difference, and I do not deny that.

We have attempted to deal with the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council in a generous way. In the years 1989-90 to 1991-92 there was an increase in funding for that organisation for its various services, not just marriage counselling, from $842,800 to $1,242,900—an increase of $400,000 or about 47 1/2 per cent in its funding.

I cannot understand why occasionally, in letters not to me, the Marriage Guidance Council of Queensland keeps on criticising the Commonwealth. In fact, it is inconsistent with a letter I received from Mr Anthony Kelly, the President of the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council, on 15 August 1991, responding to my letter allocating more funds at its request. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your most responsive letter of 12 August. I am grateful to you for your decision to review funding decisions made in regard to this agency and for your acknowledgment that genuine misunderstandings have occurred. Your decision to make an additional $41,700 available to MGQ will most certainly relieve some of the immediate pressure on the agency.

The letter goes on to talk about what the staff are doing, trying to hold the line and avoid the withdrawal of any of its existing services. It remains the hope of the President that the agency can continue to build on strong growth, et cetera. It continues:

I do assure you that my executive committee is appreciative of your Government's increased commitment to marriage support services and that our desire is to work with you and your Department to provide the highest quality service to as many Queensland couples as we can reach.

While I share your express desire that past misunderstandings can be put to rest, it remains my own view that there is a need for government to articulate its policy on marriage support more clearly, both to the approved organisations and to the community as a whole. I shall look forward to the opportunity for further dialogue on these matters.

As far as I am concerned, that letter from Anthony Kelly is one to which I can respond in the same terms. I am very happy to continue dialogue with the providers of family services in Queensland, including Marriage Guidance Queensland, but on the basis of a recognition of good faith on both sides in our commitment to provide as much as we can in relation to the services and the programs it wishes to foster in the community. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure where the Minister got the figures from that he raised with me. I would be interested to hear that. The figures given to me in the written answers to my questions that were taken on notice show that the total amount allowed for marriage counselling services grants was $12.08m, and that the Queensland share represented a 57c per capita allowance. The Minister might be able to clarify for me how those figures differ from the figures that have been given to me. The Minister raised, rather gratuitously, the apparent—
—That is because I was misrepresented at the Estimates Committee. It was not gratuitous at all. It was directly relevant to what was raised at the Estimates Committee.

—It was gratuitous today. I did not ask the Minister about it today. The Minister is obviously upset because the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council chose to write to one of its senators and ask for a better go for Queensland. Why that should upset him I am not quite sure. Maybe it is because Tasmania is getting so much. Whatever the reason, that was not the point of the matter that I was raising today, except to say that Queensland is concerned that there is not sufficient money coming to it; that Queensland is not getting its fair share of the cake.

PARA.TAB: The Minister should look at the figures that I have mentioned—57c per capita for Queensland; 63c for New South Wales; 66c for Victoria; 93c for Western Australia; $1.09 for Tasmania; $1.36 for the Northern Territory; and, would you believe, in the Australian Capital Territory—where we are now and where the Minister's advisers live—it is $2.25 per capita. I repeat, Queensland gets 57c per capita; the Australian Capital Territory gets $2.25. What makes the Australian Capital Territory that much more entitled to the marriage counselling cake than Queenslanders are? Possibly the Minister will be able to indicate the reason for that discrepancy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be obvious to almost everyone that, in allocating funds to try to set up a service, where there is a small population—as in the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory, or Tasmania, but particularly the two territories—even to establish a basic service requires a lump of money which, really, one cannot get much below if any sort of service at all is to be provided. When that amount of money is divided by the population number there is a larger per capita figure, but that may be to provide only the very basic core funding that is required to establish a particular type of service.

PARA.TAB: This fact is well recognised by the Grants Commission and other bodies, and I indicate that as one of the bases. I also indicated that because Commonwealth funding has been provided to organisations on the basis of just the way that they have grown up over the years—these community groups, voluntary organisations in many instances at their inception, either of a secular basis or based in one of the church communities of Australia—there has not been from the start the simple criterion that the honourable senator advocates of per capita funding being the same for all jurisdictions.

I believe that what we are trying to do is to move to an overall policy framework which allows for a more national approach. That will occur. The director of the services has indicated to the peak organisations that we are trying to move to a more nationally coherent approach, because that has not been the case to now. I believe that the peak organisations are welcoming the opportunity to be involved in those discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not carry this on too much further, except to say to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) that his answer and justification do not ring true when one looks at the most populous States of Victoria and New South Wales. They still have a higher per capita funding than Queensland. If one looks at the Northern Territory, which has a smaller population than the Australian Capital Territory, it still has a smaller per capita funding allocation. Therefore, although what the Minister says is generally correct, it certainly has not applied right across the board. Because the Queensland organisation believes that it is not getting a fair share of the cake, it has had to restrict and cut back on services, as I mentioned in the Estimates Committee.

PARA.TAB: I finish by saying that if the Minister looks at those figures he will see that Queensland, per capita, is fairly grossly underfunded compared with the rest of Australia. I leave the Minister with the plea that when he is looking at the funds next year, he might in his kindness be able to give Queensland a slightly better consideration than it has had in the past. I accept the Minister's statement, without having any knowledge myself of this, that Queensland people have received a fairly substantial increase in recent years. I leave him with the request that when he is considering the matter again next year he try to bring Queensland a little closer to the per capita funding that is enjoyed by all other parts of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take into some sort of account what Senator Macdonald has said. It is important to put on the record that Australian taxpayers provided almost $3m to Queensland last year for family services to various programs administered by the Commonwealth. Marriage Guidance Queensland has received over the past couple of years a huge increase in its funding of 47.5 per cent, an increase of some $400,000 in its funding. Its relative position in Queensland as among those organisations which receive grants has declined because other organisations have come forward with very good projects that deserve funding. Part of the difficulty which Marriage Guidance Queensland does not want to accept is that it is not the sole provider of services in Queensland and does not have a monopoly on innovative and effective programs in this field.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Queensland has done well; that it will continue to receive proper attention from the Commonwealth. It will not be a question of kindness, but of trying to provide proper services for those couples who apply to these various organisations for assistance in a time of some distress in their relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not raising the question of what Marriage Guidance Queensland receives particularly; I was pointing out that the figures with which the Minister's office has provided me talk of total per capita funding to the whole State of Queensland, not to individual organisations. That is the point of my request to the Minister tonight.

—Looking at a list of many figures, I would point out that in my previous answer I gave a wrong figure. When I referred to a little less than $3m, I meant a little more than $2m. In fact, a sum of $2,153,600 was provided to Queensland by way of family services grants from the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On subprogram 3.3, censorship, I refer to page 106 of Estimates Committee E, additional information received, volume 1. I hope that this time the Attorney-General's Department has someone here who will be able to answer this question, not as on the previous occasion. I have given notice of this. I deliberately made a reservation in Estimates Committee E—Report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: My reservation is in respect of a written reply by the Department. My question related to the publicity campaign that has been conducted with considerable amounts of taxpayers' money by the Film Censorship Board and the very considerable amount of money that this Budget is providing for that Board and for the whole apparatus. My question asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Film Censorship Board's working definition of `pornography'? Can some X-rated material be regarded as pornographic? Does the Board's definition differ from that of the Williams Committee, the Fraser Committee, the Meese Commission and the Joint Select Committee on Video Materials?
The answer stated:
The Film Censorship Board does not have, nor is it required to have, a working definition of `pornography'. `Pornography' is not a term contained in the legislation relating to the work of the Board.

It has two other paragraphs that are not relevant to the question. I asked what was the Film Censorship Board's working definition of `pornography' and whether some X-rated material can be regarded as pornographic. The Board has not answered the question. I want an answer to it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has been provided with an answer. It is an answer he does not like. That is a completely different matter. The answer he has been given is that, as I understand it, the Chief Censor has advised that the Office of Film and Literature Classification does not have a working definition of `pornography'. That is the end of the matter. It does not have a working definition of the word `pornography'. It uses the legislation as its framework and abides by the definitions offered by the legislation in carrying out its task.
—Under the Acts Interpretation Act, does an explanatory memorandum to a regulation or to a Bill have any relevance to the administration of the law?

—The general rule in the Acts Interpretation Act—I think it is section 15AB—is that if there is an ambiguity in the principal section being looked at from the point of view of interpretation, then regard may be had to the explanatory memorandum to aid in the resolution of an ambiguity, but in the absence of an ambiguity or some obvious lack of clarity one does not have to go to the explanatory memorandum.

—Might I remind the Minister that the explanatory memorandum to the Classification of Publications Ordinance stated when it was tabled in this Parliament that `the additional classification—"X"—is applied to hard core pornography'. That surely must bind the Film Censorship Board in the administration of this law. I want to know what its definition of `pornography' is.

—I have indicated that the film and literature classification process does not require the Film Censorship Board to have reference to the explanatory memorandum. Evidently it finds that the Act itself is sufficiently clear in its direction as to the considerations which it ought to take into account.

—Is the Minister saying that what was contained in the explanatory memorandum was a useless piece of information? This explanatory memorandum was presented to this Parliament. Is the Minister saying that we were misled, that the Parliament was misled, because the Parliament was told by the Minister at the time that the X classification would relate to hard-core pornography? This statement was made to the Parliament and, surely, it was also conveyed to the Film Censorship Board. Is the Minister saying that the Film Censorship Board should not have regard to the explanation that was given to this Parliament officially by the Government in respect of the X classification?

—The fact remains that the Board does not find an ambiguity in the Act such as would require it to direct itself to the explanatory memorandum. That is the law, passed in this Parliament, and that is the law according to which the Board is operating.

—Is the Minister saying that he agrees that the Parliament was not misled, that in fact the material to be classified into the X classification does, in the words of the explanatory memorandum, include hard-core pornography?

—The point that we are trying to make is that the Film and Censorship Board has answered accurately Senator Harradine's question in the Estimates Committee. It does not have a working definition of pornography. It does not find it necessary to have a working definition, because it finds that the description by the Parliament of the task which it is to undertake is sufficiently clear, and therefore it does not have to go beyond the terms of the section. It is a very simple proposition. That is the law and that is what the Board is having regard to.

—The answer goes on to say that `the Board classifies as X sexually explicit material which contains no violence and no coercion'. Is that true or is it not? How does it distinguish between sexually explicit material which is of an educational or medical nature and pornography?

—It is quite clear, from the answer that I have given, that in carrying out its task it does not regard pornography as one of the categories to which it needs to have regard, by way of contrast in this instance with documents that are claimed to have a medical or educational value or purpose. It just does not come into the consideration. It applies what it finds to be clear enough direction in the Act itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this point because it is an attempt being made by the hard-core video porn industry to make sure that references to pornography are not used, but that references to explicit sexual material are used. Madam Temporary Chairman, I ask you and the Committee to listen to what the Board has said. Leaving aside the last paragraph, which goes into what the Board refuses to classify and which is not relevant for the purposes of the question, I quote as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Film Censorship Board does not have, nor is it required to have, a working definition of pornography. Pornography is not a term contained in the legislation relating to the work of the Board.
The Board classifies as `X' sexually explicit material which contains no violence and no coercion.

SPEECH.PARA: That is patently untrue. The Board does not classify as X any material that is sexually explicit and is of an educational or medical nature. On what basis does the Board distinguish between sexually explicit material that is of an educational or medical nature and material that is pornographic?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator Harradine is asking how the Board classifies sexually explicit material which is of a medical or educational type; is that right?
—Clearly, it does not classify that material into X category, but it says here that it does. It says:

PARA.TAB: The Board classifies as X sexually explicit material which contains no violence and no coercion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the exact definitions in front of me as to how it classifies that material which is of a medical or educational kind. But, quite clearly, there is a provision which has worked well in this regard. The definition enables the Board to make that distinction. I do not have available to me the exact criteria that it uses to distinguish the material which otherwise would not fall within the X-rated category.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot possibly accept just conversations with him—anecdotal evidence without any true evidence. PARA.TAB: Apart from that, again we have the situation where I asked for the statistics, under the normal practice, for the number of days that patients were kept in birthing centres and again, we do not have any information. The Department is aware, however, from verbal advice

Senator Harradine asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, without notice, on 17 October 1991:

Is it a fact that the current Budget imposes an inequitable fee relief system between dual-income families and one-income families which discriminates against one-income families despite income test levels being met? Is it a fact that the Budget envisaged that over the next six years there will be no growth in occasional child care places, mainly accessed by one-income families?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In the 1991 Federal Budget the Government announced a unified fee relief system to apply from 1 January 1992. Two levels of fee relief will apply to children using approved long day care, occasional care and family day care services.

Category one, higher level fee relief (based on the system currently applying in all long day care centres and family day care) will apply where care in these service types is for work-related reasons (including seeking work and studying or training for work); where a parent or child has a disability; and where a child is at risk of abuse or neglect. Category two, lower level fee relief (based on an enhancement of the system currently applying in occasional care centres) will apply to all other families using these services.

One-income families where one parent is in the workforce and the other is seeking or training for work will be eligible for the higher rate of fee relief. Sole parent families will be eligible, like all other families, for income-related fee relief based on their reason for requiring care.

This new fee relief system will replace the different fee relief systems that currently operate in each service type and will result in families with similar financial circumstances who use these different forms of care receiving the same level of fee relief. This is more equitable than current arrangements where families using occasional or non-work related care in occasional care centres may pay more than those who use the same form of care in a long day care centre or family day care scheme.

The Government's commitment to families with one parent at home has not diminished. The level of fee relief available for non-work related care from 1 January 1992 (based on the system currently applying in occasional care centres) will involve the payment of maximum assistance to families on incomes of approximately $22,000 per annum with a tapered withdrawal of benefit so families on incomes up to around $45,000 per annum will receive some benefit.

The 1991 Budget does not envisage that there will be no growth in the provision of occasional care. The 1990 election commitment to extend the National Child Care growth strategy to 1995/96 includes a significant expansion of long day care (centres and family day care). Occasional care is provided by way of gap filling in these services. The 1989 Census of Government-funded child care services indicates that about 16% of care provided in long day care centres and 9% in family day care is for non-work related purposes. Accordingly, it is estimated that there will be considerable expansion of occasional care places over the next six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received material on the Australian Health Ethics Committee in the responses from the Department. There are a number of questions that I would like to ask about the establishment of that particular body and the disbandment of the previous body. The Minister will recall the establishment of the previous body, the National Bioethics Consultative Committee. Can the Minister advise why that Committee was disbanded, and on whose recommendation it was abolished?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the decision was taken by a joint ministerial council meeting of health and social welfare Ministers. The decision was taken to focus the work of the Committee on a slightly narrower range of health ethics matters rather than on what might have been considered to be a wider charter in relation to bioethics, which could be interpreted as a broader brief. The Ministers decided that a new body, with a slightly refined focus, would better achieve what they wanted.
—What is the expected expenditure per annum of the new Australian Health Ethics Committee, and what are its terms of reference?

—I think an answer was provided, but I am not sure. The budget for the Australian Health Ethics Committee for 1991-92 is $302,000, including salaries for secretariat staff and administrative costs. The functions of the committee are to inquire into, advise and recommend on ethical, legal and social matters.
—I have the functions.
—Why did Senator Harradine ask for them if he has them?
—I wanted the terms of reference of the committee.
—Has there been a particular reference given to it, as opposed to those general terms of reference?
—Is the Minister suggesting that the functions of the committee are the same as the terms of reference of the committee?
—Yes, Senator.
—What, if any, specific matters have been referred to that committee?

—I understand that no reference has been given to it. It has the capacity to determine its own program. Under that capacity, at its one meeting, it has determined to look at resource allocation in the provision of health services and the various health ethics committees attached to hospitals and research institutions.
—I now turn to National Health and Medical Research Council grants.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—Is this a question on notice?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—I am trying to keep within the guidelines.

—It is strictly within the guidelines. It refers to a figure probably in excess of $80m. Prior to the Senate Estimates Committee hearings I asked whether the Committee could be provided with details of the National Health and Medical Research Council grants for 1992, similar to those provided to the Estimates Committee in previous years. The response was that the NHMRC research grants for 1992 were expected to be announced towards the end of September, after approval by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), and that details would be provided to the Committee when the Minister had approved the grants. That is totally unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: I have made reference to this before. We are talking about many millions of dollars. The Estimates Committee is unable to consider those grants and the expenditure on those grants. To my knowledge, the material has never been received by the Estimates Committee until after the Estimates Committee has met. For example, on this occasion the letter from the Department was written only last Wednesday, weeks after the Senate Estimates Committee met. I think the material was received in my office on Friday of last week. I was here late on Sunday and I saw it on my desk on Monday. On Monday there was a full day of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies. Today is the only chance that I have had to look at this multimillion dollar expenditure which we have been asked to approve. That is not satisfactory, in my view, unless, of course, we take the view that we should trust what the NHMRC does with the taxpayers' money.

On a number of occasions in this chamber I have made reference to some of the very doubtful projects to which the NHMRC has directed the money. I hasten to say that most of the projects are certainly not in that category. I also hasten to say that a considerable amount of fine work has been done by the assessors and others who are required to do work in this field, assessing the proposals. I will be quite open about that. In general, these people should be congratulated for the very good work they are doing.

There are a number of proposals here that I have flagged. I could spend from now until 3 a.m. reading these out and asking the Minister questions about them, because they run into millions of dollars. I would like an assurance from the Minister that if I supply the Department with the details of the grants for which I require detailed information—including assessors' reports, obviously sanitised with the assessors' names excised—that that information will be provided to me at the earliest opportunity.

I come back to the major point: is it fair for the Government to include in a Budget a figure in the order of $80m when it does not know what it is going to be used for? I do not know the precise figure; perhaps the Minister's advisers can tell him. It may be more than $80m; it may be slightly less. Is it fair for the Parliament to be asked to approve this substantial amount of money when it does not know what it is going to be used for?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the figure for 1992 is $104m, so it is a considerable sum. I suppose the fact is that the process which is thought—and, as I understand it, well supported within the scientific and research community in Australia—to provide the fairest method of allocating the funds is the peer group assessors' report and the various regional committee recommendations that precede the final recommendations to the Minister for approval of particular grants. I do not think it would be very wise or satisfactory if this Committee tried to substitute itself for that process, although there must be a place for the Committee to comment on the expenditure of money that occurs under this system of grants.

PARA.TAB: If the inference to be drawn from Senator Harradine's comments about the timing is that somehow the Committee should substitute itself for that particular process of decision making about which proposals might be funded or ought to be funded, that would not be a satisfactory process at all. The fact that the material is now available—and I am sorry if it was received by Senator Harradine only in recent days—still enables him to make comments in relation to the particular projects that have received grants.

I will have to take advice on Senator Harradine's request about the provision of assessors' reports. I am not quite sure what the implications of agreeing to that request would be in relation to privacy considerations of the grant applicants concerned, and what influence it might have on the integrity of the process in future years. If the assessors' reports—which I presume could be from a group of three assessors with two in favour and one against, with all sorts of comments—were to go into the public domain, it might cause great difficulty to applicants. I think there needs to be some consideration of that matter before I am able to respond positively to Senator Harradine's request.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had made it perfectly clear to the Minister that I acknowledge the work that was done by the people who are assessing the validity of these projects. I am not suggesting that we, the Senate Committee and particularly a Senate Estimates Committee, should undertake the role of assessing the scientific validity of particular projects that have been put forward for grants.

PARA.TAB: I do, however, as a member of parliament, insist on my right to know where taxpayers' moneys are going. It should not be forgotten that this same National Health and Medical Research Council gave something like $350,000 to Professor Peter Singer's outfit to develop a philosophy, as it were, in respect of human embryo experimentation. That, surely, should have been a matter for considerable discussion in this chamber before it was approved, but we did not know about it. The material was not given to us until after the appropriations had been passed. That is not appropriate; that is entirely inappropriate.

As members of parliament, we have a representative function. We also have an audit function over the activity of governments and over the activity of organisations which are under the control of the Minister. It is the Minister who approves these. It is not the National Health and Medical Research Council which is the final approver, it is the Minister. I think that is an advance; that is better for democracy than an outside body deciding where money should be spent.

All I ask is that some arrangement be made whereby this document can be supplied to us prior to the meetings of Estimates committees. I have asked for this three years running and still it has not been done. I understand there may be difficulties because the budgetary year, being July to June, does not coincide with the university year and many of these grants are made to universities and other institutions. Perhaps some sort of indication could be made. In respect of the question that I asked the Minister, I have been supplied in previous years with the information that I requested and that I requested from the Minister just a moment ago, including the assessors' reports. They have been supplied with the names of the assessors deleted.

There is no-one—neither here, in the medical or scientific community, nor in the Department—who will say that I have abused that in any way. It is necessary for us to know not only the details of the project but also how the assessors see that project working out. That is a very important reason for the necessity to have the assessors' reports. With a number of these project grants, one does not quite know on paper what will be done, what is proposed and so on. For example, on the first page, on attachment 3, I notice a grant made to a Ms J.L. Halliday of Murdoch Institute in Victoria. It is entitled, `The utilisation of amniocentesis and chorion villous sampling in Victoria and subsequent perinatal outcomes'. I do not know what that is about.

Two avenues arise in my mind as to what that might mean, but I believe it is necessary, if we are spending considerable amounts of taxpayers' money, that we have the full information. Rather than reading out those particular items now, I will give those subsequently to the Minister or, if he chooses, to the Department with the request as indicated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the assessors' reports have been provided—I do not know that they have—and if there is no privacy or other consideration preventing their being made available, I presume they can again. As far as the list is concerned, if the honourable senator provides that to the departmental officers, I am sure they can get the assessors' reports in accordance with whatever past practice has been adopted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was a shortcoming of mine, but it seems to be shared by others. I ask Senator Harradine to be more specific about the two areas to which he is referring.
—The Department knows very well what areas I am referring to.
—It would help me if you told me.

—I will, and I will refer to the ministerial statement which was made to the Senate by Senator Tate on 2 April 1987. I will also refer to the references in that particular statement and in the subsequent debate. When outlining the statement of the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, Senator Tate indicated that the program had three elements—abstinence, safe sex with a single partner and the use of condoms in the absence of either of the first two. I am asking: where in this current campaign are the first two elements mentioned by the Minister at that time?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that all three methods are referred to in the material. The first two are quite explicitly mentioned.

—The material in front of me does not, as I see it, say anything about abstinence. We should bear in mind that this material will be targeted at our young people. Given the fact that the greatest cause of the transmission of STD/AIDS is homosexual anal sex, where in this material, or indeed in any of the material that the Government is putting out, is there a warning to young men that experimenting in that type of sexual behaviour poses a deadly risk?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a slightly different question from the one which Senator Harradine raised before. I return to the point that he raised initially with regard to abstinence and monogamy. My advice is that the material does refer to those options. If the material that Senator Harradine has before him does not refer to that, he obviously does not have all the material. I am quite happy to make sure that a comprehensive set of pamphlets and material is made available to him so that he can have a look. I am advised that he will then be assured that that information is available.
—The document that I have says `No matter where you go in the world, if you have sex make sure you use a condom'.
—I am wondering what you are going to go on to say; I am interested.

—I am asking where the first two elements are. I am saying this because at the time Senator Tate took a great deal of offence and umbrage at what I was suggesting, which was that in this campaign the Government was going to forget about the first two elements and just concentrate on the last one. That is precisely what has happened. What I said on that occasion and what Senator Tate took umbrage at has proven to be correct. I am raising this here and now because I had warned against it on that occasion, I was taken to task by Senator Tate and now I have been proven correct.

PARA.TAB: The focus of all this material—and we are talking about the targeted young people—is not to practise abstinence before marriage and fidelity in marriage but, wherever one goes and has sex, to use a condom. That is the message that our young people are getting. There is no positive message to indicate that there are methods of avoiding AIDS which the Minister had indicated would be part of campaigns. We are spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on these sorts of campaigns. I am asking again whether the Parliamentary Secretary is misleading the Senate by saying what he is saying.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I am not because I am telling Senator Harradine quite explicitly what my advice is and I have offered to make the information available to him so he can check it. If the question is whether I am misleading him, the answer is no. I assume that Senator Harradine is really concerned that in the material that is being presented we are recognising that the research indicates that people do go overseas and sometimes have sex while they are there; I have to confess that that is true. It may be a shock to Senator Harradine and to other honourable senators. I notice the look of shock and horror on the face of some of my colleagues, but it is true.

PARA.TAB: The evidence indicates that people who have sex are in more danger and in more need of the information than people who do not. Therefore, some of the material is directed to the people whom it is designed to assist. I do not think that is nonsensical. But I am advised that the options to which Senator Harradine refers, such as abstinence and monogamy, which, to the extent that people practise them, make people less susceptible to the risk of AIDS, are explicitly referred to in the material. The options are there, but the material does recognise the reality with which we have to deal and advocates courses of action that will make such activity safer for people going overseas. It is a responsible course for any government to take and that is why the Government is taking it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not appreciate the flippancy with which the Parliamentary Secretary has treated this matter. I have been involved with the AIDS problem ever since it was known in Australia. That ought to be understood by the Parliamentary Secretary. I do not appreciate the flippant way in which he has dealt with this question.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to remind the Senate of what the Minister said to the Senate in 1987. He said that there would be three elements in the Government's campaign. Two of them are either clearly not there or are so unable to be perceived that I cannot perceive them. Furthermore, the type of language that is used—bear in mind that it is directed at young people such as Youth Hostels Association people—seems to indicate that vaginal and anal sex are of equal choice. The pamphlet says that if a person has vaginal or anal sex, that person should protect himself or herself and his or her partner from HIV infection and other sexually transmitted diseases by using condoms. I am asking the Parliamentary Secretary whether that is a correct statement of fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is what a correct statement of fact?

—Is this a correct statement of fact: `If you have vaginal or anal sex you should protect yourself and your partner from HIV infection and other sexually transmitted diseases by using condoms.'? Is the Minister saying that condoms, in the circumstances of anal sex in particular, will `protect yourself and your partner from HIV infection'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would say that it is unquestionably extremely good advice to anybody who is going to engage in such conduct to wear a condom.

—I am asking the Minister a different question, and he knows it. We are now talking about misleading advertising, and advertising which is probably dangerous to some of the people that are going to read it, because some of the people who take this sort of advice could end up with AIDS. Everybody knows that condoms, particularly when used for anal sex, are not absolutely foolproof. What the Government is saying here, virtually, is that they give protection. In fact, it may be argued that, in that circumstance, wearing a condom gives more protection from AIDS than if a condom were not used, but the way that it is put here and the way that the campaign is waged is, I believe, misleading and quite dangerous in the long term. What I am asking now is: why is the message not given to young people that to experiment with anal sex is a deadly risk? Why is that message not given? Why have we not seen that message anywhere in any of the Government's education programs on AIDS?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine makes a speech about one point and then asks a question about another. In response to the essential element of his contribution, I do not believe that it is unreasonable to advise people that they will enhance their protection by wearing a condom. It is essentially sound advice that any responsible citizen would give and any responsible government would give—and governments around the world are giving it to young people, old people and anyone else that they feel may put themselves in danger in the course of overseas travel or other activities.

PARA.TAB: It is responsible advice. It is advice that I believe the Government will and should continue to provide to its citizens and to travellers to this country. We will continue also, in the material, to advise people of the other two elements of the campaign to which Senator Harradine referred, but nothing which he has said will persuade me or, as far as I know, the Government or other concerned citizens, that we should not continue to advise citizens that they should wear condoms in the circumstances outlined in the material.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) has not answered my question. I asked the question quite deliberately. He will have to look at the documentation to see whether the advice that he has been given is correct. I invite him to look at the posters that are proposed. Will he first tell me whether he can see any of the first two elements that Senator Tate promised would be in these campaigns? He promised them on behalf of the Minister. Let us see whether any of those are in this campaign and, if so, in what proportion. In 1987 Senator Tate said—and he will be reminded about this—that two-thirds of the Government's education campaign would be on those first two elements. When I challenged Senator Tate about that he took a great deal of umbrage before this chamber. He criticised me for daring to suggest that the Government was on the wrong track.

PARA.TAB: All I am saying is that the Government should be honest about it. The Government had a White Paper, and if it has made these decisions it should stick to them. I believe that it is not going down the right track. In fact, I believe that it is assisting in setting in place a regimen which will guarantee the continuance of AIDS in this country. But again I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, given the incidence of AIDS and the particular high risk activity that is involved in homosexual anal sex, where in any of the Government's campaigns is a warning given to young people that such activity is a deadly risk?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the strong views that Senator Harradine holds about this matter and the fact that fundamentally at the end of the day we will have to agree to disagree about the best way of conducting campaigns to warn people about the dangers of AIDS, the evidence appears to be that Australia has been relatively successful internationally in the campaign to contain the spread of AIDS. Nobody has been as successful as one would wish, but we have been relatively successful.

PARA.TAB: I assert, and the evidence tends to indicate, that giving emphasis to the dangers of anal sex and male homosexual activity in the spread of AIDS raises the significant possibility in respect of people going overseas, particularly to high risk areas, to engage in heterosexual sex of engendering just that sense of complacency that is the worst outcome that we could possibly achieve. I understand the genuineness of Senator Harradine's concern, but I think that the course of action he is recommending is ill-conceived and ill-considered and would not achieve its objective. I understand that he does not share that view and therefore we have to agree to disagree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot understand the response by the Minister. Is he saying that the Government is not giving any warning to young people in its education campaign on AIDS that it is a deadly risk indeed for them to experiment in anal sexual activity? Is he saying that the reason that the Government does not do that is that it might make people complacent about heterosexual sex? Is that what he is saying? If so, where is the logic in that given the fact that the overwhelming majority of AIDS cases, and indeed of AIDS deaths, are a result of that type of activity? One would have thought that given that fact the Government may have included that in its campaigns. Is the Minister suggesting that heterosexual sexual activity is as equally high risk as homosexual anal sexual activity?
—I have nothing to add.
—Well I have, because the Minister obviously is not addressing the question.
—You have obviously not understood the answer.
—I have certainly understood the answer.
—Then stop misrepresenting it.

—I also know the facts because I have studied the matter for some considerable time. I might also point out—there should be no need to point it out—that the community, and indeed all of us personally, need to provide imaginative care for those who have contracted AIDS. I am going to watch what the Government is saying to the youth of this country. The Government is saying to our youth that young people can do what they like, when they like and with whom they like, provided they use a condom. That is the Government's message. That message will surely enhance the promiscuous attitude within our society which is the very basis for the spread of STD/AIDS. That is a problem that the Government must face up to.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I come back to the point that Senator Tate made in 1987 which the Government has avoided. He said that two-thirds of the Government's education program on AIDS would relate to the other two elements. I ask the Minister again to show me where that two-thirds is in this new campaign?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be time to take a break. I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it be unreasonable to ask those who might have a particular interest in this part for some indication as to how long it might take? It seems to me that we have reached a stage where it would be sensible to continue in the morning, but obviously the Government has a different view. It seems to be principally a debate between Senator Harradine and the Parliamentary Secretary. There is no order that allows me to do this, but can we have some sort of guidance as to how long Senator Harradine and the Government think this part might take?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—Is there anybody in a position to answer that question?

TALK.START.PARA: —If I am permitted to draw attention to the state of the Committee, I will try to see what is next on the program.
—I intend to say a few words on this matter, too, at the appropriate time, if that influences the agenda.
—Go ahead; get on with it. (Quorum formed)

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
