TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier yesterday Senator Walters asked a question when I was not in the chair concerning an exchange which took place earlier between myself and Senator Bishop. Senator Walters suggested that I had ordered something to be struck out of Hansard. In fact, I did not give any such direction, nor would I do so. I indicated that a comment I had made concerning the result of the Melbourne Cup would not be recorded in Hansard because asides of that nature from the Chair are customarily not recorded. It has been customary in the past for the Chair to inform honourable senators in the chamber, when the Senate is sitting at the time of the Melbourne Cup, of the result of the race, and the occupant of the chair occasionally makes other asides which are not recorded as part of the proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Because reference was made about my remark by Senator Bishop and Senator Walters, it became essential that the remark should be recorded in Hansard, and thus I subsequently asked Hansard to ensure that my remark was recorded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 March, and more latterly on 5 September 1991, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) raised a number of allegations about a well-known Melbourne tax professional, Mr Mark Leibler, and Mr Leibler's appointment to both the national tax liaison group and the advisory panel of the Commissioner of Taxation. Since Mr Leibler is not a member of either House of Federal Parliament, I have been approached by a number of tax practitioners, because of my role on income tax issues on behalf of the coalition, to include in Hansard a rebuttal of Mr Aldred's misunderstanding of the issues, including those relating to Mr Leibler's appointments. I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter from Mr David Miles, President of the Law Council of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Law Council of Australia
24 October 1991
Mr Mark Leibler AO
Arnold Bloch Leibler
DX 455 MELBOURNE
Dear Mark

I have examined in detail the material you have forwarded to the Law Council relating to the personal attacks that have been made on you under Parliamentary privilege by Ken Aldred MP over the period March—September 1991.

I note that you have responded, rebutting each allegation and pointing out inaccuracies. However, I appreciate that your are fighting to protect your reputation with one hand tied behind your back when Mr Aldred is continuing to use the shield of Parliamentary privilege.

Much has been made of your membership of taxation advisory bodies. On two of those bodies, the National Tax Liaison Group and the Commissioner's Advisory Panel, you are the nominee of the Law Council of Australia pursuant to an invitation by the Commissioner to the Law Council to nominate a representative.

The Law Council greatly appreciates your long and committed service on a voluntary basis in the very important area of taxation law. Your work over two years as Chairman of the extremely busy and highly regarded Taxation Committee of the Business Law Section was invaluable.
Your appointment by the Law Council as its representative on the above advisory bodies reflects the high regard in which you are held as a senior and highly experienced practitioner in taxation law.
I trust that you will not be discouraged from cont inuing to serve the Law Council of Australia, and thereby Australian taxpayers, by Mr Aldred's utterances in Parliament.
Yours sincerely
David Miles
President

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In that letter Mr Miles states that Mr Leibler is a member of the national tax liaison group and the Commissioner's advisory panel because he is the nominee of the Law Council of Australia pursuant to an invitation by the Commissioner to the Law Council to nominate a representative. The relevant advisory bodies of the Commissioner of Taxation serve merely as a conduit through which the Australian Taxation Office receives input from a variety of professional, tax practitioner and industry-based groups. Full and detailed minutes of the proceedings of meetings of those bodies, I emphasise, are published.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, my actions this evening in placing on the parliamentary record concisely Mr Leibler's rebuttal of allegations made by Mr Aldred in the other place, I believe, have clarified the background to Mr Leibler's appointment to both those important bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the House for more than about a minute and a half. Tonight has been as much fun as a wet night at the Dapto dogs and I think everyone wants to get home. I want to put on record some of my views, expressed as succinctly as possible, about the Fairfax difficulties and the takeover bids that have been discussed day in and day out in the newspapers. I have for that purpose responded in a letter to Senator Schacht, my Labor Party colleague, who has, as most honourable senators would be aware, circulated us with a letter of his own indicating his views about the suitability or otherwise of Mr Conrad Black to be an owner of Australian newspapers.

PARA.TAB: My views are contained in the letter I have written in reply to Senator Schacht. I think the best way for me to put that on the record is simply to seek leave of the Senate to incorporate that material in Hansard, and I do so now.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: THE SENATE
CANBERRA, A.C.T.
Senator Chris Schacht
Senator for South Australia
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
5 November 1991
Dear Chris
I am in receipt of your circular of 25th October in which you enclosed an article from Conrad Black.
I must state at the outset that I do not carry a torch for any of the current bidders for the Fairfax empire.

However, I am forced to note that Conrad Black at least had the courage and/or effrontery to state his prejudices openly as a guest columnist in his own newspaper. Surely this is preferable to exercising editorial censorship behind the scenes?

I am unaware of the political views of the A.I.N. Melbourne based group which you seem to support because my guess is they confine their prejudices to the clubs and boardrooms to which I have no entree. If I were to hazard a guess I could only come to the conclusion that their views would be polite and cautious but, underneath it all, as conservative as those of Conrad Black.

I also wonder how an editor of an A.I.N. controlled newspaper would be treated if he or she were to commission an in-depth investigation of the prudential and investment policies of the major institutions that are currently backing the A.I.N. bid.

You see, I don't understand why control of a newspaper by strong-willed media magnates like Conrad Black or Kerry Packer is any worse than ownership of a newspaper by conservative institutions like AMP or National Mutual which seem to have a finger in every investment pie in this country. At least Conrad Black and Kerry Packer have identifiable personalities.
Incidentally, I happen to agree with Mr Black's views about the pharisaical Jane Fonda. She and Ted Turner deserve each other.
Yours fratricidally
Terry Aulich
Senator for Tasmania

PARA.EMPHASIS: Why won't our left-wing finally take a right turn?

SPEECH.PARA: LONDON—If Moscow has provided the requiem for communism, Toronto and Ottawa are witnessing the Gotterdammerung of the soft left. Sweden has electorally repudiated six pretentious decades of socialism to the self-conscious silence of all those Canadians of the drivelling left who keened after Nordic socialism for most of that time. Antipodean New Zealand has repealed and is rooting out the socialist encrustations of generations.

PARA.TAB: Only in Ontario in the entire democratic world, is the cant and hypocrisy of union-dominated soak-the-rich, anti-productivity, politics of envy officially approved and po-facedly presented as "caring and compassion".

In order to take a reliable day flight from Toronto to London last week, I had to drive to Niagara Falls, New York, and fly to London via New York City. On the pleasant drive to the border, I reflected that I was travelling exactly as Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, was reduced to going from Baghdad to Moscow in March. He, at least, had the excuse of a war in which his country's airspace was entirely occupied by the overwhelming power of the U.S. Air Force. I had the "public service" of Canada to thank for my detour, while long lines of cars and trucks were held up by customs officials also of the Canadian "public service"; as they waited to enter Canada at Queenstown.

Only in Canada, especially in Ontario, are the Prig stormtroopers of the old, soft, anti-capitalist left still taken seriously when they insolently strive to communize industry, confiscate wealth, and discourage economic growth. At the last endeavour they will be over-achievers, as Ontario will shortly, and for the first time, have a higher level of unemployment than all provinces west of New Brunswick and, barring a drastic course correction, will cease to be a "have" province, for equalization purposes within a few years.
(When Quebec is invited to pay for equalization benefits for Ontario and the Atlantic provinces, our bedraggled, mismanaged confederation will be put to its most spectacular test.)

In Canada, almost alone of western countries, not to mention formerly communist ones, the left has not yet had to account for its catastrophic misjudgments. In western Europe and the United States, the intelligent press is filled with mea culpas of all those who denied the corruption and economic failure of the Soviet Union, who upheld Sweden, or even Nicaragua or Cuba, as the future that worked, who demonstrated against the U.S. government all around the world at any imagined provocation, while ignoring the barbarism and Big Lies of the communist powers.

In Canada the fashionable poseurs who were proud of vacationing in Cuba, who bought Ladas but ostentatiously departed their deadly cocktail parties if South African sherry or wine lurked on the bar, who were prompted by almost every edition of the Toronto Star or "As It Happens" to demonstrate at the U.S. Consulate, who shrilly proclaimed that cruise missile testing and NATO's Euro-missile department endangered world peace, have slunk back into the lumpen tory-socialist masses of Canada. They are comparatively silent about international affairs, jubilation over supposed American decline having given way to simpering about American omnipotence, but they are still in the ascendant in domestic politics.

Jane Fonda, Joan Baez, most of the British Labor Party and the Chicago Seven, and even Regis Debray and H. Rap Brown have recanted and repented. No such morally enhancing rite has blessed Canadian public discussion. Farley Mowat, Stephen Lewis and John Ralston Saul, who in the `70s and `80s doubled Canada's Gross Claptrap and Philistinism Product, are apparently unchastened.
The Toronto Star still excerpts from the unspeakably banal Linda McQuaig. Her fictions over the free trade agreement have been subsidized by the Can Lit back-scratching and log-rolling safety net.

Veteran Liberal MP, Lloyd Axworthy, who has given new meaning to Cromwell's description of the "decayed servitor" and whose principal foreign policy initiative was effectively to appease Saddam Hussein during the gulf war, had the effrontery to style the brilliant appointment of Fred Eaton as High Commissioner in London "a payoff to a political bagman".

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly because of something Senator Watson has said with which I agree. Firstly, Mr President, I indicate on behalf of all Government senators our support for what you did yesterday afternoon and your statement this morning. I welcome the statement by Senator Watson. I think it has been, and is, important that a senior frontbench person from the Opposition should take steps to correct the situation that had been created by the unwarranted misuse of privilege by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred).I believe that what he did was unfair and unreasonable.

PARA.TAB: In the Senate we have proper procedures for allowing the offended person to have his views properly reflected in Hansard. I think that the attack did more discredit to the honourable member for Deakin than it did to the person he was attacking. Nevertheless, the person concerned felt understandably aggrieved and looked forward to an opportunity to have some of that record set straight. To the extent that what has taken place tonight has at least in some part corrected that, I welcome it. I thank Senator Watson for it and share the views he expressed on it.

I reiterate my view that the attack by the honourable member for Deakin was entirely inappropriate and inaccurate. It did the Parliament no credit. Those sorts of misuses of privilege serve only to bring the Parliament into discredit. It is appropriate that we take action to correct it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) On how many occasions has the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) travelled overseas since his election to the Parliament.
(2) What were the reasons for those visits.
(3) By whom was the Minister accompanied on these visits.
(4) What were the total costs of each of these visits.
(5) What is a breakdown of the accommodation, car hire, meal, airfare, land transport, gift and personal expense components of each the trips.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is:

PARA.TAB: (1) Three.
(2) USSR, Japan, Republic of Korea 1 to 13 July 1990.
Open Australian Trade Display, Vladivostok, USSR

Ministerial representation at the Australian Trade Display was strongly supported by the Department of Foreign Affairs, Austrade and the participating companies in order to demonstrate the importance Australia attached to the development of trade with the Soviet Far East.
Meet with counterpart Ministers in Japan and the Republic of Korea.

Hold high level discussions with industry and Government in Japan and the Republic of Korea (including public sector research organisations) concerning bilateral science arrangements, with a particular emphasis on strengthening linkages in applied research.
Itinerary for the visit included:

USSR—Briefing with Australian officials including Ambassador to the USSR, Mr Ashwin, Exhibition Director, Mr Wilson, Senior Trade Commissioner Moscow, Mr Wing; Official Opening of Australian Trade Exhibition; Press Conference for USSR and Australian Journalists; Host dinner reception for 300 guests; attend Vladivostok Trade Display; host function for representatives of participating Australian companies. Meetings with Chairman, Vladivostok Soviet, Mr Samyonkin; Deputy Chairman, Primorsk Regional Government, Mr Baturin; Vice-Chairman USSR Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Chairman USSR/ Australia Business Council, Mr Efremov; Premier, Khabarovsk Regional Government. Visits to Soviet Far East Branch of USSR Academy of Science (Mr Krushanov, Acting Chairman and other officials); Pacific Research Institute of Fisheries and Oceanography; Sea station of Pacific Oceanological Institute (Popov Island); Pacific Institute of Bio-organic Chemistry; Institute of Marine Biology, SFE. Branch of Academy of Science; Geological Museum of SFE Branch USSR Academy of Science.

Japan—Meetings with Japanese Minister of State for Science and Technology, Mr Oshima, and high level Government officials including Director-General Of Science and Technology Agency; Japanese Parliamentary Vice-Minister for International Trade and Industry (MITI) Mr Nukaga; Managing Director, Japan Industrial Technology Association, Dr Shimuzu; Kirin Executive Vice-President, Dr Yamamoto and General Manager R and D, Dr Morimoto. Attend dinner hosted by Australian Ambassador, Mr Dalrymple, to meet eminent representatives of Japanese science community and industry; attend lunch hosted by Japanese Minister of State for Science and Technology. Visits to Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute, Takasaki Radiation Chemistry Research Establishment (Dr S Machi, Director-General); Kirin Fundamental Research Laboratory and Pharmaceutical Research Laboratory, Takasaki, (Dr Takahoshi, General Manager); Tsukuba Science City; NEC Tsukuba Research Institute (Mr Saito, Vice-President NEC); Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation, Tokai-Mura (Mr Kurhara, Executive Director). Press conferences Takasaki and Tokyo.

Republic of Korea—Meetings with Republic of Korea Minister of Science and Technology, Dr Chung Kun-Mo; Republic of Korea Minister for Labour Affairs, Mr Choi Young-choul; Commissioner, Korea Industrial Property Office, Dr Kim Chul-su; President, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST), Dr Park Won-hee; President and CEO Lucky Co, Mr Choi Keun-sun and other senior company officials; President, Samsung Aerospace, Mr Ahn Si-Bwan; President IBM Korea, Mr Peter Rowley. Host breakfast for members of the Australian Business Group in Korea; attend lunch hosted by Korean Minister for Science and Technology attended by senior Republic of Korea Government officials; host dinner at Daedok Science Town for Presidents of Research Institutes (including Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Korea Science and Engineering Foundation, Genetic Engineering Centre, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology), attend lunch hosted by Australian Ambassador Gribble to meet eminent representatives of Republic of Korea Government, science community and industry. Visits to Samsung Electronics, Suwon (Chairman and CEO, Mr Kang Jin-ku); Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology (President, Dr Soh Jin-wha); Taedok Science Town, Korea Advanced Energy Research Institute, Daedok (President, Dr Han Pilsson); Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute, Daedok, (President, Mr Kyong Sang-han).
USA, Canada 21 to 30 September 1990
Represent the Treasurer (in capacity as Minister Assisting the Treasurer) at the Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington D.C.
Visit and hold discussions in relation to Ontario's ``Centres of Excellence''. (The centres are based on similar principles as the Government's Cooperative Research Centres programme).
Itinerary for the visit included:

USA—Attend IMF Interim Committee Meeting; Attend IMF/World Bank Development Committee Meeting; Attend IMF/World Bank Annual General Meetings; Bilateral meeting with Swiss Finance Minister on Swiss Membership application; attend lunch hosted by Australian Ambassador Cook to meet high level US Government officials including the science adviser to President Bush, Dr Bromley.

Canada—Visits to Manufacturing Research Corporation of Ontario (Mr David Henderson, Executive Vice-President); Ortech International (Dr Robert Sawa, Manager); Ontario Laser and Lightwave Research Centre (Dr Van Driel, Director); Micronet Centre of Excellence (Prof Andre Salama). Meet with representatives from the following other `Centres of Excellence' Telecommunications Research Institute of Ontario, Information Technology Research Centre, Institute of Space and Terrestrial Science. Attend Round Table lunch University of Toronto. Attend dinner hosted by Australian High Commissioner Humphries to meet senior Government, university and industry representatives.
Malta, Spain, Italy, Germany, France 13 November to 2 December 1990.
Attend meeting of Commonwealth Ministers with responsibility for Science and Technology in Malta.

Meet with counterpart Ministers in Spain, Germany and France in order to discuss strengthening of bilateral contact in science field, in particular to emphasise applied research and private sector involvement. Note: Arising from these meetings a programme of reciprocal industry/research missions has been established in order to develop practical opportunities for strategic collaboration.
Hold discussions re industry `networking' and the manner in which R&D is linked to industry and industrial innovation in Northern Italy.
Itinerary for the visit included:

Malta—Participate in Meeting of Commonwealth Ministers with responsibility for Science and Technology, including representing all Ministers at Official Opening by the Maltese Prime Minister and Press Conference. Bilateral meeting with Minister for Foreign Affairs and President, UN General Assembly, Professor Guido de Marco.

Spain—Meetings with Spanish Minister for Education and Science, Sr D Javier Solana Madariaga and senior Government officials including the Secretary of State for Universities and Research, Sr Rojo; Spanish Minister for Industry and Energy, Sr D Jose Claudio Aranzadi Martinez; President, National Superior Council for Scientific Research, Sr Munoz; Director-General, Centre for the Development of Industrial Technology, Sr Arnes; Secretary-General for the National Scientific Research and Technological Development Plan, Sr Oro. Host lunch for representatives of the Spanish Confederation of Business Associations (CEOE) and senior industrialists.

Note: During the visit Mr Crean exchanged formal correspondence with the Spanish Minister for Education and Science in order to confirm agreement to focus bilateral research collaboration in six nominated areas. A Spanish delegation comprised of senior representatives of industry and public sector research organisations visited Australia in September 1991 to pursue the agreed approach by Ministers with a return Australian delegation anticipated for early 1992.

Italy—Visit the `Bicocca' Project site, Milan (a project of international significance which will establish research centres of excellence with linkages to industry and universities). Meetings with General Manager, Societa Proguetto Bicocca, Mr Nassi, Scientific Manager, Dr Pascucci; General Manager, Consortium Milano Ricerche, Dr Archetti; Vice-President, Metropolitan Interests Association, Dr Torrani. Host lunch for senior representatives of industry and universities. Visit research centres including Teleinformatics, Institute for the Environment, Data Set (telecommunication) Sensors, Special materials. Visit and hold discussions `Assessorato all'Industria Regione Emilia-Romagna' Bologna with Director of ASTER Dr Gimelli and senior representatives of industry concerning 'networking' and access of small to medium enterprises to research. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Telecom, utilising s.7 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, covertly intercepted and monitored, without warrant, individual telephone subscribers' telephones for periods up to and exceeding three weeks, that is, `long-term' for purposes other than security or `nuisance' calls; if so, what is the longest period of time, from installation of the `tap' until its eventual removal, that Telecom has covertly intercepted and monitored subscribers' telephones in South Australia, Western Australia and nationally.

(2) What is the estimated maximum time that such covert long-term interceptions and monitoring of subscribers' telephones has been `left up', that is, connected, from installation of the `tap' until eventual removal, in South Australia, Western Australia and nationally.
(3) What is the estimated average time of such covert interceptions and monitoring of subscribers' telephones in South Australia, Western Australia and nationally.

(4) Is there legislation or regulation which sets out and states a maximum time limit on such covert long-term interception and monitoring, without warrant, of subscribers' telephones, by Telecom; if so, which are those legislative or regulative authorities; if not, what are the legal/moral ramifications of the practices referred to above.

(5) Did the Commonwealth Ombudsman in 1981-82 and on subsequent occasions recommend to Telecom that it formulate official guidelines, ensuring specifically that subscribers be notified that their services are to be intercepted and monitored `long-term', as distinct from advice to them that `loudspeaker' monitoring will take place; if so, did Telecom accept the Ombudsman's recommendations.

(6) In regard to such covert `long-term' monitoring of subscribers' telephones, without warrant, does Telecom maintain internal files or folders identified as `Interception and Recording of Telephone Conversations'.
(7) Does Telecom's Security and Investigation Section maintain its own filing and record system separately from Telecom's Central Record system.
(8) Was Telecom's Security and Investigation Section maintaining a file on a subscriber, Mr John Doohan of Willagee, Western Australia, and was such a file subsequently culled and removed by Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom. In giving me a response to the honourable senator's question, Telecom has also provided the following background information.

PARA.TAB: Section 7 of the Telecommunications (Interception) (T(I)) Act permits employees of Telecom to record and/or listen to a communication passing over a telecommunications system in relation to:

(i) the installation of any line, or the installation of any equipment, used or intended for use in connection with a telecommunications service or the operation or maintenance of a telecommunications system; or
(ii) the identifying or tracing of any person who has contravened, or is suspected of having contravened or being likely to contravene a provision of Part VIIB of the Crimes Act 1914.
In relation to (i), this has covered situations such as:
(a) the inadvertent overhearing of a conversation in relation to the installation of a particular service or the restoration of a faulty service.

(b) listening to conversations at a telephone exchange in order to find and rectify any abnormal fault condition on a particular customer's service. This procedure is now only carried out where the customer is aware that his/her conversations are being listened to.

(c) the use of Call Charge Analysis Equipment (CCAE) as part of the operation and maintenance of the telecommunications network. This includes day-to-day maintenance activities and the use of CCAE in relation to billing disputes. The use of this equipment does not involve listening to conversations. In the case of billing disputes, it is used to record such details as the type of call (local, STD, IDD), time of call, duration and cost and, in effect, establish the integrity of the metering equipment of a particular service. The normal length of time CCAE is on a service is two to three weeks. The records created are often used to discuss the calling patterns with the customer. The use of CCAE for billing disputes does not necessarily involve the consent of the customer; however, initial use of the equipment is often at the customer's request or with his/her knowledge.

In regard to (ii), this has related to the use of CCAE to identify persons in the circumstances outlined and covers cases such as menacing, harassing or offensive calls or interference with telecommunications services.

Recent advice from the Attorney-General's Department has been to the effect that the T(I) Act does not govern the use of CCAE i.e. its use does not involve the recording of a communication in its passage over a telecommunications system. However, Telecom has no plans to extend its use beyond the circumstances described above. Further, it is expected that the use of CCAE to resolve billing disputes will decline as Telecom continues with its plans of providing itemisation of STD, IDD and 0055 calls on customers' bills. All customers on Telecom's Cellular Mobile Telephone Service receive itemised bills.
Having regard to the foregoing, Telecom has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
(1) Telecom does not `covertly intercept and monitor, without warrant'. There are no warrant provisions in the T(I) Act relating to any Telecom actions permitted under Section 7(2) of that Act.

Telecom is aware of cases occurring in the period up to 1986 where `loudspeaker' monitoring took place without a customer's knowledge at a telephone exchange in order to rectify particular faults. Two cases in particular were subject to detailed investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The length of time involved in monitoring of the two cases was 26 days and one week. The practice did not contravene the T(I) Act but the Ombudsman's investigations led to the current procedures being introduced whereby customers are now informed if any such monitoring is to take place. Telecom pointed out that this monitoring procedure is now rarely used in view of more sophisticated techniques being available to locate and rectify faults.
(2) See reply to part (1).
(3) Telecom has indicated that it would be an extremely time consuming task to try and identify all cases:
(i) prior to 1986 where loudspeaker monitoring took place without the knowledge of the customer, or
(ii) where CCAE was used for circumstances such as billing disputes or the tracing of menacing, harassing or offensive calls.

Having regard to the fact that such activities were or are within Telecom's powers and responsibilities in providing efficient and effective services to its customers, I do not propose to ask Telecom to undertake such a task.
(4) There is no such legislation. However, Telecom does not undertake `covert long-term interception and monitoring' and regards its present practices as being legally and morally responsible.

(5) No. In September 1981 an Assistant Ombudsman wrote to Telecom exploring the possibility of developing instructions to give customers prior notice of an intention to monitor a service by use of a loudspeaker in an exchange. In subsequent correspondence it was mutually agreed that Telecom's practice of giving its employees the discretion not to advise the customer was a reasonable one.
This was on the basis that prior knowledge by the customer may cause a departure from typical calling habits, thus possibly making it difficult to locate a particular fault.

However in 1986 in connection with a similar case raised by the Ombudsman's Office, it was agreed that it would be appropriate in future not to monitor customers' lines by loudspeaker without the consent of the customer concerned.

(6) As previously indicated, Telecom does not undertake `covert, long-term monitoring'. However, it does have internal files or folders in relation to the interception and recording of telephone conversations.
(7) Yes.

(8) Telecom's Protective Services Directorate has not maintained any files on Mr John Doohan. However, it did arrange for creation of a local Central Registry file on his complaints and this file is still held by Telecom. There is also a file containing Mr Doohan's request for information under the Freedom of Information Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 16 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department estimated that the full-year cost of social security payments to migrants who have been in Australia 12 months or less is $280 million; if not, what was the department's most recent estimate.
(2) Which social security payments accounted for the department's most recent estimate and how much did each of these payments contribute to that estimate.
(3) What assumptions were necessary to reach the final estimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Finance has not estimated the full-year cost of social security payments to migrants who have been in Australia 12 months or less as $280 million. The Department's most recent estimate is $251m, for which the unemployment and other benefit payment figures are based on client numbers, provided by the Department of Social Security, for the fortnight prior to 17 June 1991.
(2) This estimate includes the following payments:
Unemployment payments183
Sickness allowance7
Special benefit15
Other benefits(a) 15
Pensions10
Family allowance16
Family allowance supplement5
Total251

(a) Other Benefits include the Adult Migrant English Program Living Allowance, and living allowances associated with DEET formal training programs and with English as a Second Language courses funded by DEET. DSS is reimbursed by DEET for the costs of allowances for DEET courses. AMEP Living Allowance funding was transferred from DILGEA to DSS in July 1991.
(3) This estimate was derived as follows:

For unemployment payments (Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance), sickness benefits (Sickness Allowance from 12 November 1991), special benefits and other benefits, the estimates are based on client numbers, provided by the Department of Social Security, indicating the actual level of these payments made in the fortnight prior to 17 June 1991 to persons whose date of permanent legal residence was 12 months or less. The estimates assume that the number in receipt of these allowances was constant for the previous 12 months. The estimates will vary with fluctuations in the general level of unemployment, the number of visas issued in the previous 12 months, the composition of the formal migration program and the level of trans-Tasman migration (although trans-Tasman recipients would normally have to wait for 6 months before they could access the allowances).

For pensions, the estimate is based on advice from the Department of Social Security, indicating the actual level of pensions paid to migrant pensioners whose date of first arrival in Australia was between 22 June 1990 and 21 June 1991.

In the case of family allowances and family allowance supplement, DSS does not maintain relevant information on its computer systems. The estimate for family allowances has therefore been derived using the age profile of a model migrant intake derived by averaging the profiles of 1988-89 and 1989-90 migrant intakes. The estimate for family allowance supplement again used the model migrant intake and assumed that family allowance supplement was paid only on behalf of dependent children of unemployed migrants who have been in the country 12 months or less.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the statement made by the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories at the conclusion of Question Time on Wednesday, 14 August 1991, that his advice of 13 August 1991 that the Australian Securities Commission had commenced a section 597 examination into matters relating to the payment of Commonwealth monies to the owners of the Ravenshoe Timber Mill, was incorrect and that, in fact, the Australian Securities Commission was conducting an investigation under Section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Law:
(1) What is the difference between the two types of investigation.
(2) Does a section 597 examination require an application to the Court, whereas a section 13 investigation is simply an investigation by the Australian Securities Commission.
(3) Has the Australian Securities Commission been conducting investigations pursuant to section 13 since the matter was first referred to the Attorney-General almost ten weeks ago.

(4) In what way does the Minister's announcement that the Australian Securities Commission is investigating the matter pursuant to section 13, further advance the investigation, any prosecutions which might be appropriate and any recovery action which might be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) Section 597 of the Corporations Law provides for public examination before a court, upon application by the ASC or a prescribed person (usually a liquidator or receiver), of a person or persons, concerned in the affairs of a corporation, who are suspected of misconduct in relation to that corporation. Section 597 may also be used to examine a person or persons who may be capable of giving information about the promotion, formation, management and affairs of a corporation. The Court may, on the application of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) or prescribed person, if it thinks fit, order that the person(s) attend before the Court to be examined on oath as to the affairs of the relevant company.

Section 13(1) provides for general investigatory powers of the ASC. The ASC may under Section 13(1) make such investigations where it has reason to suspect that there may have been a breach of the Corporations Law or a breach of other laws where the contraventions concern the management or affairs of a company or involve fraud or dishonesty and relate to a company. Once the ASC has made a decision to conduct an investigation under section 13, a number of additional powers are available to it under the ASC Law and the Corporations Law, including the power to examine persons, the power to inspect documents, the power to compel the production of documents and the power to apply for a warrant to seize a document.

Whilst the section 597 examination can be used by the ASC in other circumstances, it is used most commonly by liquidators to obtain evidence in respect of the affairs of a corporation. The ASC has broad powers of investigation and information gathering under Part 3 of the ASC Law and usually does not need to have recourse to the provisions of section 597. Although the ASC has decided to embark on a section 13(1) investigation, it would not be precluded from making an application to the court under section 597 if it considered it necessary or desirable for its examinations to be held in public. The provisions of these two sections are not mutually exclusive. However, the need for a s.597 application becomes somewhat redundant once a s.13(1) investigation has been commenced.

(3) The ASC has been conducting investigations into the affairs of the Ravenshoe Timber Mill pursuant to section 13(1) since early August. Under section 13(1) of the ASC Law, the ASC may investigate a matter only `...where it has reasons to suspect that there may have been committed:
(a) a contravention of a national scheme law; or
(b) a contravention of a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, being a contravention that:
(i) concerns the management or affairs of a body corporate; or
(ii) involves fraud or dishonesty and relates to a body corporate, securities or futures contract.
I am advised that in order to meet the requirements of these provisions the ASC had to make a preliminary assessment of a considerable body of complex evidence.

(4) The ASC is an independent statutory body established by the Commonwealth Parliament to regulate the operations of companies and the securities and futures markets. It has been given wide ranging powers to enforce companies and securities laws, including the discretion to decide what action (if any) should be taken in relation to matters that come to its attention during an investigation.

Following an investigation under section 13(1), the ASC may cause a civil proceeding and/or criminal prosecution to be commenced. However, in relation to any criminal proceeding, the question of whether there is a substantive case to answer is a matter for the ASC in consultation with the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.
As far as the ASC's investigation into the Ravenshoe Timber Mill is concerned, it would not be appropriate for me to make any further comment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Social Security: Visit to Ireland

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the trip undertaken by the Minister to the west coast of Ireland in January 1991 (a) what were the names and occupations of each member of the party making the trip; (b) was the trip for the purpose of conducting any and what talks or discussions; (c) what was the subject matter of the talks; (d) what was the duration of the talks; (e) who participated in the talks; (f) what was the precise location of the talks; (g) who arranged the talks; (h) when, by whom and in what circumstances were the talks first proposed; (i) what was the purpose of the talks; (j) what was the outcome of the talks; (k) were any and what decisions taken during the course of, or as a result of the talks; (1) were any and what records kept of the talks and will the Minister make them available; (m) did the trip commence from Dublin or any other and what place in the vicinity thereof; (n) how long did the trip take; (o) were any and what makes, models and types of cars hired for the trip; (p) by whom were such cars hired; (q) did the Minister give any and what instructions as to the mode of travel and the type of vehicle to be used for the trip; (r) why was it necessary to hire vehicles for the trip; (s) were any and what cars attached to the Australian Embassy in Dublin made available for use for the trip; if not, why not; (t) what was the number of official cars attached to the Australian Embassy in Dublin in January 1991; (u) what was the total cost of the trip; (v) what was the cost of each and every component in the cost of the trip; (w) why was it necessary for talks to be held on the west coast; (x) was there any and what reason why the talks could not have been held in Dublin; (y) at what time and on what date did the party leave Dublin for the west coast; (z) at what time and on what date did the party return to Dublin from the west coast; (aa) between what hours and on what dates were the talks held; and (ab) will the Minister make available the transcripts, minutes or documentation relating to the talks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The question raises a large number of issues of various degrees of relevance to the portfolio. Information on several of the matters raised is not available to me.

My visit to Ireland was at the invitation of the Irish Minister for Social Welfare, Dr Michael Woods, who selected the west coast venue, Ashford Castle, which has been the venue of various international meetings hosted by the Irish Government. I am sure the honourable Senator, in asking parts of his question, was not aware of these facts. I shall not add to the insensitivity and lack of diplomacy he has shown by commenting further on these matters.
The purpose of the visit was to settle arrangements for an early 1991 signing of the social security agreement between the countries and to discuss recent developments in social security.

I was accompanied by my wife, my Senior Adviser, Ms Janet Willis, the Secretary to my Department, Mr Derek Volker, and Mrs Volker and the Assistant Secretary, International and Review Branch of the Department, Mr Andrew Phelan. The Ambassador was also present at most functions. My delegation and I held many talks:
in Dublin, I called on the newly-elected President of Ireland, Ms Mary Robinson

on the west coast, I discussed social security matters with Dr Woods and extended an invitation for him to visit Australia to sign the agreement (an invitation he accepted, the agreement being signed here last April)

my delegation held extensive and detailed discussions on social security issues with senior officials of the Irish Department of Social Welfare, including the Secretary General, Mr Ed McCumiskey. There were also technical discussions on the agreement and drafting of it was completed

I also had discussions with Irish Parliamentarians on the benefits of the agreement to the bilateral relationship, a process which I believe assisted the passage of the agreement through the Irish Parliament and accelerated its signing. These took place both at Ashford Castle and in Dublin.

Transport to the west coast of Ireland was arranged by the Australian Embassy. I understand motor transport was chosen for a variety of reasons, including convenience and the unreliability of air travel in the prevailing weather. The delegation arrived in Dublin on 29 December 1990, travelled to Ashford Castle on 1 January and departed Ireland via Dublin on 3 January 1991. The delegation travelled from Ashford Castle straight to Dublin for an official function and then direct to the airport.
There continues to be dispute about the cost of vehicle hire especially in regard to the breakdown of one vehicle for which a charge was made when it was immobile.
I do not intend to make available documents relating to the talks which were conducted in confidence.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Social Security: Visit to Italy

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: Did the Minister visit Italy in January 1991; if so: (a) what official engagements were involved; (b) what was the duration of each offical engagement (d) did the Minister participate in any and which engagements to any and what extent; (e) will the Minister make available the transcripts, minutes or documents relating to the visit; (f) during the course of the aforesaid visit, did the Minister travel to Avellino in southern Italy and to what surrounding areas; if so (i) what was the total cost of any such trip, including food, travel accommodation and other expenses for the Minister and any other and what members of his party, (ii) what was the precise cost for each item of expenditure in respect of such trip, (iii) what was the purpose of such visit, (iv) were any and what official invitations received from any Italian Government officials or local government authorities, (v) will the Minister make available all correspondence or documentation in relation thereto, (vi) what was the nature and duration of any official component of the trip to Avellino, (vii) what was the duration of the trip and between what dates and times did the trip to Avellino occur, and (viii) did the Minister perform any and what official duties at Avellino or in any and what surrounding areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I visited Italy in January 1991, for the purposes of:

discussing with the Italian Government proposed changes to Italian pension laws which adversely affect Australian residents and conflict with the spirit of the social security agreement between the countries
meeting the leaders of key trade union and other organisations to bring their attention to Australian pensioner opposition to the proposed changes to Italian pension laws
meeting representatives of Australian pensioners to address pension concerns
visiting areas affected by earthquakes in the early 1980s rebuilt with Australian money.

I arrived in Rome on the evening of 12 January, had engagements in Rome on 13, 14, 15 and 16 January, travelled south in the late afternoon of 16 January, arriving at night, visited the earthquake affected area around Avellino during 17 January, returned to Rome late the same day and left Rome for Australia on 18 January 1991.
During the course of the visit, I had meetings with the following:
His Holiness the Pope
the Italian Deputy Minister for Labour and Social Security, Mr Ugo Grippo (I had arranged to meet the Minister, the late Senator Donat-Cattin, but the latter's illness prevented this)
the Undersecretary for Foreign Affairs, Mr Claudio Lenoci
various officials in the Italian Ministry of Labour and Social Security, including the Secretary-General
senior officials from the Christian Democrat (CISL), Socialist (UIL) and Communist (CGIL) trade union confederations:
leaders of the return Australian migrant association, ANEA:

In the earthquake affected areas I made official visits to the Avellino Child Development Centre and the San Pasquale Institute Rest Home for the Aged, Benevento, and met officials, pensioners and patients.
I travelled in an Embassy car with my wife and a senior Embassy official and the rest of the party was in a small bus.
Costs related to one night's accommodation, dinner and breakfast.
The visits were extremely well received and demonstrated Australia's ongoing close relations with the region and its people.
I do not intend to make available documents on discussions which were conducted in confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Could the Minister explain why copies of the Constitution, which is the very basis of our Parliamentary process and fundamental to our laws, can be sold by the Parliamentary Education Office in Parliament House for only 60 cents a copy while the same copy is sold at almost six times that amount by Government Bookshops.
(2) Does the Minister agree that copies of our Constitution should be freely available.
(3) Is the Minister aware that other western countries, such as the USA, give away free copies of their Constitution.

(4) Is the Minister aware that the relatively inexpensive copy is difficult to read because of the print size and that to obtain a readable, workable copy costs in the vicinity of $10 at Government Bookshops.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The normal retail price in the Parliament House Bookshop for single copies of the A6 version of the Australian Constitution is $2.50, the same price as is charged by AGPS Bookshops. The Parliamentary Education Office does make copies available at 60 cents per copy but only to educational institutions ordering a minimum of 30 copies. While AGPS also gives trade and bulk discounts where applicable, in accordance with Government policy, the pricing of AGPS sales has regard to recovering the overall cost of publishing and distributing its publications.

(2) Access to the Australian Constitution is readily available to all Australians through public libraries, schools and other publicly funded institutions. As indicated above, purchase of the Constitution is available from Government outlets at prices ranging from 60 cents upwards depending on the quantity and nature of the client and the quality of the edition.

(3) Not all western countries have a written constitution and those that have adopt a range of policies in respect of the pricing and availability of copies of the document. As an initiative of the US Bicentennial Commission, the United States of America provides copies of its constitution free of charge but copies are also sold to the public by the US Government Printing Office.

(4) The price of a publication reflects the cost of its production. The size of print and quality of paper of the A6 version enable it to be offered for sale at the inexpensive price of $2.50. A higher quality version, involving large print size, is available for $8.50 while a Department of the Senate publication including an outline of the content and structure of the Constitution is available for $9.95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: In respect of the reply to Question No. 1004 (Senate Hansard, 11 September 1991 p.1405) relating to mining interests in Kakadu National Park, is his statement that, `it is presently not possible to provide an answer to the Hon. Senator's question in respect of each such interest' intended to imply that neither his Department, nor any other Commonwealth authority, maintains a list or register of such interests; if so, will the Minister instruct his Department to prepare such a list without delay, given that the existence of mining interests within the national park area is a significant matter for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in its consideration of a plan of management for the park, and given that the creation and management of mining or other interests in the park land has been the responsibility of the Commonwealth since 1 July 1978; if not, will the Minister provide the list to me and the Senate, as originally requested in Question No. 1004.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: While the Commonwealth possesses records relating to mining and other interests in land which now comprises Kakadu National Park neither my Department nor any other Commonwealth authority has prepared a single list or register of such interests. The land comprising Kakadu National Park is now vested in, or leased from Aboriginal Land Trusts by, the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, who is responsible for the administration and management of Kakadu National Park. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has recently begun an assessment of the status, if any, of all mining and other interests presently recorded as existing in the Park and may need to seek assistance from my Department in this regard. Persons claiming to have a particular interest in the Park would be able to have that interest considered in the assessment process if they come forward. The existence of mining interests is not regarded by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service as a significant matter for consideration in the preparation of a new plan of management for the Park. As noted in the answer to Question No. 1004 (Senate Hansard, 11 September 1991 p.1405) subsection 10(1A) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 does not permit operations for the recovery of minerals to be carried on in the Park.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to this country's surplus of staple foods such as wheat, beef, mutton and sugar and of wool, what action, if any, has the Government initiated to sell these items to the Soviet Union, which is reportedly undergoing a critical shortage of such staple foods and faces a winter of hardship.
(2) Have trade missions been sent to the Soviet Union to market Australian goods since the failure of last month's coup.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In view of the rapid deterioration of the Soviet economy and thereby one of Australia's major commodity export markets, the Government initiated several steps from the beginning of 1990 to facilitate food and other exports to the Soviet Union.

In February 1990, the Australian Government signed a Commodities Agreement with the Soviet Union, which, together with the Fisheries Agreement also signed at that time, provided a commitment to a wider, more substantive relationship, providing a reliable framework within which Australian and Soviet concerns could negotiate long term contracts. The structure upon which the Agreement is built consists of a Schedule which lists indicative targets for agricultural and resource products including wheat, sugar, butter, mutton, wool, barley and protein crops. Despite the Government's effort to encourage food exports to the Soviet Union through this medium, actual export figures have rarely reached quantity indicator levels, largely owing to Soviet economic and political disarray and hard currency shortages. In consequence, provision of credit has become the central issue in fostering agricultural trade.

In November 1990, in order to assist the Soviets in resuming purchases of Australian agricultural products, the Government underwrote two credit facilities administered by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. The first provides $100 million credit on 2 year terms for the sale of 1 million tonnes of wheat and barley, and has been fully utilised. The second is a $400 million, 240 day rollover credit facility to support traditional trade with the Soviet Union, and has been almost fully utilised to cover wool and meat sales. The Government is continuing to monitor the credit situation.
(2) There have as yet been no trade missions to the Soviet Union since the August coup.

In July 1990 a trade fair was held in Vladivostok at which Australian mining and other equipment was displayed. The display was a success and revealed significant potential opportunities for Australia in the Soviet Far East.

I understand that Austrade is monitoring the situation in the Soviet Union carefully, with an eye to opportunities for trade missions. Indeed, at the beginning of October the Senior Trade Commissioner in Moscow was researching opportunities in the Soviet Far East for an Australian Food Processing and Distribution Mission to be run under the Australia/USSR Agricultural Agreement administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the present plight of Australian pineapple producers who are battling against cheap subsidised imports from the Philippines, Indonesia and other countries in the region and which threaten the financial viability of the Australian pineapple industry, will the Minister take appropriate action to rectify the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Increased competition from imported food products generally have been widely reported recently. In particular, competition from a number of our Asian neighbours which have the advantage of low labour costs and concessionary tariffs under the Australian System of Tariff Preferences.

It is important, however, that these imports be put into perspective. Australian exported about $977 million worth of food and beverages to the ASEAN countries in 1990-91, almost three times the level of imports of food and beverages from those countries.

Action to explicitly restrict imports would be contrary to the Government's industry and international trade policies and could result in retaliatory action which would clearly be to Australia's detriment.

Many of Australia's internationally competitive primary industries which export to the region are located in Queensland and thus it would be against the interests of the wider community to increase controls on imports.
I am aware that the pineapple industry is concerned about the increasing level of imports of canned pineapple over recent years.

This situation appears to have followed a decision by Australia's only pineapple cannery, Golden Circle, to not supply `generic' labelled product to Australian supermarket chains. The supermarket chains subsequently placed orders with overseas suppliers who were prepared to meet their requirements.

The increase in import levels in recent times coincides with a shortfall in the availability of Australian canned pineapple due to adverse weather in 1989. Golden Circle management say this situation will not be rectified until 1992 at which time, with increased supplies of raw product into the cannery, I hope that Golden Circle will consider possibilities to increase exports and to improve its competitive position.
Nevertheless, the Government has been actively considering the issue of food imports generally.
The Government believes that Australian industries should not be subject to unfair market competition from imports.

As foreshadowed in the March 1991 industry policy statement, anti-dumping procedures have been further strengthened. The changes speed up processing of complaints by industry so that, where there is injury to local producers, in most cases provisional measures will be available earlier.

The question alleges that imports from the region are subsidised. While I am not aware of any evidence to support this contention, if evidence exists, the industry has open to it the option of submitting a case to the Australian Customs Service seeking to impose countervailing duties.

The Government is developing an economic environment in which our industries can become internationally competitive. Decisions such as the general tariff reductions, increased support for research and development and taxation reforms are aimed at reducing costs and increasing efficiency.

The Government strongly supports research and development for the horticultural sector, including the pineapple industry, through the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The Corporation's research program this year will be in the region of $9.3m, up from $5.2m in 1990-91.

The pineapple industry could also benefit from work being undertaken to develop an industry development strategy for the processed food industry, arising from the Prime Minister's Science Council. This initiative is well advanced and a submission should be ready for the Government's consideration before the end of the year.

It is true that pineapple imports from developing countries enjoy a preference margin of 5 per cent under Australia's system of tariff preferences. I have indicated that I would examine this situation and I am currently doing so. This is an involved issue which impacts on domestic industry and our bilateral trade relations with developing countries.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: Has Professor Huey, appointed to examine the Jindalee Over-the-Horizon Radar project, commented that the safety perimeter should be greater than 1.6 kilometres but less than 2.5 kilometres from the transmitter; if so, at what distance from the transmitter will the safety perimeter be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In his final report, Professor Huey did suggest that the safety perimeter should be greater than 1.6 kilometres but less than 2.5 kilometres and the location of the safety fence should be reviewed to include an adequate safety margin for good propagation conditions which may enhance the signal strength under specific circumstances.

The Department of Defence noted that this recommendation was premised on the provision of an additional 6 decibel (4 times) field strength level margin over levels mandated by AS 2772.1—1990 and the even more stringent European IRPA guidelines. The Department therefore approached Professor Huey and requested he review his recommendation taking into account that the Department's field strength calculations had been based on the absolute best propagating conditions and that the IRPA guidelines, with which the Department will comply, already have inbuilt safety margins.
In response Professor Huey advised that the fence could be safely erected at a distance of 1.6 kilometres provided that further adequate precautions were taken.

As a consequence, the safety fence will be erected at a distance of 1.6 kilometres and these precautionary measures, which cover earthing of fences and substantial metallic structures, the prohibition against the erection of new substantial metallic structures and procedures to guard against the possibility of RF burns, will be implemented by the Department.
A Public Notice to this effect was published in the Longreach Leader on 30 August 1991.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Women: Membership of Boards, Councils and Committees

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 10 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Labour caucus motion of 21 August 1988, requiring that women get at least 25 per cent of the places on Government boards, councils and committees, please supply an update of the information given in answer to House of Representatives Question on Notice No 2093 (House of Representatives Hansard, 22 December 1989, p.3580).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Finance has the power to make appointments to three boards as follows:

EMPHASIS.TAB: The Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No 1

PARA.TAB: Section 20 of the Superannuation Act 1990 provides that there is established a board called the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No 1.
Section 23 of the Act provides for the Board to consist of:
(a) a Chairperson; and
(b) four other trustees appointed on a part-time basis.
Currently none of the members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees is a woman.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No 2

PARA.TAB: Section 27A of the Superannuation Act 1976 provides that there is established a board called the Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No 2.
Section 27F of the Act provides for the Board to consist of:
(a) the persons who for the time being are members, or acting as members, of Commonwealth Superannuation Board of Trustees No 1; and
(b) two additional part-time members.
Currently the two additional members of the Board of Trustees are men.

One of the additional members is on long term leave of absence. After consultation with the ACTU, the person appointed as an alternate member, during this leave of absence and during all periods when that particular member is absent from duty or from Australia or is unable to perform the duties of the office, is a woman.
The Board of Directors of Commonwealth Funds Management Limited (CFM)
CFM's Articles provide that the Board shall be made up of:
(a) a part-time Chairperson;
(b) three to five part-time Directors; and
(c) a full-time Managing Director.

The Articles provide that all Board appointments (after the initial appointments) shall be made by a resolution of the company. This means, in effect, that the Minister acting for and on behalf of the Commonwealth, the sole shareholder of CFM, has the power to make Board appointments.
Currently none of the members of CFM's Board is a woman. It is expected that a woman will be appointed to a vacant part-time Director's position on the Board shortly.
